Title: Temporarily repair a lost-cause graphics card by heating it up in an oven

Toolbox.Name: working oven with fan and temerature setting

Lines.Text: remove the video card ( if it's installed in the system )

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the video card (if it's installed in the system)

Lines.Text: if the card is still under warranty , get it repaired by the manufacturer . otherwise , continue with this guide .

Steps.Text_raw: If the card is still under warranty, get it repaired by the manufacturer.  Otherwise, continue with this guide.

Lines.Text: precision screwdriver ( s ) -- usually phillips 0 and/or 1 for the fan and anything else screwed onto the graphics card
aluminium foil to cover heat sensitive components and to prop up the card on your baking tray
some thermal paste to replace the paste you clean off the chips
paper towel to rub any excess of old heatsink compound from the components
an oven
a baking tray

Steps.Text_raw: Precision screwdriver(s) -- usually Phillips #0 and/or #1 for the fan and anything else screwed onto the graphics card Aluminium foil to cover heat sensitive components and to prop up the card on your baking tray Some thermal paste to replace the paste you clean off the chips Paper towel to rub any excess of old heatsink compound from the components An oven A baking tray

Lines.Text: preheat the oven to 385 f ( 195 c ) .
if you've already finished this guide once and are baking again , increase the temperature slightly -- 395 f ( 200 c ) or 400 f ( 205 c ) .
solder melts at different temperatures depending on the type , so if you're squeamish , you might start at 375 f .
due to new information - most of these temporary repairs are only expanding/shrinking of bumps under the graphics chip surface-mount , so lower heat might work too .

Steps.Text_raw: Preheat the oven to 385F (195C). If you've already finished this guide once and are baking again, increase the temperature slightly  -- 395F (200C) or 400F (205C). Solder melts at different temperatures depending on the type, so if you're squeamish, you might start at 375F. Due to new information - most of these temporary repairs are only expanding/shrinking of bumps under the graphics chip surface-mount, so lower heat might work too.

Lines.Text: while the oven is pre-heating :
remove the screws or clips holding your fan and heatsink and any ductwork from the video card .
gently take the fan/heatsink off .
remove any old heatsink compound from the chips ( using a paper towel ) . --note some of the memory or other chips might have heat pads , only remove those if you have a replacement !
place the screws in a safe place .
be sure there are not many or any plastic components on the board , if there are , they might melt .
i usually prop up the video card on small scrunched up balls of aluminium-foil ( in the corners ) so the board doesn't rest on any components .

Steps.Text_raw: While the oven is pre-heating: Remove the screws or clips holding your fan and heatsink and any ductwork from the video card. Gently take the fan/heatsink off. Remove any old heatsink compound from the chips (using a paper towel). --NOTE some of the memory or other chips might have heat pads, only remove those if you have a replacement! Place the screws in a safe place. Be sure there are not many or any plastic components on the board, if there are, they might melt. I usually prop up the video card on small scrunched up balls of aluminium-foil (in the corners) so the board doesn't rest on any components.
Tools_extracted: working oven with fan and temerature setting

Lines.Text: '''be patient ! ''' -- if your oven has a window you'll probably see the solder melt when it gets really shiny .
you want to heat the gpu slowly .
my experience : ps3 - 6 minutes , xbox - 4-6 minutes , desktop boards -12 minutes , laptop boards - 8-12 minutes , gfx - 8-15 min .
use this as a guide only - not a golden rule , different materials will melt at different rates .

note : who is my in the box above ? ? - the original author gaspard here ; i never had this step in my version of the guide , and i only ever tried this on a video card , not a laptop or desktop or console

re-flowing might work for some circuit-boards , but new more scientific data has revealed that most quick , temporary repairs like this are actually caused by expanding and contracting bumps on the bottom of the surface mount chips such as the main gpu or the memory modules ( which can happen at lower temperatures as well )

Steps.Text_raw: '''Be patient!''' -- if your oven has a window you'll probably see the solder melt when it gets really shiny. You want to heat the GPU SLOWLY. 5 -10 mins at 200 - 220 C° (395 - 425 F°) My experience: PS3 - 6 minutes,  Xbox - 4-6 minutes, desktop boards -12 minutes , laptop boards - 8-12 minutes, GFX - 8-15min. Use this as a guide only - not a golden rule, different materials will melt at different rates. NOTE: who is "My" in the box above?? - The original Author "Gaspard" here; I never had this step in my version of the guide, and I only ever tried this on a video card, not a laptop or desktop or console Re-flowing might work for some circuit-boards, but new more scientific data has revealed that most "quick, temporary" repairs like this are actually caused by expanding and contracting "Bumps" on the bottom of the surface mount chips such as the main GPU or the memory modules (which can happen at lower temperatures as well)

Lines.Text: once the oven is at the required temperature , set a timer for 8-12 minutes .
place the baking sheet or dish in the middle of the oven .
do not leave the oven unattended at any cost !

Steps.Text_raw: Once the oven is at the required temperature, set a timer for 8-12 minutes. Place the baking sheet or dish in the middle of the oven. Do not leave the oven unattended at any cost!

Lines.Text: when ready , open the oven door - let smoke out . keep opening and closing about 5 to 10 times , this equalises temperature differences .
hold your tray firmly . be careful , try not to touch anything or make sudden moves as components can be dislodged while the solder is still soft .
you will notice a smell from the molten solder/flux .
leave the card to cool for a while . note that using fans to accelerate the cooling process might result in weaker joints or unsuccessful re-flow .

Steps.Text_raw: When ready, open the oven door - let smoke out. Keep opening and closing about 5 to 10 times, this equalises temperature differences. Hold your tray firmly. Be careful, try not to touch anything or make sudden moves as components can be dislodged while the solder is still soft. You will notice a smell from the molten solder/flux. Leave the card to cool for a while. Note that using fans to accelerate the cooling process might result in weaker joints or unsuccessful re-flow.

Lines.Text: you have 2 options :
1. test the card quickly without reinstalling the fan/heatsink .
2. reinstall the fan/heatsink , then test the card .
most people will want to test the card to see if it powers on and passes the post .
if you are trying it without the heatsink/fan , do not run it for longer than 30 seconds .
if the card still doesn't work after baking , you may repeat the process and might need to increase its time .

Steps.Text_raw: You have 2 options: 1. Test the card quickly without reinstalling the fan/heatsink. 2. Reinstall the fan/heatsink, then test the card. Most people will want to test the card to see if it powers on and passes the POST. If you are trying it without the heatsink/fan, DO NOT run it for longer than 30 seconds. If the card still doesn't work after baking, you may repeat the process and might need to increase its time.
Tools_extracted: working oven with fan and temerature setting

Lines.Text: apply some thermal grease onto the main chip and everywhere else where that is necessary .
use only a small amount of thermal paste and spread evenly over the surface using a piece of cardboard or a credit card for example .

new information : you can also just use the rice/pea option where you place a small pea or large grain of rice sized blob of thermal paste in the middle of the cleaned gpu and the pressure of applying the heat-sink will spread it out evenly
if there is thermal tape or pads that were removed for the reflow , place these back in their original position .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply some thermal grease onto the main chip and everywhere else where that is necessary. Use only a small amount of thermal paste  and spread evenly over the surface using a piece of cardboard or a credit card for example. "NEW" information: You can also just use the "Rice/pea" option where you place a small pea or large grain of rice sized blob of thermal paste in the middle of the cleaned GPU and the pressure of applying the heat-sink will spread it out evenly If there is thermal tape or pads that were removed for the reflow, place these back in their original position.

Lines.Text: place the heat-sink over the gpu carefully , lining up any screws or clips .
insert and tighten all the screws carefully ! they are usually quite small , and the pcb may be damaged if the screws are over tightened .

tighten the screws in an alternating pattern . e . g . top left , bottom right , top right , bottom left . with more than 4 screws , use a star pattern when tightening the screws ensuring all screws are evenly tightened .
if you notice any dust , make sure to clean that as well .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the heat-sink over the GPU carefully, lining up any screws or clips. Insert and tighten all the screws carefully! They are usually quite small, and the PCB may be damaged if the screws are over tightened. Tighten the screws in an alternating pattern.  E.G.  Top left, Bottom right, Top right, Bottom left. With more than 4 screws, use a "Star" pattern when tightening the screws ensuring all screws are evenly tightened. If you notice any dust, make sure to clean that as well.

Lines.Text: verify that the fan was reconnected ( if there is one ) .
verify that the fan spins when the pc is powered up .
make sure the gpu works when loading up in windows , etc .
a good program to get is gpu-z . it can display the gpu temperature on supported cards .
good luck

Steps.Text_raw: Verify that the fan was reconnected (if there is one). Verify that the fan spins when the PC is powered up. Make sure the GPU works when loading up in Windows, etc. A good program to get is GPU-Z. it can display the GPU temperature on supported cards. GOOD LUCK
Tools_extracted: working oven with fan and temerature setting

Title: How to clean and reapply thermal paste on ATI Radeon X1900 XTX

Lines.Text: start by removing the card from the pc if you haven't already .

Steps.Text_raw: Start by removing the card from the PC if you haven't already.

Lines.Text: the fan's power cable is located towards the bottom-left of the card .
disconnect the cable from the card .
the cable and its connector on the x1900 are fragile . be careful , and try not to use excessive force when removing it .

Steps.Text_raw: The fan's power cable is located towards the bottom-left of the card. Disconnect the cable from the card. The cable and its connector on the X1900 are fragile.  Be careful, and try not to use excessive force when removing it.

Lines.Text: removing the heatsink from the card :
the clamp is held on by four small phillips screws . remove them , then the clamp .
remove the four phillips screws surrounding the clamp .

Steps.Text_raw: Removing the heatsink from the card: The clamp is held on by four small Phillips screws.  Remove them, then the clamp. Remove the four phillips screws surrounding the clamp.

Lines.Text: seperate the heatsink and the card .

Steps.Text_raw: Seperate the heatsink and the card.

Lines.Text: replacing thermal paste :
using a q-tip/cotton swab and rubbing alcohol , clean the copper plate that protrudes from the bottom of the heatsink .

Steps.Text_raw: Replacing Thermal Paste: Using a Q-tip/cotton swab and rubbing alcohol, clean the copper plate that protrudes from the bottom of the heatsink.

Lines.Text: removing the heatsink's plastic cover :
remove these phillips screws .
seperate the plastic cover from the metal heat sink .

Steps.Text_raw: Removing the heatsink's plastic cover: Remove these Phillips screws. Seperate the plastic cover from the metal heat sink.

Lines.Text: cleaning dust out of the heat sink :
using a cotton swab/q-tip , clean the edges of the heat sink . you can also use canned air if available .

Steps.Text_raw: Cleaning dust out of the heat sink: Using a cotton swab/q-tip, clean the edges of the heat sink.  You can also use canned air if available.

Lines.Text: using the same method that you used to clean the copper plate , clean the surface of the gpu die .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same method that you used to clean the copper plate, clean the surface of the GPU die.

Lines.Text: re-applying thermal paste :
apply a small glob of thermal paste to the corner of the die , ( i recommend using arctic silver 5 ) and use an index card to spread a thin , even layer of it over the surface of the chip .
for more detailed directions , follow our guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Re-Applying Thermal Paste: Apply a small glob of thermal paste to the corner of the die, (I recommend using [product|IF179-010|Arctic Silver 5]) and use an index card to spread a thin, even layer of it over the surface of the chip. For more detailed directions, follow our [guide|744|Applying Thermal Paste Guide].

Title: Microsoft Wireless Laser Mouse 6000 and 5000 Disassembly

Lines.Text: remove the battery door and use a 8 torx tamper proof bit to remove the center screw . pry the cover of the mouse starting from the back and lifting it up toward the wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery door and use a #8 Torx Tamper Proof Bit to remove the center screw. Pry the cover of the mouse starting from the back and lifting it up toward the wheel.

Lines.Text: remove the screw from the cover with a 1 phillips . unclip the two fins from the plate by lifting up on each gently . remove the silver plate by prying the cover striaght up .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the screw from the cover with a #1 Phillips.  Unclip the two fins from the plate by lifting up on each gently. Remove the silver plate by prying the cover striaght up.

Lines.Text: gently lift up on the left shroud until it detaches . you can also detach the two side buttons . they are compression fit . pry them each gently out of the hinge with a flat blade .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift up on the left shroud until it detaches. You can also detach the two side buttons. They are compression fit. Pry them each gently out of the hinge with a flat blade.

Lines.Text: ''' be extremely careful ''' there is a small spring between the housing and the base plate of the mouse . the ribbon cable that attachs the mouse wheel is tough to remove . it is compression fit without tabs . i needed to use a small flat blade screwdriver to pry it out of the socket . the mouse wheel housing that clicks to the left and right is compression fitted on the bottom only . you can separate it from the other housing by lifting up on the bottom hinge . the bottom housing is again a compression fit hinge attaching it to the base plate with spring .

Steps.Text_raw: ''' Be Extremely Careful '''  There is a small spring between the housing and the base plate of the mouse. The ribbon cable that attachs the mouse wheel is tough to remove. It is compression fit without tabs.  I needed to use a small flat blade screw driver to pry it out of the socket. The mouse wheel housing that clicks to the left and right is compression fitted on the bottom only. You can separate it from the other housing by lifting up on the bottom "hinge". The bottom housing is again a compression fit hinge attaching it to the base plate with spring.

Lines.Text: the mouse wheel assembly comes apart easily .

Steps.Text_raw: The mouse wheel assembly comes apart easily.

Lines.Text: the circuit board is all one piece that lifts straight out . as you lift out the circuit board push the battery terminals so they clear the base plate . the reset pin will come loose after the circuit board is removed .

Steps.Text_raw: The circuit board is all one piece that lifts straight out.  As you lift out the circuit board   push the battery terminals so they clear the base plate. The reset pin will come loose after the circuit board is removed.

Lines.Text: cleaning time ! now all the plastic parts are separated you can clean them . i used a crest spin brush with simple green . spray the large parts and then brush and rinse in the sink . for the smaller parts spray and brush over a container and then rinse in water in another container . let all the parts air dry and use compressed air for the small parts before reassembling .

Steps.Text_raw: Cleaning Time!  Now all the plastic parts are separated you can clean them.  I used a crest spin brush with simple green. Spray the large parts and then brush and rinse in the sink.  For the smaller parts spray and brush over a container and then rinse in water in another container.  Let all the parts air dry and use compressed air for the small parts before reassembling.

Title: Iomega Z100S2 Disk Reader Replacement

Lines.Text: push in the plastic tab that can be seen through cracks in the front left corner using a spudger .

Steps.Text_raw: Push in the plastic tab that can be seen through cracks in the front left corner using a spudger.

Lines.Text: move down the same side and push in the plastic tab .

Steps.Text_raw: Move down the same side and push in the plastic tab.

Lines.Text: move to the front right side and once again push in the plastic tab .
there is not a fourth tab to push in after this one .

Steps.Text_raw: Move to the front right side and once again push in the plastic tab. There is not a fourth tab to push in after this one.

Lines.Text: grab the cover by the front side and pull upwards .
you might encounter some resistance . pull firmly , but don't yank it .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab the cover by the front side and pull upwards. You might encounter some resistance. Pull firmly, but don't yank it.

Lines.Text: tilt the front case down until the pegs detach from the bottom of the case .
lift up and outward .
the motherboard will be loose at this point .

Steps.Text_raw: Tilt the front case down until the pegs detach from the bottom of the case. Lift up and outward. The motherboard will be loose at this point.

Lines.Text: unhook the two springs from the front plastic hooks .
the black side rails of the reader should easily slide forward and off .

Steps.Text_raw: Unhook the two springs from the front plastic hooks. The black side rails of the reader should easily slide forward and off.

Lines.Text: there is a white tab connected to the motherboard . pull it upward by gently rocking it back and forth .
the tab does not come completely out , it only slides up slightly , so don't rip it out !

Steps.Text_raw: There is a white tab connected to the motherboard. Pull it upward by gently rocking it back and forth. The tab does not come completely out, it only slides up slightly, so don't rip it out!

Lines.Text: grab the reader by its sides and gently pull it upward .
there are two wires still connected to the bottom of the reader that haven't been detached .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab the reader by its sides and gently pull it upward. There are two wires still connected to the bottom of the reader that haven't been detached.

Lines.Text: disconnect the white wires by using tweezers to gently pull the bottom connector toward you .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the white wires by using tweezers to gently pull the bottom connector toward you.

Lines.Text: disconnect the thin ribbon wire by using tweezers to gently pull the connector at the bottom toward you .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the thin ribbon wire by using tweezers to gently pull the connector at the bottom toward you.

Lines.Text: lift the reader up and out from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the reader up and out from the device.

Title: Repairing an LCD Display with failed capacitors

Lines.Text: these steps are as generic as possible , since most lcd displays use a similar design . however , you will need to think carefully about how to take the display apart so you can put it back together , and have it still work !
the images are from viewsonic vx924 lcd monitor blinking green power button ( youtube ) . you should watch it through once to get an idea for what it's like .
first , remove the plastic back of the monitor . the stand/pedestal may be attached by screws , or the back and the stand may all be one unit .
keep the screws you removed with the plastic back . that way they won't get mixed up with the screws you take out of the internal parts .
there is also probably some sort of snap-on device molded into the plastic back .
in the video , a piece of steel is used . a screwdriver or a piece of strong , flat plastic can also do the job .
snapping the back off should take some strength ; however , too much force will permanently damage the plastic .

start with very little force and poke the edges of the back . if one corner moves easily but another corner seems solid , then you may have missed a screw . gradually increase the force you are using until the snaps come off .

Steps.Text_raw: These steps are as generic as possible, since most LCD displays use a similar design. However, you will need to think carefully about how to take the display apart so you can put it back together, and have it still work! The images are from [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZccykxrtX9g|Repair ViewSonic VX924 LCD Monitor Blinking Green power Button] (youtube). You should watch it through once to get an idea for what it's like. First, remove the plastic back of the monitor. The stand/pedestal may be attached by screws, or the back and the stand may all be one unit. Keep the screws you removed with the plastic back. That way they won't get mixed up with the screws you take out of the internal parts. There is also probably some sort of snap-on device molded into the plastic back. In the video, a piece of steel is used. A screwdriver or a piece of strong, flat plastic can also do the job. Snapping the back off should take some strength; however, too much force will permanently damage the plastic. Start with very little force and poke the edges of the back. If one corner moves easily but another corner seems solid, then you may have missed a screw. Gradually increase the force you are using until the snaps come off.

Lines.Text: after removing the back , you need to unscrew the power unit .
some displays use an external brick and have a 12 v dc power plug .
most displays , especially larger ones , have an ac plug ( wall outlet ) . this guide shows a display with an ac plug .
locate the power unit and remove any screws to access it .
you may also need to remove protecting tape . this tape blocks rf noise ( static ) from distorting the display . it is ok to cut the tape carefully , or you may be able to unpeel it .
unplug all the cables that come from the power unit and supply power to the other parts of the display .
'''''be sure you memorize how they go back together ! '''''
it's usually a good idea to pull out your digital camera and shoot pictures of the boards before you take them apart . this will help you put them together the same way .

Steps.Text_raw: After removing the back, you need to unscrew the power unit. Some displays use an external "brick" and have a 12V DC power plug. Most displays, especially larger ones, have an AC plug (wall outlet). This guide shows a display with an AC plug. Locate the power unit and remove any screws to access it. You may also need to remove protecting tape. This tape blocks RF noise ("static") from distorting the display. It is ok to cut the tape carefully, or you may be able to unpeel it. Unplug all the cables that come from the power unit and supply power to the other parts of the display. '''''Be sure you memorize how they go back together!''''' It's usually a good idea to pull out your digital camera and shoot pictures of the boards before you take them apart. This will help you put them together the same way.

Lines.Text: identifying bad capacitors is fairly simple . start with a for images of bad capacitors to see what they look like .

if one capacitor has failed , there is a good chance the ones around it will fail , or may have partially failed . they were manufactured around the same time . also , when a component fails , the rest of the circuit can be damaged by the electrical stress .
doing them all at the same time is fairly easy .
new capacitors cost a few cents .
each capacitor is coded on the side with :
manufacturer and/or product ( green box in the image )
red box : capacity ( micro farads ) ; blue box : voltage ( v ) ; yellow circle : temperature rating ( c )
notice also how the capacitor on the right has obviously blown out .

Steps.Text_raw: Identifying bad capacitors is fairly simple. Start with a [http://www.google.com/images?q=bad+capacitor|search for images of bad capacitors] to see what they look like. If one capacitor has failed, there is a good chance the ones around it will fail, or may have partially failed. They were manufactured around the same time. Also, when a component fails, the rest of the circuit can be damaged by the electrical stress. Doing them all at the same time is fairly easy. New capacitors cost a few cents. Each capacitor is coded on the side with: Manufacturer and/or Product (Green box in the image) Red box: Capacity (micro Farads); Blue box: Voltage (V); Yellow circle: Temperature Rating (C) Notice also how the capacitor on the right has obviously "blown out".

Lines.Text: you can get replacement capacitors from mouser , digi-key , or arrow , or a local electronics parts store .
be sure to match '''''all''''' the requirements :
capacity ( micro farads )
voltage ( v )
temperature rating ( c )
capacitor diameter ( mm )
obviously , the manufacturer is not something you need to match .

you can go over on capacitor ratings to some extent so the monitor has more of a safety level when in use and less likey to blow to voltage . this can be bad if the capacitor is failing due to over voltage , sometimes the cap is like a surge protector because it fails open .

Steps.Text_raw: You can get replacement capacitors from Mouser, Digi-key, or Arrow, or a local electronics parts store. Be sure to match '''''all''''' the requirements: Capacity (micro Farads) Voltage (V) Temperature Rating (C) Capacitor Diameter (mm) Obviously, the manufacturer is not something you need to match. You can go over on capacitor ratings to some extent so the monitor has more of a safety level when in use and less likey to blow to voltage. *this can be bad if the capacitor is failing due to over voltage, sometimes the cap is like a surge protector because it fails open.

Lines.Text: match the capacitor diameter in mm .

Steps.Text_raw: Match the capacitor diameter in mm.

Lines.Text: use a screwdriver or piece of metal to short across the legs of the old capacitors , while they are still in the board . this will short out any remaining power left in them so they don't spark or shock you while you do the repair .
using a soldering iron , remove the old capacitors . then solder in the new ones .
replace the board and screw it into place .
replace all the cables that you removed .
if you feel brave , you may want to test the display before putting the plastic back on .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a screwdriver or piece of metal to short across the legs of the old capacitors, while they are still in the board. This will "short out" any remaining power left in them so they don't spark or shock you while you do the repair. Using a soldering iron, remove the old capacitors. Then solder in the new ones. Replace the board and screw it into place. Replace all the cables that you removed. If you feel brave, you may want to test the display before putting the plastic back on.

Subject: Failed Capacitors

Title: Repairing Viewsonic Optiquest Q9 Power supply repair capacitor replacement

Lines.Text: first off unplug the monitor from power as well as from the back of the computer . find a flat surface and lay the monitor on its face so that you can get to the back of it . the screws that hold the monitor stand on are covered by a small plastic bezel ( shown in photo with the red arrow ) . this is held on with just pressure and if you squeeze at the points mark with a blue circle it should pop free and the bezel can be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: First off unplug the monitor from power as well as from the back of the computer. Find a flat surface and lay the monitor on its face so that you can get to the back of it.    The screws that hold the monitor stand on are covered by a small plastic bezel ( shown in photo with the red arrow).  This is held on with just pressure and if you squeeze at the points mark with a blue circle it should pop free and the bezel can be removed.

Lines.Text: once the plastic bezel is removed it will expose the 8 screws that need to be removed , 4 on each side . use the phillips screwdriver to remove these screws . there are 2 types of screws here so as you remove them take note of the hole they came out of so that you can rebuild it correctly after you are done . here is a picture of 1 set of screws to show you the 2 different sizes . this is from the left hand set of 4 screws . they are laid out how they came out .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the plastic bezel is removed it will expose the 8 screws that need to be removed, 4 on each side.  Use the Phillips screw driver to remove these screws.  There are 2 types of screws here so as you remove them take note of the hole they came out of so that you can rebuild it correctly after you are done.  Here is a picture of 1 set of screws to show you the 2 different sizes.  This is from the left hand set of 4 screws.  They are laid out how they came out.

Lines.Text: look at what would have been the bottom of the monitor and on the right hand side there is a small slot . this is our starting point to open up the monitor . use a flat blade screwdriver in this hole and twist it to pop open the case . at this point this case is held together by snap clips via pressure . work from this hole across the bottom and then up both sides . slide the screwdriver in the open space between the two pieces until it gets tight and then twist gently to open the next snap points . the top is going to be the hardest to open . keep the back flat as possible while opening .

Steps.Text_raw: Look at what would have been the bottom of the monitor and on the right hand side there is a small slot.  This is our starting point to open up the monitor.  Use a flat blade screw driver in this hole and twist it to pop open the case.  At this point this case is held together by snap clips via pressure.  Work from this hole across the bottom and then up both sides.  Slide the screw driver in the open space between the two pieces until it gets tight and then twist gently to open the next snap points.  The top is going to be the hardest to open.  Keep the back flat as possible while opening.

Lines.Text: once the back of the monitor is loose you can start to lift it free . first item to watch is the power cord . it should slide up and be free to help open the case . once past the power cord open/lift it as if there was a hinge on the right . do this so you don't pull the speaker wire that is routed in that direction .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the back of the monitor is loose you can start to lift it free.  First item to watch is the power cord.  It should slide  up and be free to help open the case.  Once past the power cord open/lift it as if there was a hinge on the right.  Do this so you don't pull the speaker wire that is routed in that direction.

Lines.Text: once the back is open you can reach this wire and unplug it from the controller board . this is a wire that is plugged in and can be removed . i have seen issues with this being very tight before and you also pull the plug and the connector off the solder leads , so be careful . once this speaker wire has been unplugged you can set this case piece out of the way . ( need better photo )

Steps.Text_raw: Once the back is open you can reach this wire and unplug it from the controller board.  This is a wire that is plugged in and can be removed.  I have seen issues with this being very tight before and you also pull the plug and the connector off the solder leads, so be careful.  Once this speaker wire has been unplugged you can set this case piece out of the way.  (need better photo)

Lines.Text: the area that we are needing to repair is under the chromed metal cover . that is the power supply and it is shielded to help protect from interfering with the display . remove the 2 screws that hold this on . careful as you removed it try not to damage the silver tape . fold this metal case to the left .

Steps.Text_raw: The area that we are needing to repair is under the chromed metal cover.  That is the power supply and it is shielded to help protect from interfering with the display.  Remove the 2 screws that hold this on.  Careful as you removed it  Try not to damage the silver tape.  Fold this metal case to the left.

Lines.Text: this metal cover can be folded to the left to protect the metal tape that is covering the power wires for the lcd display and still give you room to remove the power board .

Steps.Text_raw: This metal cover can be folded to the left to protect the metal tape that is covering the power wires for the LCD display and still give you room to remove the power board.

Lines.Text: at this point you should be able to do a visual inspection to confirm that you have a blown capacitor or not . this monitor had the most common problem . a blown 1000 uf 16 v cap . the second most common is that the large cap to its left is also blown .

Steps.Text_raw: At this point you should be able to do a visual inspection to confirm that you have a blown capacitor or not.  This monitor had the most common problem.  A blown 1000uf 16v cap.  The second most common is that the large cap to its left is also blown.

Lines.Text: now that you have confirmed a blown cap the power board needs to be removed so that the bad part can be replaced . there are 4 screws and 5 cables that need unplugged to get the board free . unplug the cables first then undo the screws , makes it easer to remove the cables , in case that is not obvious to you .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that you have confirmed a blown cap the power board needs to be removed so that the bad part can be replaced.  There are 4 screws and 5 cables that need unplugged to get the board free.  Unplug the cables first then undo the screws, makes it easer to remove the cables, in case that is not obvious to you.

Lines.Text: with the board now removed we can start to remove the blown capacitor . these larger capacitors are held in place with more than just the solder joints , there is also a small blob of some sort of glue or such that hold these in place . red square show this glob in place and blue square shows it removed . take a exacto knife and cut this away from the capacitor that is needing to be replaced . your doing this on the top of the board where there shouldn't be anything you can really damage , like electronic traces , but be careful anyway .

Steps.Text_raw: With the board now removed we can start to remove the blown capacitor.  These larger capacitors are held in place with more than just the solder joints, there is also a small blob of some sort of glue or such that hold these in place.  Red square show this glob in place and blue square shows it removed.  Take a Exacto knife and cut this away from the capacitor that is needing to be replaced.  Your doing this on the top of the board where there shouldn't be anything you can really damage, like electronic traces, but be careful anyway.

Lines.Text: now flip the circuit board over and de-solder the capacitor . as this cap is close to the edge of the board it shouldn't be to hard to figure out which two points need de-soldered to get the cap free . a hot iron and the solder wic should have the cap free in just a couple moments . i have de-soldered the wrong component before so double check yourself .

Steps.Text_raw: Now flip the circuit board over and de-solder the capacitor.  As this cap is close to the edge of the board it shouldn't be to hard to figure out which two points need de-soldered to get the cap free.  A hot iron and the solder wic should have the cap free in just a couple moments.  I have de-soldered the wrong component before so double check yourself.

Lines.Text: the new capacitor can be installed and soldered in now . as you do this you need to pay attention to polarity of the cap . the negative lead is marked on the new capacitor with a gray strip and the '-' symbol in that strip , as seen in the first photo . the negative spot on the circuit board is shown by the black half of the circle on the circuit board . there is also a '+' sign next to the other hole as well . be sure the negative lead of the capacitor goes into the negative hole of the board , and then solder down the new cap .

Steps.Text_raw: The new capacitor can be installed and soldered in now.  As you do this you need to pay attention to polarity of the cap.  The negative lead is marked on the new capacitor with a gray strip and the '-' symbol in that strip, as seen in the first photo.  The negative spot on the circuit board is shown by the black half of the circle on the circuit board.  There is also a '+' sign next to the other hole as well.  Be sure the negative lead of the capacitor goes into the negative hole of the board, and then solder down the new cap.

Lines.Text: be sure to clip the extra length of wire from the cap after it has been soldered in . don't leave it like the photo or you will have problems . use wire cutters and clip those leads as close as you can to the board , with out cutting the new solder joint you just did . i also don't replace that gray compound that we cut out . for better or worse i have done maybe 30 monitors and haven't had any problems so far . not sure what that stuff is to replace it either , so that is part of it .

Steps.Text_raw: Be sure to clip the extra length of wire from the cap after it has been soldered in.  Don't leave it like the photo or you will have problems.  Use wire cutters and clip those leads as close as you can to the board, with out cutting the new solder joint you just did.  I also don't replace that gray compound that we cut out.  For better or worse I have done maybe 30 monitors and haven't had any problems so far.  Not sure what that stuff is to replace it either, so that is part of it.

Lines.Text: at this point the hard work is done . the monitor now needs to be rebuilt . put the power supply board back in place and replace the 4 screws that were removed . once these are in then reattach the 5 cables there were unplugged . they should be resting right were they need plugged in , so it shouldn't be that hard to figure out where they go . here is the same picture you saw a few steps ago just as a reminder .

Steps.Text_raw: At this point the hard work is done.  The monitor now needs to  be rebuilt.  Put the power supply board back in place and replace the 4 screws that were removed.  Once these are in then reattach the 5 cables there were unplugged.  They should be resting right were they need plugged in, so it shouldn't be that hard to figure out where they go.  Here is the same picture you saw a few steps ago just as a reminder.

Lines.Text: one the power supply board is reattached the shield plate needs replaced . again be careful about that metal shielding tape , you don't want to tear or damage it . fold it back into place and replace the two screws to anchor it . careful as you put it back as there is a small tab at the top that needs to be correctly placed to get the shield in place or it will keep the screw holes from lining up correctly . blue circle in first photo shows where this tab is .

Steps.Text_raw: One the power supply board is reattached the shield plate needs replaced.  Again be careful about that metal shielding tape, you don't want to tear or damage it.  Fold it back into place and replace the two screws to anchor it.  Careful as you put it back as there is a small tab at the top that needs to be correctly placed to get the shield  in place or it will keep the screw holes from lining up correctly.  Blue circle in first photo shows where this tab is.

Lines.Text: last cable that needs plugged in is the audio cable for the speakers on this monitor . this cable is keyed with a set of 'rails' on one face of the plug so that it can't be plugged in backward . hold the back piece in place as if it were a hinged on the right side . also be sure to route the video cable out the correct hole in the back as well ( out the biggest hole ) . once the audio is plugged in you should be able to lower the back in place and align it .

Steps.Text_raw: Last cable that needs plugged in is the audio cable for the speakers on this monitor.  This cable is keyed with a set of 'rails' on one face of the plug so that it can't be plugged in backward.  Hold the back piece in place as if it were a hinged on the right side.  Also be sure to route the video cable out the correct hole in the back as well( out the biggest hole).  Once the audio is plugged in you should be able to lower the back in place and align it.

Lines.Text: once the back is in place and aligned , it just needs squeezed back together . you will hear snaps and pops as it goes back together . be sure to squeeze the edges and middle of all 4 sides . then do a visual inspected to make sure that it has correctly snapped back together . on rare occasions i have had to re-open the back and redo it as alignment is not what it should have been .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the back is in place and aligned, it just needs squeezed back together.  You will hear snaps and pops as it goes back together.  Be sure to squeeze the edges and middle of all 4 sides.  Then do a visual inspected to make sure that it has correctly snapped back together.  On rare occasions I have had to re-open the back and redo it as alignment is not what it should have been.

Lines.Text: last step is to reattach the monitor stand with the 8 screws that were removed and then to reattach the plastic bezel that covered them . here is a photo of the screws to show alignment . these are the screw locations for the left hand set of holes . flip it over for the right hand set of screws . then press the bezel into place and you should be done .

Steps.Text_raw: Last step is to reattach the monitor stand with the 8 screws that were removed and then to reattach the plastic bezel that covered them.  Here is a photo of the screws to show alignment.  These are the screw locations for the left hand set of holes.  Flip it over for the right hand set of screws.  Then press the bezel into place and you should be done.

Lines.Text: you should be done now , plug in the monitor and confirm that it works . hope this guide was useful to you .

Steps.Text_raw: You should be done now, plug in the monitor and confirm that it works.  Hope this guide was useful to you.

Title: Disassembling Western Digital 2104U External Drive Case

Lines.Text: locate 2 small phillips-head screws under the middle-top and bottom of the bar code sticker on bottom of drive . uncover screws and loosen .

feel around on the sticker for two depressions in which the screws are sunk . on the 2014 u model , the one depression is under the al of western digital at the top and the other is near the ul symbol at the bottom .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate 2 small phillips-head screws under the middle-top and bottom of the bar code sticker on bottom of drive.  Uncover screws and loosen. Feel around on the sticker for two depressions in which the screws are sunk.  On the 2014U model, the one depression is under the “al” of Western Digital” at the top and the other is near the UL symbol at the bottom.

Lines.Text: use a small flathead screwdriver to pry away the black stripe of trim .
(black tabs hold it in place and they come out fairly easily . it comes off in two pieces , wrapped around the whole drive .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a small flathead  screwdriver to pry away the black stripe of trim. (Black tabs hold it in place and they come out fairly easily.  It comes off in two pieces, wrapped around the whole drive.

Lines.Text: with all the black trim taken off , five tabs will be exposed . one on the front , one on the left and three on the right .

the tabs have three small marks/dots on them . the three dots are tabs that poke into three holes in the tabs behind them , so put the small flathead screwdriver in between the two tabs in a downward direction , prying the five tabs out of their holes and lift gently .

Steps.Text_raw: With all the black trim taken off, five tabs will be exposed.  one on the front, one on the left and three on the right. The tabs have three small marks/dots on them.  The three dots are tabs that poke into three holes in the tabs behind them, so put the small flathead screwdriver in between the two tabs in a downward direction, prying the five tabs out of their holes and lift gently.

Lines.Text: when all these tabs are loosened , the back of the case holds the two halves together .
pry the top of the back , above the vent holes , away from the top half / lid .
this should finish the separation of the two halves .

Steps.Text_raw: When all these tabs are loosened, the back of the case holds the two halves together. Pry the top of the back, above the vent holes, away from the top half / lid. This should finish the separation of the two halves.

Lines.Text: remove the three strips of metallic tape that hold the internal ide drive into the enclosure on the top and sides of the drive .
you may need the screwdriver to scrape the tape away from the sides .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three strips of metallic tape that hold the internal IDE drive into the enclosure on the top and sides of the drive. You may need the screwdriver to scrape the tape away from the sides.

Lines.Text: gently release the led cable from the clips that attach it to the lower carriage of the enclosure

Steps.Text_raw: Gently release the LED cable from the clips that attach it to the lower carriage of the enclosure

Lines.Text: at the back of the drive , pry away the four metal tabs on the left and right holding down the metal bracket at the back of the drive . a fourth strip of metallic tape may cover two of these tabs rearmost on the drive . look for the bumps under the tape .
score / cut / remove the metallic tape that holds the back of the metal bracket to the back of the carriage assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: At the back of the drive, pry away the four metal tabs on the left and right holding down the metal bracket at the back of the drive.  A fourth strip of metallic tape may cover two of these tabs rearmost on the drive.  Look for the bumps under the tape. Score / cut / remove the metallic tape that holds the back of the metal bracket to the back of the carriage assembly.

Lines.Text: remove the optional metal bracket .
this will reveal the ide cable and power connector where you can install another drive .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the optional metal bracket. This will reveal the IDE cable and power connector where you can install another drive.

Lines.Text: lift the drive and carriage assembly out of the enclosure .
remove the four screws on the underside of the carriage holding the ide drive in the assembly .
detach the ide data cable and power cable from the drive .
replace the ide drive

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the drive and carriage assembly out of the enclosure. Remove the four screws on the underside of the carriage holding the IDE drive in the assembly. Detach the IDE data cable and power cable from the drive. Replace the IDE drive

Subject: Case

Title: HP Photosmart D110a Printer Hood Assembly Replacement

Lines.Text: first , begin by removing the printer's hood .
open the printer's mouth by simply pulling down on it ; there are 2 mouth pieces that need to be pulled down .
adjust the flap covering the scanner upward , as shown .

Steps.Text_raw: First, begin by removing the printer's hood. Open the printer's mouth by simply pulling down on it; there are 2 mouth pieces that need to be pulled down. Adjust the flap covering the scanner upward, as shown.

Lines.Text: remove the flap for the scanner . the flap is attached with two clips that can be dislodged by pulling lightly away from the printer .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the flap for the scanner. The flap is attached with two  clips that can be dislodged by pulling lightly away from the printer.

Lines.Text: locate the three screws on top of the printer .
the orange circle shows a fourth screw located behind the power panel . directions to remove this screw are in a later step .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the three screws on top of the printer. The orange circle shows a fourth screw located behind the power panel.  Directions to remove this screw are in a later step.

Lines.Text: remove the three screws from the top of the printer with a t-9 screwdriver as shown .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three screws from the top of the printer with a T-9 screwdriver as shown.

Lines.Text: to access and remove the fourth and final screw attaching the hood , the panel for the power button must be removed as follows :
reach into the mouth of the printer and press on the small clip behind the power button . this allows the panel of the power button to be removed .
a picture of the power button panel removed is provided to show the location of the clip that needs to be pressed .
after pressing the clip , pull out the power button panel by pulling from right to left .

Steps.Text_raw: To access and remove the fourth and final screw attaching the hood, the panel for the power button must be removed as follows: Reach into the mouth of the printer and press on the small clip behind the power button. This  allows the panel of the power button to be removed. A picture of the power button panel removed is provided to show the location of the clip that needs to be pressed. After pressing the clip, pull out the power button panel by pulling from right  to left.

Lines.Text: remove the exposed screw that was covered by the power button panel .
'''do not try and torque the screw from an angle . ''' this will ruin the screw's head , and make it even more difficult to remove the screw . only remove it as already described .
this screw is placed awkwardly . we found holding a t9 bit in a pair of needle nose pliers gave us enough leverage to pull it up .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the exposed screw that was covered by the power button panel. '''Do not try and torque the screw from an angle.''' This will ruin the screw's head, and make it even more difficult to remove the screw. Only remove it as already described. This screw is placed awkwardly. We found holding a T9 bit in a pair of needle nose pliers gave us enough leverage to pull it up.

Lines.Text: this step is easier with two people . carefully have one person lift the hood of the printer 2-3 inches above where it was resting .
remove the ribbon cables and wires attaching the motherboard ( the only green pcb board ) to the hood by gently pulling upward on them .
when all three cables are removed , lift the hood away from the printer and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: This step is easier with two people. Carefully have one person lift the hood of the printer 2-3 inches above where it was resting. Remove the ribbon cables and wires attaching the motherboard (the only green PCB board) to the hood by gently pulling upward on them. When all three cables are removed, lift the hood away from the printer and set it aside.

Subject: Printer Hood Assembly

Lines.Text: remove the three screws with a t-9 screwdriver . ( one screw is behind a small black capacitor . its location is indicated by a yellow box as are the two uncovered screws . )
remove the cables and ribbon cables by pulling them free . they attach the motherboard to the printer and are indicated by red boxes .

when reattaching the cables and ribbon cable , make sure they go in their corresponding slots as previously pictured : they will not fit in other slots .

Title: HP Photosmart D110a Power Button Replacement

Lines.Text: open the printer's mouth by pulling the two mouth pieces down .
lift the flap covering the scanner . when you are finished , the printer should appear as shown .

Steps.Text_raw: Open the printer's mouth by pulling the two mouth pieces down. Lift the flap covering the scanner. When you are finished, the printer should appear as shown.

Lines.Text: remove the flap for the scanner by pulling lightly on the clip that attaches it to the printer .
the clip may be damaged by applying too much force .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the flap for the scanner by pulling lightly on the clip that attaches it to the printer. The clip may be damaged by applying too much force.

Lines.Text: remove the three screws from the top of the printer using a t9 screwdriver as shown .
the screws are located in the far-left , far-right , and near-right corners of the printer , with respect to the front view .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three screws from the top of the printer using a T9 screwdriver as shown. The screws are located in the far-left, far-right, and near-right corners of the printer, with respect to the front view.

Lines.Text: reach into the mouth of the printer and press the clip behind the power button to release the power button face .

Steps.Text_raw: Reach into the mouth of the printer and press the clip behind the power button to release the power button face.

Lines.Text: a picture of the removed power button is provided to show the location of the clip that needs to be pressed .
after pressing the clip , pull out the face of the power button by sliding it from the right to the left side .

Steps.Text_raw: A picture of the removed power button is provided to show the location of the clip that needs to be pressed. After pressing the clip, pull out the face of the power button by sliding it from the right to the left side.

Lines.Text: the power button face has a plastic holder that attaches the power button and the wireless button to the face plate using two slots .
loosen the plastic holder by pulling the slots on the face plate away from the plastic holder .
remove the plastic holder from the face plate after the slots are loosened .

Steps.Text_raw: The power button face has a plastic holder that attaches the power button  and the wireless button to the face plate using two slots. Loosen the plastic holder by pulling the slots on the face plate away from the plastic holder. Remove the plastic holder from the face plate after the slots are loosened.

Lines.Text: the plastic holder secures the power button by two slots .
using a spudger , push the holders inward to detach the button from the plastic holder .

Steps.Text_raw: The plastic holder secures the power button by two slots. Using a spudger, push the holders inward to detach the button from the plastic holder.

the lcd module should now be separated from the hood . the large ribbon wire from the lcd can be detached if needed .

Title: APS Tech 101629 External Casing Replacement

Lines.Text: pry 4 plastic feet off the bottom of the enclosure using the ipod opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry 4 plastic feet off the bottom of the enclosure using the iPod opening tool.

Lines.Text: unscrew the four screws previously covered by the feet .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the four screws previously covered by the feet.

Lines.Text: flip the device right side up , then gently slide the casing upwards and off the hard drive .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the device right side up, then gently slide the casing upwards and off the hard drive.

Lines.Text: flip device upside down again .
gently pry the bottom gray casing away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip device upside down again. Gently pry the bottom gray casing away from the device.

Lines.Text: rotate so back of device is facing you , then gently pry the back casing away .
when back casing is removed , the fan will become loose .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate so back of device is facing you, then gently pry the back casing away. When back casing is removed, the fan will become loose.

Subject: External Casing

Title: APS Tech 101629 Exhaust Fan Replacement

Lines.Text: pry 4 plastic feet off the bottom of the enclosure using the ipod opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry 4 plastic feet off the bottom of the enclosure using the iPod opening tool.

Lines.Text: unscrew the four screws previously covered by the feet .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the four screws previously covered by the feet.

Lines.Text: flip the device right side up , then gently slide the casing upwards and off the hard drive .

gently pry the bottom gray casing away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip device upside down again. Gently pry the bottom gray casing away from the device.

Lines.Text: rotate so back of device is facing you , then gently pry the back casing away .
when back casing is removed , the fan will become loose .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate so back of device is facing you, then gently pry the back casing away. When back casing is removed, the fan will become loose.

Lines.Text: disconnect id cable .
make sure to lift the white portion of the connection first , as this holds the two connectors together .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect ID cable. Make sure to lift the white portion of the connection first, as this holds the two connectors together.

Lines.Text: for easier access the fan is loose and can be easily moved but not disconnected .
using spudger , depress pressure holders at all 4 corners .
pull out , removing cord as well .

Steps.Text_raw: For easier access the fan is loose and can be easily moved but not disconnected. Using spudger, depress pressure holders at all 4 corners. Pull out, removing cord as well.

Lines.Text: depress 2 pressure holds on each side of the power switch .
press out the back of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Depress 2 pressure holds on each side of the power switch. Press out the back of the device.

Lines.Text: remove all four 4 connections from the power switch .
remember that the straight connections are on the far side , while the l-shaped connections are on the near side , and that both yellow connections are on top . this is helpful for reassembly .
these are very hard to get off , use patience and wiggling .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove all four 4 connections from the power switch. Remember that the straight connections are on the far side, while the L-shaped connections are on the near side, and that both yellow connections are on top. This is helpful for reassembly. These are very hard to get off, use patience and wiggling.

Lines.Text: remove temperature guage .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove temperature guage.

Lines.Text: move the exhaust fan out of the way so you can access its control cord .
use the spudger to depress the hold on the fan cord .
gently pull fan cord from connection and remove fan completely .

Steps.Text_raw: Move the exhaust fan out of the way so you can access its control cord. Use the spudger to depress the hold on the fan cord. Gently pull fan cord from connection and remove fan completely.

Subject: Exhaust Fan

remove 4 screws with phillips 1 screwdriver .

Lines.Text: slide the internal drive component away from the back of the device .
remove the connections from the back of the internal component in the order of your choosing , we suggest left to right . the connections are :

scsi id
terminate on
scsi connection
dc input ( power )

using spudger , depress pressure holders at all 4 corners .
pull out , removing cord as well .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the device right side up, then gently slide the casing upwards and off the hard drive.

gently pry the bottom gray casing away from the device .

when back casing is removed , the fan will become loose .

using spudger , depress pressure holders at all 4 corners .
pull out , removing cord as well .

press out the back of the device .

Lines.Text: remove all four 4 connections from the power switch .

remove 4 screws with phillips 1 screwdriver .

Title: Epson Stylus Photo 820 Driver Motor Replacement

Lines.Text: to remove the top cover of the printer you have to first release it from several tabs .
note : this may take more than one person to complete .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the top cover of the printer you have to first release it from several tabs. Note: This may take more than one person to complete.

Lines.Text: these three are the easiest tabs to remove . they are located on the back side of the printer .
push the tab in with one of the plastic opening tools .
keep the tab pushed in by leveraging the tool between the tab and the hole . pull up on the case so that the tab doesn't lock back into place .
repeat this process with the furthermost right tab , then proceed with the middle tab .

Steps.Text_raw: These three are the easiest tabs to remove. They are located on the back side of the printer. Push the tab in with one of the plastic opening tools. Keep the tab pushed in by leveraging the tool between the tab and the hole. Pull up on the case so that the tab doesn't lock back into place. Repeat this process with the furthermost right tab, then proceed with the middle tab.

Lines.Text: note : it is recommended that step 3 and step 4 be completed simultaneously . the tabs are identical just on opposite sides .
viewing from the front of the printer , there is a tab in the lower left corner .
viewing the tab hole from the bottom of the printer .
insert the mini screwdriver into the marked hole and pry out the tab .
push in towards the blue sticker of the printer while pulling up on the case at the same time . use one of the tools to keep the tab pried open .
this tab is the easiest to break so be very careful .

Steps.Text_raw: Note: It is recommended that step 3 and step 4 be completed simultaneously. The tabs are identical just on opposite sides. Viewing from the front of the printer, there is a tab in the lower left corner. Viewing the tab hole from the bottom of the printer. Insert the mini screwdriver into the marked hole and pry out the tab. Push in towards the blue sticker of the printer while pulling up on the case at the same time. Use one of the tools to keep the tab pried open. This tab is the easiest to break so be very careful.

Lines.Text: there is another tab in the right corner of the printer ( viewing from the front ) .
viewing the tab hole from under the printer .
zoomed in on the tab hole .
follow the same instructions in step 3 to remove this tab .

Steps.Text_raw: There is another tab in the right corner of the printer (viewing from the front). Viewing the tab hole from under the printer. Zoomed in on the tab hole. Follow the same instructions in step 3 to remove this tab.

Lines.Text: the final two tabs can be more difficult to release . viewing from the front , they are located in the back left and right corners of the printer .
the release points for the tabs are located in holes on the depressed area of the base ( darker piece ) .
use the mini screwdriver to pry out the tab .
use one of the plastic tools to keep the tab pried out . once it releases push in towards the printer ( viewing from the side ) and pull up on the case .

Steps.Text_raw: The final two tabs can be more difficult to release. Viewing from the front, they are located in the back left and right corners of the printer. The release points for the tabs are located in holes on the depressed area of the base (darker piece). Use the mini screwdriver to pry out the tab. Use one of the plastic tools to keep the tab pried out. Once it releases push in towards the printer (viewing from the side) and pull up on the case.

Lines.Text: all of the tabs have now been released .
when trying to completely remove the cover , it gets caught on these two back components . maneuvering around these can be tricky .
push the cover to the right slightly and then push it backwards ( out of the screen in this picture ) . this should give it some wiggle room . repeat this as necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: All of the tabs have now been released. When trying to completely remove the cover, it gets caught on these two back components. Maneuvering around these can be tricky. Push the cover to the right slightly and then push it backwards (out of the screen in this picture). This should give it some wiggle room. Repeat this as necessary.

Lines.Text: now , pull the cover up and off .

Steps.Text_raw: Now, pull the cover up and off.

Lines.Text: locate the drive motor . it is the square object located in the back right of the chassis .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the drive motor.  It is the square object located in the back right of the chassis.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws that hold the motor down .
use a small pair of needle-nose pliers to hold the back nut steady .
be careful not to lose the small washers and grommets under the nut when removing the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws that hold the motor down. Use a small pair of needle-nose pliers to hold the back nut steady. Be careful not to lose the small washers and grommets under the nut when removing the screws.

Lines.Text: push on the spring loaded tensioner on the left side of the belt to loosen the force on the drive motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Push on the spring loaded tensioner on the left side of the belt to loosen the force on the drive motor.

Lines.Text: remove the red cable connecting the motor to the logic board .
be careful , this is the most sensitive part of the printer .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the red cable connecting the motor to the logic board. Be careful, this is the most sensitive part of the printer.

Lines.Text: once your old motor is out , follow the previous steps in reverse to install the new one !

Steps.Text_raw: Once your old motor is out, follow the previous steps in reverse to install the new one!

Subject: Driver Motor
