the upper lid can now safely be removed from the bottom lid .

Steps.Text_raw: Do not fully remove the lid until you remove the ribbon cable attached to the front of the upper lid. Do this by grabbing the upper lid from the sides and rotating it ninety degrees so it is perpendicular to the bottom lid. Grab the ribbon cable and gently pull it out of its slot with your fingers. The upper lid can now safely be removed from the bottom lid.

Lines.Text: lift up the central plastic housing inside the scanner .
there are four plastic tabs located on the outer plastic housing . push on each of these and pull to remove it .
underneath you will see that the ribbon cable is attached to the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up the central plastic housing inside the scanner. There are four plastic tabs located on the outer plastic housing. Push on each of these and pull to remove it. Underneath you will see that the ribbon cable is attached to the circuit board.

Lines.Text: grab onto ribbon cable with tweezers and gently pull until it come outs .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab onto ribbon cable with tweezers and gently pull until it come outs.

Lines.Text: simply remove the ribbon cable from within the holes it is wrapped through .

Steps.Text_raw: Simply remove the ribbon cable from within the holes it is wrapped through.

Lines.Text: grab the ribbon cable , and gently pull it off of the bottom of the scanner .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab the ribbon cable, and gently pull it off of the bottom of the scanner.

Lines.Text: peel back the sticky metal from the other side of the ribbon cable .
use tweezers to gently remove the ribbon cable from the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel back the sticky metal from the other side of the ribbon cable. Use tweezers to gently remove the ribbon cable from the circuit board.

Lines.Text: remove the metal housing for the ribbon cable at the base of the scanner .
use the tweezers to slide off the metal housing .
the ribbon cable is now completely free to be replaced .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the metal housing for the ribbon cable at the base of the scanner. Use the tweezers to slide off the metal housing. The ribbon cable is now completely free to be replaced.

Subject: New Ribbon Cable

Title: Apple AirPort Express Base Station Power Supply Kit

Lines.Text: mark or note the edges that need to be cut to open the airport express case .

use a dremel tool with a thin cutting bit to slowly cut around the marked edges . cut evenly along the middle of the edges , and make several shallow passes to ensure that you don't accidentally cut into any of the components inside .
if you see sparks while cutting , it means you are cutting through the emi shields . reduce your cutting depth immediately to prevent further damage .

be especially cautious when cutting next to the led light , as the power wires are right next to the case wall . the wires are highlighted in orange in the third picture . severing these wires may make the repair extremely difficult .

Steps.Text_raw: Mark or note the edges that need to be cut to open the AirPort Express case. Use a dremel tool with a thin cutting bit to slowly cut around the marked edges. Cut evenly along the middle of the edges, and make several shallow passes to ensure that you don't accidentally cut into any of the components inside. If you see sparks while cutting, it means you are cutting through the EMI shields. Reduce your cutting depth immediately to prevent further damage. Be especially cautious when cutting next to the LED light, as the power wires are right next to the case wall. The wires are highlighted in orange in the third picture. Severing these wires may make  the repair extremely difficult.

Lines.Text: use a metal spudger or prying device to begin levering the case halves apart .
do not push the prying device too far into the case , as this could damage the emi shields or other components .
the case will be most stubborn near the grey power inlet , as this piece is glued to the case halves . focus on separating the other parts of the case first .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a metal spudger or prying device to begin levering the case halves apart. Do not push the prying device too far into the case, as this could damage the EMI shields or other components. The case will be most stubborn near the grey power inlet, as this piece is glued to the case halves. Focus on separating the other parts of the case first.

Lines.Text: once the case halves are loose , use your hands to pry open the case .
do not attempt to separate the case halves as there are wires still joining them .
trace the red , orange and black power wires to their connector on the power supply .
disconnect the power cables from the power supply .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the case halves are loose, use your hands to pry open the case. Do not attempt to separate the case halves as there are wires still joining them. Trace the red, orange and black power wires to their connector on the power supply. Disconnect the power cables from the power supply.

Lines.Text: remove the grey power inlet from the case half it is still attached to . use a pair of pliers to rock the power inlet back and forth until it breaks free from the glue .
finish separating the case halves .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the grey power inlet from the case half it is still attached to. Use a pair of pliers to rock the power inlet back and forth until it breaks free from the glue. Finish separating the case halves.

Lines.Text: the power supply is attached to the upper case half with one 5.38 mm phillips screw .
use a 1 phillips screwdriver to remove the screw and then remove the power supply .
do not lose this screw . you will be using it to secure the new power supply to the upper case half .

Steps.Text_raw: The power supply is attached to the upper case half with one 5.38 mm Phillips screw. Use a #1 Phillips screwdriver to remove the screw and then remove the power supply. Do not lose this screw. You will be using it to secure the new power supply to the upper case half.

Lines.Text: the printed circuit board ( pcb ) supplied in your kit can be soldered using any rails that you desire . however , we have determined that using the following rails provides a nice , low-profile , fit .
ground
5 v
adjust

Steps.Text_raw: The printed circuit board (PCB) supplied in your kit can be soldered using any rails that you desire. However, we have determined that using the following rails provides a nice, low-profile, fit. Ground 5V 3.3V "Adjust"

Lines.Text: the following are the suggested hole locations for components , though they can be placed in any hole along the proper traces .
.1 µf capacitor
1 µf capacitor
240 ω resistor
390 ω resistor
voltage regulator pin 1
voltage regulator pin 2
voltage regulator pin 3

Steps.Text_raw: The following are the suggested hole locations for components, though they can be placed in any hole along the proper traces. .1 µF Capacitor 1 µF Capacitor 240 Ω Resistor 390 Ω Resistor Voltage Regulator Pin 1 Voltage Regulator Pin 2 Voltage Regulator Pin 3

Lines.Text: the power inlet and outlet wires are recommended to be soldered in the following locations , though again they can be soldered to any through-hole you desire along the proper trace .
power supply +
power supply -
5 v out
3.3 v out
ground out

Steps.Text_raw: The power inlet and outlet wires are recommended to be soldered in the following locations, though again they can be soldered to any through-hole you desire along the proper trace. Power Supply + Power Supply - 5 V Out 3.3 V Out Ground Out

Lines.Text: the voltage regulator has 3 pins :
pin 1 : v in ( 5 v )
pin 2 : v out ( 3.3 v )
pin 3 : adjust
use a pair of pliers to carefully bend pin 1 down 90 , pin 3 up 90 and pin 2 up as far as possible without touching pin 3.
do not worry about getting exact angles , as you will likely need to adjust the pins when you go to fit the ic to the pcb .
do not repeatedly bend and unbend the pins , as repeated bending will weaken the metal and eventually cause it to break .

Steps.Text_raw: The voltage regulator has 3 pins: Pin 1: V in (5 V) Pin 2: V out (3.3 V) Pin 3: "Adjust" Use a pair of pliers to carefully bend pin 1 down 90°, pin 3 up 90° and pin 2 up as far as possible without touching pin 3. Do not worry about getting exact angles, as you will likely need to adjust the pins when you go to fit the IC to the PCB. Do not repeatedly bend and unbend the pins, as repeated bending will weaken the metal and eventually cause it to break.

Lines.Text: use needle nose pliers to bend just the tips ( approximately 2 mm ) of the pins 90 up so that they are pointing the same direction as the ic face .
if you bend too much of the pins , they will not be able to reach their assigned holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Use needle nose pliers to bend just the tips (approximately 2 mm) of the pins 90° up so that they are pointing the same direction as the IC face. If you bend too much of the pins, they will not be able to reach their assigned holes.

Lines.Text: place the pins of the voltage regulator through the holes indicated in step 7. adjust the pins if necessary .
there should be just a small portion of the pin sticking up through the top side of the pcb . if the pins do not stick through the board , adjust the pin bends so that they do .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the pins of the voltage regulator through the holes indicated in step 7. Adjust the pins if necessary. There should be just a small portion of the pin sticking up through the top side of the PCB. If the pins do not stick through the board, adjust the pin bends so that they do.

Lines.Text: solder the pins to the board on the printed side of the pcb .
unsure of how to properly through-hole solder ? check out our guide . you can even use a thin piece of wire and practice with a hole on an unused trace .
try to solder quickly and efficiently . prolonged application of heat to any of the component pins can transfer enough heat to damage it .

Steps.Text_raw: Solder the pins to the board on the printed side of the PCB. Unsure of how to properly through-hole solder? Check out our [guide|6190|technique guide|stepid=26971]. You can even use a thin piece of wire and practice with a hole on an unused trace. Try to solder quickly and efficiently. Prolonged application of heat to any of the component pins can transfer enough heat to damage it.

Lines.Text: insert the leads of the 390 ω resistor through the holes indicated in step 7. this resistor will have an orange , grey , brown and gold band on it . the direction of the resistor does not matter .
be sure to route the leads so that they do not cover any of the indicated holes in steps 7 and 8.
solder the resistor to the pcb and clip off the excess leads .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the leads of the 390 Ω resistor through the holes indicated in step 7. This resistor will have an orange, grey, brown and gold band on it. The direction of the resistor does not matter. Be sure to route the leads so that they do not cover any of the indicated holes in steps 7 and 8. Solder the resistor to the PCB and clip off the excess leads.

Lines.Text: insert the leads of the 240 ω resistor through the holes indicated in step 7. this resistor will have a red , yellow , brown , and gold band on it . the direction of the resistor does not matter .
be sure to route the leads so that they do not cover any needed holes from steps 7 and 8. also , do not allow the leads to contact the leads of other components .
solder the resistor to the pcb and clip the excess leads off .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the leads of the 240 Ω resistor through the holes indicated in step 7. This resistor will have a red, yellow, brown, and gold band on it. The direction of the resistor does not matter. Be sure to route the leads so that they do not cover any needed holes from steps 7 and 8. Also, do not allow the leads to contact the leads of other components. Solder the resistor to the PCB and clip the excess leads off.

Lines.Text: insert the leads of the 1 µf capacitor through the holes indicated in step 7. the capacitor will have markings on it indicating its capacitance . the direction of the capacitor does not matter .
be sure to route the leads so that they do not cover any needed holes from step 7 or 8. also , do not allow the leads to contact the leads of other components .
solder the capacitor to the pcb and clip off the excess leads .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the leads of the 1 µF capacitor through the holes indicated in step 7. The capacitor will have markings on it indicating its capacitance. The direction of the capacitor does not matter. Be sure to route the leads so that they do not cover any needed holes from step 7 or 8. Also, do not allow the leads to contact the leads of other components. Solder the capacitor to the PCB and clip off the excess leads.

Lines.Text: insert the leads of the . 1 µf capacitor through the holes indicated in step 7. the capacitor will have markings on it indicating its capacitance . the direction of the capacitor does not matter .
be sure to route the leads so that they do not cover any needed holes from steps 7 and 8. also , do not allow the leads to contact the leads of other components .
solder the capacitor to the pcb and clip the excess leads off .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the leads of the .1 µF capacitor through the holes indicated in step 7. The capacitor will have markings on it indicating its capacitance. The direction of the capacitor does not matter. Be sure to route the leads so that they do not cover any needed holes from steps 7 and 8. Also, do not allow the leads to contact the leads of other components. Solder the capacitor to the PCB and clip the excess leads off.

Lines.Text: cut the lead off of the power supply included in the kit .
you can cut the power supply leads as short as you desire to reduce clutter .
strip the outer sheath off the wires . you can use either wire strippers with the correct size hole , or you can use a pair of wire cutters to carefully cut just the outer sheath .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the lead off of the power supply included in the kit. You can cut the power supply leads as short as you desire to reduce clutter. Strip the outer sheath off the wires. You can use either wire strippers with the correct size hole, or you can use a pair of wire cutters to carefully cut just the outer sheath.

Lines.Text: strip approximately 7 mm of wire , being careful not to accidentally cut the wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Strip approximately 7 mm of wire, being careful not to accidentally cut the wire.

Lines.Text: pre-tin the exposed wires to add rigidity to them and keep them from fraying when pushing through the pcb through-holes .

pre-tinning is when you cover or fill wires with solder to improve a solder connection . be sure that your pre-tin does not have any globs on it , or it will not fit through the pcb through-holes . if necessary , trim the wire so that it will fit through the holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Pre-tin the exposed wires to add rigidity to them and keep them from fraying when pushing through the PCB through-holes. Pre-tinning is when you cover or fill wires with solder to improve a solder connection. Be sure that your pre-tin does not have any globs on it, or it will not fit through the PCB through-holes. If necessary, trim the wire so that it will fit through the holes.

Lines.Text: insert the leads of the power supply through the holes indicated in step 8. insert the wires until the wire sheath is against the pcb .
solder the wires to the pcb and clip off the excess wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the leads of the power supply through the holes indicated in step 8. Insert the wires until the wire sheath is against the PCB. Solder the wires to the PCB and clip off the excess wire.

Lines.Text: cut the connector off the power wires in the lower airport express case half .
strip approximately 5 mm off each of the wires , being careful not to accidentally sever the wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the connector off the power wires in the lower AirPort Express case half. Strip approximately 5 mm off each of the wires, being careful not to accidentally sever the wires.

Lines.Text: twist the exposed ends of the same-colored wires together .

Steps.Text_raw: Twist the exposed ends of the same-colored wires together.

Lines.Text: pre-tin the exposed wire ends to join them .

Steps.Text_raw: Pre-tin the exposed wire ends to join them.

Lines.Text: cut the included 150 mm wire into 3 equal 50 mm lengths .
strip approximately 5 mm of sheath off both ends of the 3 wire pieces .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the included 150 mm wire into 3 equal 50 mm lengths. Strip approximately 5 mm of sheath off both ends of the 3 wire pieces.

Lines.Text: secure a wire and pre-tin both of its ends . repeat for the remaining two wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Secure a wire and pre-tin both of its ends. Repeat for the remaining two wires.

Lines.Text: align the pre-tinned section of the cut wire with one of the lower case power wires . melt the two pre-tinned sections together length-wise . repeat for the remaining two wire sets .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the pre-tinned section of the cut wire with one of the lower case power wires. Melt the two pre-tinned sections together length-wise. Repeat for the remaining two wire sets.

Lines.Text: cut the included heat shrink tubing into 3 equal length pieces .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the included heat shrink tubing into 3 equal length pieces.

Lines.Text: slip a piece of shrink tubing over each of the exposed solder joints .
use the soldering iron to apply a little heat evenly around each of the shrink tubing pieces until they are secured to the wire .
do not hold the soldering iron to the shrink tubing pieces for more than a few seconds at a time . you may accidentally de-solder the wires or even break the shrink tubing .

we recommend using the side of the soldering iron when applying heat to the shrink tubing . the sides are cooler than the tips , and using the sides will also prevent solder from getting on the shrink tubing or vice-versa .

Steps.Text_raw: Slip a piece of shrink tubing over each of the exposed solder joints. Use the soldering iron to apply a little heat evenly around each of the shrink tubing pieces until they are secured to the wire. Do not hold the soldering iron to the shrink tubing pieces for more than a few seconds at a time. You may accidentally de-solder the wires or even break the shrink tubing. We recommend using the side of the soldering iron when applying heat to the shrink tubing. The sides are cooler than the tips, and using the sides will also prevent solder from getting on the shrink tubing or vice-versa.

Lines.Text: insert and solder the wires from the airport board into the appropriate holes of the pcb .
the red-wired lead goes to the 5 v out hole from step 8.
the orange-wired lead goes to the 3.3 v out hole from step 8.
the black-wired lead goes to the ground out hole from step 8.

after soldering these wires is the perfect time to give your new power supply a quick test . plug in the power supply and see if the led on the lower case half turns on . if it does , your power supply is working . if it doesn't , quickly unplug the power supply and recheck all your connections .

you can test output using a multimeter and checking the voltage at the red ( 5 v ) and orange ( 3.3 v ) wire solder joints and using the black wire solder joint as ground . variations of no more than . 3 v is acceptable .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert and solder the wires from the  AirPort board into the appropriate holes of the PCB. The red-wired lead goes to the 5 V out hole from step 8. The orange-wired lead goes to the 3.3 V out hole from step 8. The black-wired lead goes to the ground out hole from step 8. After soldering these wires is the perfect time to give your new power supply a quick test. Plug in the power supply and see if the LED on the lower case half turns on. If it does, your power supply is working. If it doesn't, quickly unplug the power supply and recheck all your connections. You can test output using a multimeter and checking the voltage at the red (5 V) and orange (3.3 V) wire solder joints and using the black wire solder joint as ground. Variations of no more than .3 V is acceptable.

Lines.Text: secure the pcb to the upper case half using the original 5.38 mm 1 phillips screw and the included washer .
do not over-tighten the screw or you will break the screw hole .
be sure to orient the pcb so that the voltage regulator points towards where the grey power inlet used to be .
peel the white back off the thermal pad , being careful not to accidentally peel the thermal pad off of the heat sink .

set the heat sink onto the voltage regulator so that their lower left corners , as oriented in the third picture , are aligned . press the heat sink firmly onto the voltage regulator to ensure that it will stick .

Steps.Text_raw: Secure the PCB to the upper case half  using the original 5.38 mm #1 Phillips screw and the included washer. Do not over-tighten the screw or you will break the screw hole. Be sure to orient the PCB so that the voltage regulator points towards where the grey power inlet used to be. Peel the white back off the thermal pad, being careful not to accidentally peel the thermal pad off of the heat sink. Set the heat sink onto the voltage regulator so that their lower left corners, as oriented in the third picture, are aligned. Press the heat sink firmly onto the voltage regulator to ensure that it will stick.

Lines.Text: put the case halves together . be careful not to pinch the 3 power leads , and be sure to route the power supply cable out of the opening in such a way that it won't put tension on any of the pcb components .

Steps.Text_raw: Put the case halves together. Be careful not to pinch the 3 power leads, and be sure to route the power supply cable out of the opening in such a way that it won't put tension on any of the PCB components.

Lines.Text: there are likely large burrs ( shredded plastic bits ) on the edges of your case from cutting it open . for ease of joining the case halves , it is recommended that you smooth the edges by de-burring them . a dremel tool with a sanding bit , a sanding block , or a knife will work for this process .

Steps.Text_raw: There are likely large burrs (shredded plastic bits) on the edges of your case from cutting it open. For ease of joining the case halves, it is recommended that you smooth the edges by de-burring them. A dremel tool with a sanding bit, a sanding block, or a knife will work for this process.

Lines.Text: pour a small amount of the plastic beads that were included with the kit into a heat- and stick-resistant container .
use a heat gun to heat the plastic beads until they turn transparent .

most hair driers are also capable of melting the beads . if neither a hair drier of sufficient power nor a heat gun are available to you , you can also try boiling them and straining them out of the boiling water .
when using a heat gun or hair dryer , be sure to turn the heat to high but leave the fan on low , or you will blow the beads out of the container !

Steps.Text_raw: Pour a small amount of the plastic beads that were included with the kit into a heat- and stick-resistant container. Use a heat gun to heat the plastic beads until they turn transparent. Most hair driers are also capable of melting the beads. If neither a hair drier of sufficient power nor a heat gun are available to you, you can also try boiling them and straining them out of the boiling water. When using a heat gun or hair dryer, be sure to turn the heat to high but leave the fan on low, or you will blow the beads out of the container!

Lines.Text: give the plastic beads a few seconds to cool , then remove them and mash them together until they form one piece .
the plastic beads should be fairly warm still , but their container will likely be extremely hot . use care when removing and handling the beads .
stretch the glob of plastic into a thin strip that will fill one of the gaps between the case halves .
press the plastic into the crevices and smooth it out with your finger .
if the plastic becomes too hard to work with , you can re-apply heat to loosen the plastic .
be cautious if you reheat the plastic while it's in the case . allow cooling periods between reheating so you don't accidentally de-solder any components .

Steps.Text_raw: Give the plastic beads a few seconds to cool, then remove them and mash them together until they form one piece. The plastic beads should be fairly warm still, but their container will likely be extremely hot. Use care when removing and handling the beads. Stretch the glob of plastic into a thin strip that will fill one of the gaps between the case halves. Press the plastic into the crevices and smooth it out with your finger. If the plastic becomes too hard to work with, you can re-apply heat to loosen the plastic. Be cautious if you reheat the plastic while it's in the case. Allow cooling periods between reheating so you don't accidentally de-solder any components.

Lines.Text: when you are satisfied with the smoothness and fill of the crevice , allow the case and plastic to cool for approx 10-15 minutes . the plastic filler will become a milky white color when it is fully solidified .
repeat steps 29 through 35 for all of the crevices created from cutting the case .
it is highly recommended that you leave the old power inlet hole unsealed to allow some cooling for your new power supply .

Steps.Text_raw: When you are satisfied with the smoothness and fill of the crevice, allow the case and plastic to cool for approx 10-15 minutes. The plastic filler will become a milky white color when it is fully solidified. Repeat steps 29 through 35 for all of the crevices created from cutting the case. It is highly recommended that you leave the old power inlet hole unsealed to allow some cooling for your new power supply.

Lines.Text: allow the case to cool for at least an hour when you have finished sealing it . this will prevent you from starting the airport express while components are too hot .

try to operate your airport express in an open and/or well ventilated location . initial failure can result from over-heating , and over-heating can still cause your new power supply , or any of the other components , to fail .

Steps.Text_raw: Allow the case to cool for at least an hour when you have finished sealing it. This will prevent you from starting the AirPort Express while components are too hot. Try to operate your AirPort Express in an open and/or well ventilated location. Initial failure can result from over-heating, and over-heating can still cause your new power supply, or any of the other components, to fail.

Subject: Power Supply Kit

Title: Disassembling Microtek ScanMaker 5900 Motor Tread

Lines.Text: loosen the screws on the serial port by turning them counter clockwise by hand .
after loosening the screws , pull the serial port out .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the screws on the serial port by turning them counter clockwise by hand. After loosening the screws, pull the serial port out.

Lines.Text: lift lid to its vertical position .
pull lid straight up to remove it from the scanner .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift lid to its vertical position. Pull lid straight up to remove it from the scanner.

Lines.Text: push the plastic opening tools into the crack between the top and the bottom of the chassis .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the plastic opening tools into the crack between the top and the bottom of the chassis.

Lines.Text: after placing one plastic opening tool into the slit , slide other plastic opening tools along the slit to detach the top from the bottom of the chassis .
go all the way along the chassis until you can lift the upper lid .

Steps.Text_raw: After placing one plastic opening tool into the slit, slide other plastic opening tools along the slit to detach the top from the bottom of the chassis. Go all the way along the chassis until you can lift the upper lid.

Lines.Text: do not fully remove the lid until you remove the ribbon cable attached to the front of the upper lid .
do this by grabbing the upper lid from the sides and rotating it ninety degrees so it is perpendicular to the bottom lid .
grab the ribbon cable and gently pull it out of its slot with your fingers .
the upper lid can now safely be removed from the bottom lid .

Steps.Text_raw: Do not fully remove the lid until you remove the ribbon cable attached to the front of the upper lid. Do this by grabbing the upper lid from the sides and rotating it ninety degrees so it is perpendicular to the bottom lid. Grab the ribbon cable and gently pull it out of its slot with your fingers. The upper lid can now safely be removed from the bottom lid.

Lines.Text: locate the stepper motor . with the front of the scanner facing you , the motor is located at the top left .
disconnect the white connector from the vertical standing circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the stepper motor. With the front of the scanner facing you, the motor is located at the top left. Disconnect the white connector from the vertical standing circuit board.

Lines.Text: using a 2 phillips screwdriver , unscrew the two 7.7 mm screws holding the stepper motor in place .
the stepper motor will become loose , but not completely free .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a #2 Philips Screwdriver, unscrew the two 7.7mm screws holding the stepper motor in place. The stepper motor will become loose, but not completely free.

Lines.Text: using tweezers gently remove the tread from the black gear on the stepper motor .
the stepper motor will become completely free .

Steps.Text_raw: Using tweezers gently remove the tread from the black gear on the stepper motor. The stepper motor will become completely free.

Lines.Text: facing the front of the scanner you will see a white plastic wheel holding the other end of the tread .
pull the spring towards you until it snaps off the side wall releasing the tension in the spring .
using a 2 phillips screwdriver , unscrew the single 5.88 mm screw holding the mount of the plastic wheel in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Facing the front of the scanner you will see a white plastic wheel holding the other end of the tread. Pull the spring towards you until it snaps off the side wall releasing the tension in the spring. Using a #2 Philips Screwdriver, unscrew the single 5.88mm screw holding the mount of the plastic wheel in place.

Lines.Text: the plastic wheel and it's mount will be loose .
remove the shaft holding the plastic wheel and the mount together
the tread will be completely loose .

Steps.Text_raw: The plastic wheel and it's mount will be loose. Remove the shaft holding the plastic wheel and the mount together The tread will be completely loose.

after loosening the screws , pull the serial port out .

pull lid straight up to remove it from the scanner .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift lid to its vertical position. Pull lid straight up to remove it from the scanner.

Lines.Text: push the plastic opening tools into the crack between the top and the bottom of the chassis .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the plastic opening tools into the crack between the top and the bottom of the chassis.

Lines.Text: after placing one plastic opening tool into the slit , slide other plastic opening tools along the slit to detach the top from the bottom of the chassis .
go all the way along the chassis until you can lift the upper lid .

Steps.Text_raw: After placing one plastic opening tool into the slit, slide other plastic opening tools along the slit to detach the top from the bottom of the chassis. Go all the way along the chassis until you can lift the upper lid.

Lines.Text: do not fully remove the lid until you remove the ribbon cable attached to the front of the upper lid .
do this by grabbing the upper lid from the sides and rotating it ninety degrees so it is perpendicular to the bottom lid .
grab the ribbon cable and gently pull it out of its slot with your fingers .
the upper lid can now safely be removed from the bottom lid .

Steps.Text_raw: Do not fully remove the lid until you remove the ribbon cable attached to the front of the upper lid. Title: Linksys WRT54GS v2 Front Case Replacement

Lines.Text: turn the router over so that all four of its feet are facing upwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the router over so that all four of its feet are facing upwards.

Lines.Text: remove the rubber inserts inside the the two purple feet located on the router's front case .
this may be a challenge , so try the following two methods :
use a plastic opening tool . insert the flat end of the tool into the seam and slowly pry the rubber feet out .
use a metal spudger . insert the point of the metal spudger directly into the hole of the rubber feet and pry the insert out .

Title: Polaroid LCD-0700P LCD Power Board Replacement

Lines.Text: turn the entire device over , so that the underside of the device is facing upward .

with the underside of the device facing up , locate the 11 mm screw found in each far corner of the device . remove the single 11 mm screw from each of the four corners , using the phillips 0 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the entire device over, so that the underside of the device is facing upward. With the underside of the device facing up, locate the 11mm screw found in each far corner of the device. Remove the single 11mm screw from each of the four corners, using the Phillips #0 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: turn the device so that the underside faces you , and the edge where the case and device bind , faces upward . the opening of the device should be face down .

in this position you will see a crease line between the device and the top cover . gently insert your blue plastic opening tool into the crack of the crease line , between the front and back cover to separate them .
be careful when separating the front and back covers , as the two are held together by a thin wire .
separate the halves of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the device so that the underside faces you, and the edge where the case and device bind, faces upward. The opening of the device should be face down. In this position you will see a crease line between the device and the top cover. Gently Insert your blue plastic opening tool into the crack of the crease line, between the front and back cover to separate them. Be careful when separating the front and back covers, as the two are held together by a thin wire. Separate the halves of the case.

Lines.Text: locate the input/output board on the top left hand corner of the device . it will look like a green circuit board with wires protruding and connecting to the case cover .

using your blue plastic opening tool , disconnect the multicolored wires located on the input/output board . these will be the same multicolored wires that connect the back cover to the input/output board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the input/output board on the top left hand corner of the device. It will look like a green circuit board with wires protruding and connecting to the case cover. Using your blue plastic opening tool, disconnect the multicolored wires located on the input/output board. These will be the same multicolored wires that connect the back cover to the input/output board.

Lines.Text: find the lcd power board located on the top right hand corner of the device ( the lcd power board will be the long green circuit board with a pink and white wire emerging from the top ) .
using your blue plastic opening tool , remove the wire connections from the lcd power board located on the top of the board ( these will be the pink and white wires ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Find the LCD power board located on the top right hand corner of the device (The LCD power board will be the long green circuit board with a pink and white wire emerging from the top). Using your blue plastic opening tool, remove the wire connections from the LCD power board located on the top of the board (These will be the pink and white wires).

Lines.Text: locate the two 5 mm screws on the lcd power board . one screw will be in the top left corner , the second will be in the bottom right corner .
remove the two 5 mm screws with your phillips 0 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the two 5mm screws on the LCD power board. One screw will be in the top left corner, the second will be in the bottom right corner. Remove the two 5mm screws with your Phillips #0 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift the lcd power board out of the device ( there will still be wires connecting the board to the device ) .

vertically flip the lcd power board so that the side that was originally facing the device is now facing up . using your blue opening tool , remove the connection ( multi-colored and twisted wire ) from the input/output board .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the LCD power board out of the device (There will still be wires connecting the board to the device). Vertically flip the LCD power board so that the side that was originally facing the device is now facing up. Using your blue opening tool, remove the connection (multi-colored and twisted wire) from the Input/Output board.

Subject: LCD Power Board

Lines.Text: use two blue plastic opening tools to remove the three wire connectors on the side of the input/output board .
use a phillips 0 screwdriver to remove the five screws on the board .
one of the screws is hidden below the black tape , so gently pull the tape to the side to gain access to it . be sure to replace the tape when reinstalling the board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use two blue plastic opening tools to remove the three wire connectors on the side of the input/output board. Use a Philips #0 screwdriver to remove the five screws on the board. Lines.Text: remove the five different connections to this board . two from the speakers , two from input/output board and the orange ribbon cable .
remove connections from input/output board and speaker with the plastic opening tool .
remove the orange ribbon cable using the plastic opening tool to release the two brown retention tabs .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the five different connections to this board.  Two from the speakers, two from input/output board and the orange ribbon cable. Lines.Text: remove the seven 5 mm screws using the phillips 0 screwdriver .
detach the wire mesh tape connection the logic board to the lcd screen with the sharp end of the spudger .
remove the logic board with your hands .

Lines.Text: use the small flat-head screwdriver to scrape the glue spots off the retaining posts on all four corners of the speaker to be removed . ( right speaker shown )
be careful when scraping the glue spots off to avoid damaging the logic board .
when reassembling , mix a small amount of 5 minute epoxy and apply it to the four retaining posts . wait the full 5 minutes for the epoxy to harden before continuing with your reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the small flat-head screwdriver to scrape the glue spots off the retaining posts on all four corners of the speaker to be removed. (Right speaker shown) Be careful when scraping the glue spots off to avoid damaging the logic board. When reassembling, mix a small amount of 5 minute epoxy and apply it to the four retaining posts. Wait the full 5 minutes for the epoxy to harden before continuing with your reassembly.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to lift the speaker ( s ) free of the retaining posts .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to lift the speaker(s) free of the retaining posts.

Subject: Speakers

Title: Polaroid LCD-0700P Screen Replacement

Lines.Text: turn the entire device over , so that the underside of the device is facing upward .

with the underside of the device facing up , locate the 11 mm screw found in each far corner of the device . remove the single 11 mm screw from each of the four corners , using the phillips 0 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the entire device over, so that the underside of the device is facing upward. With the underside of the device facing up, locate the 11mm screw found in each far corner of the device. Remove the single 11mm screw from each of the four corners, using the Phillips #0 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: turn the device so that the underside faces you , and the edge where the case and device bind , faces upward . the opening of the device should be face down .

in this position you will see a crease line between the device and the top cover . gently insert your blue plastic opening tool into the crack of the crease line , between the front and back cover to separate them .
be careful when separating the front and back covers , as the two are held together by a thin wire .
separate the halves of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the device so that the underside faces you, and the edge where the case and device bind, faces upward. The opening of the device should be face down. In this position you will see a crease line between the device and the top cover. Gently Insert your blue plastic opening tool into the crack of the crease line, between the front and back cover to separate them. Be careful when separating the front and back covers, as the two are held together by a thin wire. Separate the halves of the case.

Lines.Text: locate the input/output board on the top left hand corner of the device . it will look like a green circuit board with wires protruding and connecting to the case cover .

using your blue plastic opening tool , disconnect the multicolored wires located on the input/output board . these will be the same multicolored wires that connect the back cover to the input/output board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the input/output board on the top left hand corner of the device. It will look like a green circuit board with wires protruding and connecting to the case cover. Using your blue plastic opening tool, disconnect the multicolored wires located on the input/output board. These will be the same multicolored wires that connect the back cover to the input/output board.

Lines.Text: use two blue plastic opening tools to remove the three wire connectors on the side of the input/output board .
use a phillips 0 screwdriver to remove the five screws on the board .
one of the screws is hidden below the black tape , so gently pull the tape to the side to gain access to it . be sure to replace the tape when reinstalling the board .
lift board from case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use two blue plastic opening tools to remove the three wire connectors on the side of the input/output board. Use a Philips #0 screwdriver to remove the five screws on the board. One of the screws is hidden below the black tape, so gently pull the tape to the side to gain access to it. Be sure to replace the tape when reinstalling the board. Lift board from case.

Lines.Text: remove the five different connections to this board . two from the speakers , two from input/output board and the orange ribbon cable .
remove connections from input/output board and speaker with the plastic opening tool .
remove the orange ribbon cable using the plastic opening tool to release the two brown retention tabs .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the five different connections to this board.  Two from the speakers, two from input/output board and the orange ribbon cable. Remove connections from input/output board and speaker with the plastic opening tool. Remove the orange ribbon cable using the plastic opening tool to release the two brown retention tabs.

Lines.Text: remove the seven 5 mm screws using the phillips 0 screwdriver .
detach the wire mesh tape connection the logic board to the lcd screen with the sharp end of the spudger .
remove the logic board with your hands .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the seven 5mm screws using the Phillips #0 screwdriver. Detach the wire mesh tape connection the logic board to the LCD screen with the sharp end of the spudger. Remove the logic board with your hands.

Lines.Text: find the lcd power board located on the top right hand corner of the device ( the lcd power board will be the long green circuit board with a pink and white wire emerging from the top ) .
using your blue plastic opening tool , remove the wire connections from the lcd power board located on the top of the board ( these will be the pink and white wires ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Find the LCD power board located on the top right hand corner of the device (The LCD power board will be the long green circuit board with a pink and white wire emerging from the top). Using your blue plastic opening tool, remove the wire connections from the LCD power board located on the top of the board (These will be the pink and white wires).

Lines.Text: locate the two 5 mm screws on the lcd power board . one screw will be in the top left corner , the second will be in the bottom right corner .
remove the two 5 mm screws with your phillips 0 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the two 5mm screws on the LCD power board. One screw will be in the top left corner, the second will be in the bottom right corner. Remove the two 5mm screws with your Phillips #0 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift the lcd power board out of the device ( there will still be wires connecting the board to the device ) .

vertically flip the lcd power board so that the side that was originally facing the device is now facing up . using your blue opening tool , remove the connection ( multi-colored and twisted wire ) from the input/output board .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the LCD power board out of the device (There will still be wires connecting the board to the device). Vertically flip the LCD power board so that the side that was originally facing the device is now facing up. Using your blue opening tool, remove the connection (multi-colored and twisted wire) from the Input/Output board.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to release the top and side retention clips .
it may be easier to release all of the necessary clips by pushing gently on the front of the screen to keep the disengaged clips from re-engaging .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to release the top and side retention clips. It may be easier to release all of the necessary clips by pushing gently on the front of the screen to keep the disengaged clips from re-engaging.

Lines.Text: pivot the screen downward to disengage the remaining clips and lift the screen from the front bezel .

Steps.Text_raw: Pivot the screen downward to disengage the remaining clips and lift the screen from the front bezel.

Subject: Screen

with the underside of the device facing up , locate the 11 mm screw found in each far corner of the device . remove the single 11 mm screw from each of the four corners , using the phillips 0 screwdriver .

in this position you will see a crease line between the device and the top cover . gently insert your blue plastic opening tool into the crack of the crease line , between the front and back cover to separate them .
be careful when separating the front and back covers , as the two are held together by a thin wire .
separate the halves of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the device so that the underside faces you, and the edge where the case and device bind, faces upward. The opening of the device should be face down. In this position you will see a crease line between the device and the top cover. Gently Insert your blue plastic opening tool into the crack of the crease line, between the front and back cover to separate them. Be careful when separating the front and back covers, as the two are held together by a thin wire. Separate the halves of the case.

Lines.Text: locate the input/output board on the top left hand corner of the device . it will look like a green circuit board with wires protruding and connecting to the case cover .

using your blue plastic opening tool , disconnect the multicolored wires located on the input/output board . these will be the same multicolored wires that connect the back cover to the input/output board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the input/output board on the top left hand corner of the device. It will look like a green circuit board with wires protruding and connecting to the case cover. Using your blue plastic opening tool, disconnect the multicolored wires located on the input/output board. These will be the same multicolored wires that connect the back cover to the input/output board.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 0 screwdriver to remove the screws for the bar you are replacing .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Philips #0 screwdriver to remove the screws for the bar you are replacing.

Lines.Text: slide out the bar .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide out the bar.

Subject: Metal Holding Bars

Title: Dell Photo Printer 540 Mother Board Replacement

Lines.Text: rotate the photo printer so that the bottom of the case faces upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the photo printer so that the bottom of the case faces upward.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 2 screwdriver to remove the three 5.65 mm screws on the bottom panel of the case in a counter-clockwise fashion .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #2 screwdriver to remove the three 5.65 mm screws on the bottom panel of the case in a counter-clockwise fashion.

Lines.Text: rotate the device so that it is upright again . under the lcd panel there is a 9.62 mm screw , unscrew using a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the device so that it is upright again. Under the LCD Panel there is a 9.62 mm screw, unscrew using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the back panel of the case by pulling directly back .
some carefully applied force may be required to remove this part .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the back panel of the case by pulling directly back. Some carefully applied force may be required to remove this part.

Lines.Text: rotate the photo printer so that the bottom panel faces up once again . now lift off the bottom panel of the case to access all internal components .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the photo printer so that the bottom panel faces up once again. Now lift off the bottom panel of the case to access all internal components.

Lines.Text: finally remove the side panel with the ink-cartridge door by holding the right side and pulling backwards with the left side .
caution ! the side panel is held in by tabs ; don't break these .

Steps.Text_raw: Finally remove the side panel with the ink-cartridge door by holding the right side  and pulling backwards with the left side. Caution! The side panel is held in by tabs; don't break these.

Lines.Text: carefully remove the inner components of the device by lifting the inner components up and out of the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove the inner components of the device by lifting the inner components up and out of the casing.

Lines.Text: locate the red and black cable that is connecting the fan to the top of the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the red and black cable that is connecting the fan to the top of the logic board.

Lines.Text: carefully , remove the red and black cable from the logic board by pulling gently in order to isolate the cooling fan from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully, remove the red and black cable from the logic board by pulling gently in order to isolate the cooling fan from the device.

Lines.Text: locate the data ribbon that connects the lcd panel to the mother board .
loosen the fasteners next to the ribbon by carefully pushing them away from the white ribbon holder .
once the fasteners are loosened the ribbon should easily slide away from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the data ribbon that connects the LCD panel to the mother board. Loosen the fasteners next to the ribbon by carefully pushing them away from the white ribbon holder. Once the fasteners are loosened the ribbon should easily slide away from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: locate the clips with multi-colored wires that connect the motherboard to the printing unit .
disconnect both of them by gently pulling them away from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the clips with multi-colored wires that connect the motherboard to the printing unit. Disconnect both of them by gently pulling them away from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: locate the white ribbon that connects the motherboard to the printing feed .
disconnect the ribbon by gently pulling the ribbon away from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the white ribbon that connects the motherboard to the printing feed. Disconnect the ribbon by gently pulling the ribbon away from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: the mother board has changed orientation . notice the new orientation based on the white data ribbon we removed in the previous step .
locate the black data ribbon that connects the mother board to the printing motors .
disconnect it from the logic board , by gently pulling the wire away from the mother board .

Steps.Text_raw: The mother board has changed orientation. Notice the new orientation based on the white data ribbon we removed in the previous step. Locate the black data ribbon that connects the mother board to the printing motors. Disconnect it from the logic board, by gently pulling the wire away from the mother board.

Lines.Text: now unscrew the three screws 7.89 mm ( counter-clockwise ) using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Now unscrew the three screws 7.89mm (counter-clockwise) using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: once screws and ribbons are disconnected , you can pull mother board away from the printing unit .

Steps.Text_raw: Once screws and ribbons are disconnected, you can pull mother board away from the printing unit.

Subject: Mother Board

Lines.Text: locate the red and black cable that is connecting the fan to the top of the logic board .

Lines.Text: locate the data ribbon that connects the lcd panel to the mother board .
carefully unclip the ribbon from the mother board .
separate top cover from bottom base and flip upright so that the lcd panel is facing up for the next step

hold bottom of lcd panel and lift the screen 70 degrees . set the screen face down for the next step

note : make sure removal of front face plate is completed .

completely detach the motherboard from the face casing .
note : leave the power switch control attached to the main control panel motherboard .

detach the cable , power switch is now accessible .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the back panel of the case by pulling directly back. Some carefully applied force may be required to remove this part.

Lines.Text: rotate the photo printer so that the bottom panel faces up once again . now lift off the bottom panel of the case to access all internal components .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the photo printer so that the bottom panel faces up once again. Now lift off the bottom panel of the case to access all internal components.

Lines.Text: finally remove the side panel with the ink-cartridge door by holding the right side and pulling backwards with the left side .
caution ! the side panel is held in by tabs ; don't break these .

Steps.Text_raw: Finally remove the side panel with the ink-cartridge door by holding the right side  and pulling backwards with the left side. Caution! The side panel is held in by tabs; don't break these.

Lines.Text: carefully remove the inner components of the device by lifting the inner components up and out of the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove the inner components of the device by lifting the inner components up and out of the casing.

Lines.Text: locate the red and black cable that is connecting the fan to the top of the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the red and black cable that is connecting the fan to the top of the logic board.

Lines.Text: carefully , remove the red and black cable from the logic board by pulling gently in order to isolate the cooling fan from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully, remove the red and black cable from the logic board by pulling gently in order to isolate the cooling fan from the device.

Lines.Text: locate the data ribbon that connects the lcd panel to the mother board .
loosen the fasteners next to the ribbon by carefully pushing them away from the white ribbon holder .
once the fasteners are loosened the ribbon should easily slide away from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the data ribbon that connects the LCD panel to the mother board. Loosen the fasteners next to the ribbon by carefully pushing them away from the white ribbon holder. Once the fasteners are loosened the ribbon should easily slide away from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: locate the clips with multi-colored wires that connect the motherboard to the printing unit .
disconnect both of them by gently pulling them away from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the clips with multi-colored wires that connect the motherboard to the printing unit. Disconnect both of them by gently pulling them away from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: locate the white ribbon that connects the motherboard to the printing feed .
disconnect the ribbon by gently pulling the ribbon away from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the white ribbon that connects the motherboard to the printing feed. Disconnect the ribbon by gently pulling the ribbon away from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: the mother board has changed orientation . notice the new orientation based on the white data ribbon we removed in the previous step .
locate the black data ribbon that connects the mother board to the printing motors .
disconnect it from the logic board , by gently pulling the wire away from the mother board .

Steps.Text_raw: The mother board has changed orientation. Notice the new orientation based on the white data ribbon we removed in the previous step. Locate the black data ribbon that connects the mother board to the printing motors. Disconnect it from the logic board, by gently pulling the wire away from the mother board.

Lines.Text: now unscrew the three screws 7.89 mm ( counter-clockwise ) using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Now unscrew the three screws 7.89mm (counter-clockwise) using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: once screws and ribbons are disconnected , you can pull mother board away from the printing unit .

Steps.Text_raw: Once screws and ribbons are disconnected, you can pull mother board away from the printing unit.

Lines.Text: gain access to the bottom of the top case with a thin horizontal control panel motherboard attached to the bottom .
remove the front panel .
the dell top casing should now only have two sides .

Steps.Text_raw: Gain access to the bottom of the top case with a thin horizontal control panel motherboard attached to the bottom. Remove the front panel. The dell top casing should now only have two sides.

Lines.Text: locate the four 7.85 mm screws attaching the control panel motherboard to the top face casing .
use a phillips head 1 screwdriver to remove the four highlighted screws .
note : make sure removal of front face plate is completed .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the four 7.85 mm screws attaching the control panel motherboard to the top face casing. Use a Phillips Head #1 screw driver to remove the four highlighted screws. NOTE: Make sure removal of front face plate is completed.

Lines.Text: gently lift the horizontal control panel motherboard and square power switch board .
completely detach the motherboard from the face casing .
note : leave the power switch control attached to the main control panel motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift the horizontal control panel motherboard and square power switch board. Completely detach the motherboard from the face casing. NOTE: Leave the power switch control attached to the main control panel motherboard.

Subject: Removal of the Control Panel Motherboard

caution : this part is very fragile , so it is recommended that a blow dryer is used on the covering to heat it up . simply blow dry the covering while slowly peeling it away , and the covering will not tear .

Lines.Text: turn the device so that the antenna to be replaced is facing you .

using the screwdriver , unscrew the 2.5 mm phillips screw on the antenna .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the device over so that the antenna with the screw removed is still facing you.

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully peel back the metallic silver tape covering the cable of the antenna to be removed.

Lines.Text: carefully peel back the clear yellow tape covering the cable of the antenna to be removed .

completely remove the wifi card .

it may be difficult to split apart , so use force with caution .

Title: HP FHA-3510 Wireless Mouse Button Replacement

Lines.Text: turn off the mouse and remove the silver ( or other colored ) top cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn off the mouse and remove the silver (or other colored) top cover.

Lines.Text: remove the screws and keep them safe . one screw is under where the battery was located .
gently lift the cover from the mouse to reveal the printed circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the screws and keep them safe. One screw is under where the battery was located. Gently lift the cover from the mouse to reveal the Printed Circuit Board.

Lines.Text: study how the antenna wire in front of the mouse wheel and the mouse wheel assembly are located into the pcb . you'll need to know this when you perform the re-assembly . also note which side the power switch is set to .
remove the mouse wheel from the assembly , then remove the pcb .
the tactile switches for the left , right or page down buttons are tall black and square devices . one can be seen next to the wire in the picture .

Steps.Text_raw: Study how the antenna wire in front of the mouse wheel and the mouse wheel assembly are located into the PCB. You'll need to know this when you perform the re-assembly. Also note which side the power switch is set to. Remove the mouse wheel from the assembly, then remove the PCB. The tactile switches for the left, right or page down buttons are tall black and square devices. One can be seen next to the wire in the picture.

Lines.Text: the new evq p0 e07 k can be seen in the image .
using your soldering iron , de-solder the old switch by placing tweezers under the switch for leverage whilst heating the pins .
you may find it easier to wriggle the switch out one pin at a time , rather than heating both pins at once .
de-solder the holes with the solder pump or wick .
insert the new buttons and solder , ensuring they are flush with the pcb .
re-assemble the mouse carefully ensuring the power switch , lens , antenna and mouse wheel are in the correct locations .
test the switch works acceptably before screwing the unit back together .

Steps.Text_raw: The new EVQ P0E07K can be seen in the image. Using your soldering Iron, de-solder the old switch by placing tweezers under the switch for leverage whilst heating the pins. You may find it easier to wriggle the switch out one pin at a time, rather than heating both pins at once. De-solder the holes with the solder pump or wick. Insert the new buttons and solder, ensuring they are flush with the PCB. Re-assemble the mouse carefully ensuring the power switch, lens, antenna and mouse wheel are in the correct locations. Test the switch works acceptably before screwing the unit back together.

Subject: Button

Title: How to create and install a Cisco EX90 console cable

Lines.Text: '''gather the necessary tools'''
'''1 '''--soldering iron
'''2 '''--solder
'''3 '''--db9 enclosure . this is being used here .
'''4 '''--rs232 to ttl/cmos converter . sells the one used here . cisco does not recommend or endorse alldav specifically .
'''5 '''--cable w/rj45 connector on one end any type of cable with an 8 p8 c ( rj45 ) connector could used as long as pins 1 , 2 , 7 8 are connected . a standard rj45 cable is being used here .
you will also need wire strippers and possibly a screwdriver ( depending on which db9 enclosure you are using ) .

Steps.Text_raw: '''Gather the necessary tools''' '''1'''--Soldering Iron '''2'''--Solder '''3'''--DB9 Enclosure. This [http://www.frys.com/product/1910474;jsessionid=6N+v7z1c0R55b1KT6Stfjg__.node3?site=sr:SEARCH:MAIN_RSLT_PG|one] is being used here. '''4'''--RS232 to TTL/CMOS converter. [http://alldav.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=11|alldav.com] sells the one used here. Cisco does not recommend or endorse Alldav specifically. '''5'''--Cable w/RJ45 connector on one end Any type of cable with an 8P8C (RJ45) connector could used as long as pins 1,2,7 & 8 are connected. A standard RJ45 cable is being used here. You will also need wire strippers and possibly a screwdriver (depending on which DB9 enclosure you are using).

Lines.Text: '''prep the cable . ''' strip the sheathing from the wires that correspond to pins 1 , 2 , 7 8.

Steps.Text_raw: '''Prep the cable.''' Strip the sheathing from the wires that correspond to pins 1,2,7 & 8.

Lines.Text: '''connect the rs232 to ttl/cmos converter . ''' connect the rs232 to ttl/cmos converter to the cable and solder the connections . '''note : ''' the colors used in the wiring diagram don't correspond to the color of the actual wires .

Steps.Text_raw: '''Connect the RS232 to TTL/CMOS converter.''' Connect the RS232 to TTL/CMOS converter to the cable and solder the connections. '''Note:''' The colors used in the wiring diagram don't correspond to the color of the actual wires.

Lines.Text: '''install the enclosure''' the ex90 console is now complete . the subsequent steps will cover making a console connection .

Steps.Text_raw: '''Install the Enclosure''' The EX90 console is now complete.  The subsequent steps will cover making a console connection.

Lines.Text: '''make a console connection . ''' locate the console port . the ex90 console port is an 8 p8 c ( rj45 ) connection and is located on the bottom left corner of the unit .

Steps.Text_raw: '''Make a Console Connection.''' Locate the Console Port. The EX90 console port is an 8P8C (RJ45) connection and is located on the bottom left corner of the unit.

Lines.Text: '''connect to the console port . ''' plug the 8 p8 c ( rj45 ) end into the console port . you'll have to lean the unit forward to plug the cable in . it might be a little awkward to do alone . if someone else is available , ask for their assistance . as a last resort , lay the unit down . ensure you have something soft ( like a towel ) to lay the unit on .

Steps.Text_raw: '''Connect to the Console Port.''' Plug the 8P8C (RJ45) end into the console port.  You'll have to lean the unit forward to plug the cable in. It might be a little awkward to do alone. If someone else is available, ask for their assistance. As a last resort, lay the unit down. Ensure you have something soft (like a towel) to lay the unit on.

Lines.Text: connect the db9 to a usb serial adapter and connect to a laptop/pc .

Steps.Text_raw: Connect the DB9 to a USB serial adapter and connect to a laptop/PC.

Lines.Text: '''configure a terminal emulator session''' configure your terminal emulator with the following parameters :
baud38400
data bits8
paritynone
stop bits1
flow controlnone
the example uses hyperterminal for windows ; configuring your terminal emulator may vary slightly .
you should now be at a login prompt when you connect with the terminal emulator .

Steps.Text_raw: '''Configure a Terminal Emulator Session''' Configure your terminal emulator with the following parameters: Baud=38400 Data bits=8 Parity=none Stop bits=1 Flow Control=none The example uses HyperTerminal for Windows; configuring your terminal emulator may vary slightly. You should now be at a login prompt when you connect with the terminal emulator.

Title: Fixing Wheel Glitch on Mouse Roccat Kone[+] Plus

Lines.Text: unplug mouse .
cover the optical sensor with tape

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug mouse. Cover the optical sensor with tape

Lines.Text: with a heat gun/hair dryer start warming up the covers . this serves to loosen up the glue that keeps the glides attached to the mouse .

once hot , try to gently lift the glide and work the edges . ( to reapply it back on heat the gliders but not to hot to burn but to make the the glue soft , then firmly hold it in place till it cools and holds it grip . )
once glidez are removed , screws are in plain sight
do not touch or stain the sticky part of the glidez , otherwise they will not stick back .

Steps.Text_raw: With a heat gun/hair dryer start warming up the covers. This serves to loosen up the glue that keeps the glides attached to the mouse. Once hot, try to gently lift the glide and work the edges. (to reapply it back on heat the gliders but not to hot to burn but to make the the glue soft, then firmly hold it in place till it cools and holds it grip.) Once glidez are removed, screws are in plain sight DO NOT TOUCH OR STAIN THE STICKY PART OF THE GLIDEZ, otherwise they will not stick back.

Lines.Text: unscrew all 4 screws .
gently pull the lower and upper part in opposite directions . do not use force .
lower and upper part are attached by 5 wires
you can either leave them attached or unplug the wires using the tweezers
i prefered to separate the two parts for better handling of the lower part , where optical sensor and scroll sensor are located .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew all 4 screws. Gently pull the lower and upper part in opposite directions. DO NOT USE FORCE. Lower and upper part are attached by 5 wires You can either leave them attached or unplug the wires using the tweezers I prefered to separate the two parts for better handling of the lower part, where optical sensor and scroll sensor are located.

Lines.Text: replug the mouse in its initial usb port .
insert small piece cloth or tissue paper under the mouse wheel to prevent uncontrolled wd-40 leakeges

Steps.Text_raw: Replug the mouse in its initial USB port. Insert small piece cloth or tissue paper under the mouse wheel to prevent uncontrolled WD-40 leakeges

Lines.Text: now spray contact cleaner ( ignore wd-40 ) directly in the space indicated in the picture . scroll up a couple of times and scroll down a few times while spraying .
plug mouse in to pc , you can easily check in real time if it clears up persistent , or vanishes .
if this won't fix it , this probably means the scroll sensor is permanently damaged/defective . ( rma ? )

Steps.Text_raw: Now spray contact cleaner (ignore WD-40) directly in the space indicated in the picture. Scroll up a couple of times and scroll down a few times while spraying. plug mouse in to PC, you can easily check in real time if it clears up persistent, or vanishes. If this won't fix it, this probably means the scroll sensor is permanently damaged/defective. (RMA?)

Lines.Text: if the mouse wheel is not sturdy enough for your taste you can easily insert small pices of cropped paper between spaces around the mouse wheel
i used small piece of folded sticky note i always keep on my desk . : ) no more wiggling mouse wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: If the mouse wheel is not sturdy enough for your taste you can easily insert small pices of cropped paper between spaces around the mouse wheel I used small piece of folded sticky note I always keep on my desk. :) No more wiggling mouse wheel.

Lines.Text: once the glicth is fixed re-attach the wires and reassemble the lower and upper part together .
when reattaching the glidez use same method backwards . basically apply pressure on the the heated glidez and they should stick back to their place .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the glicth is fixed re-attach the wires and reassemble the lower and upper part together. When reattaching the glidez use same method backwards. Basically apply pressure on the the heated glidez and they should stick back to their place.

Title: Logitech MX Revolution battery Replacement

Toolbox.Name: li-ion battery l-ly11 old mouse or l-ll11 new mouse

Lines.Text: remove the mouse feet carefully with a flathead screwdriver .
also you can buy new mouse feet on ebay if you break them .
unscrew each screw a little at a time alternating between all 4 so that the base comes off all at once .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the mouse feet carefully with a flathead screw driver. Also you can buy new mouse feet on ebay if you break them. Unscrew each screw a little at a time alternating between all 4 so that the base comes off all at once.
Tools_extracted: li-ion battery l-ly11 old mouse or l-ll11 new mouse

Lines.Text: gently lift off the top of the mouse as the bottom and top are connected with a ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift off the top of the mouse as the bottom and top are connected with a ribbon cable.
Tools_extracted: li-ion battery l-ly11 old mouse or l-ll11 new mouse

Lines.Text: remove the ribbon cable gently use your flat head screwdriver to pry up each side of the black clip evenly until the ribbon releases .
at this point , the mouse shield should be free from the mouse board .
if you have an older model mouse , follow steps 4 to 7.
if you have a newer model mouse , jump to steps 8.

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the ribbon cable GENTLY use your flat head screwdriver to pry up each side of the black clip evenly until the ribbon releases. At this point, the mouse shield should be free from the mouse board. If you have an older model mouse, follow steps 4 to 7. If you have a newer model mouse, jump to steps 8.
Tools_extracted: li-ion battery l-ly11 old mouse or l-ll11 new mouse

Lines.Text: remove the battery retainer . use your flat head screwdriver to pry up the metal tab as it is quite flexable .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery retainer.  Use your flat head screw driver to pry up the metal tab as it is quite flexable.

Lines.Text: remove the battery by pushing the tab forward and lifting the battery at the same time .
you can see the part number for the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery by pushing the tab forward and lifting the battery at the same time. You can see the part number for the battery.

Lines.Text: remove the battery cage with your phillip's screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery cage with your Philip's screw driver.

Lines.Text: using your flat head screwdriver , wiggle the connector until it comes off .
insert the new li-ion battery l-ly11 and you are done .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your flat head screwdriver, wiggle the connector until it comes off. Insert the new Li-ion battery L-LY11 and you are done.
Tools_extracted: li-ion battery l-ly11 old mouse or l-ll11 new mouse

Lines.Text: this step is for the newer model mouse .
remove the battery by pushing the tab forward and lifting the battery at the same time .
insert the new li-ion battery l-ll11 and you are done .

Steps.Text_raw: This step is for the newer model mouse. Remove the battery by pushing the tab forward and lifting the battery at the same time. Insert the new Li-ion battery L-LL11 and you are done.
Tools_extracted: li-ion battery l-ly11 old mouse or l-ll11 new mouse

the mouse use omron d2 fc-f-7 n micro switch .

Title: Logitech Anywhere Mouse MX Micro Switch Replacement

Lines.Text: 2 screws are located under the battery stickers .
2 screws , one under each of the sliding pads under the mouse's nose .

Steps.Text_raw: 2 screws are located under the battery stickers. 2 screws, one under each of the sliding pads under the mouse's nose.

Lines.Text: peel off the battery sticker to reveal 2 screws .
remove those screws with a phillips screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel off the battery sticker to reveal 2 screws. Remove those screws with a phillips screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift the edge of the foot gliders with a screwdriver .
remove those screws with a phillips screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the edge of the foot gliders with a screwdriver. Remove those screws with a phillips screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift the upper shell away from the base . no cable connects the two parts .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the upper shell away from the base. No cable connects the two parts.

Lines.Text: desolder the micro switch and replace it with a new one , e-switch ts20100 f070 s . some have trouble to desolder the switch . you can eventually clip the tab to remove the switch . once the switch is remove you can easily remove the solder tab .
i use a weller st7 0.03 x0.79 mm st series conical tip to remove and solder the micro switch
just remember , the micro switch doesn't have a polarity . but the connectors will guide you which side the micro switch needs to face .
e-switch ts20100 f070 s

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the micro switch and replace it with a new one, E-Switch TS20100F070S. Some have trouble to desolder the switch. You can eventually clip the tab to remove the switch. Once the switch is remove you can easily remove the solder tab. I use a Weller ST7 0.03" X0.79 mm ST Series Conical Tip to remove and solder the micro switch Just remember, the micro switch doesn't have a polarity. But the connectors will guide you which side the micro switch needs to face. E-Switch TS20100F070S
