Title: How to fix HP Color LaserJet 2600n Fading Color

Lines.Text: before we begin , make sure to unplug the printer and any connected wires . to be extra safe , turn the power switch to 'off . '

first , let's establish what part of the printer is what so that we can communicate clearly throughout the guide . the red square is the front and the orange square is the top . after those , we have left ( yellow ) , and right ( green ) . the back is opposite the front and the bottom is opposite the top .

Steps.Text_raw: Before we begin, make sure to unplug the printer and any connected wires. To be extra safe, turn the power switch to 'off.' First, let's establish what part of the printer is what so that we can communicate clearly throughout the guide. The red square is the front and the orange square is the top. After those, we have left (yellow), and right (green). The back is opposite the front and the bottom is opposite the top.

Lines.Text: laser printers often have loose toner , a very fine and vibrant powder that will invade everything you don't want it to . i did my disassembly outside
open the front door and remove the toner cartridges .
set the cartridges aside for later . to keep them clean , place them in a bag or closed box .

Steps.Text_raw: Laser printers often have loose toner, a very fine and vibrant powder that will invade everything you don't want it to. I did my disassembly outside Open the front door and remove the toner cartridges. Set the cartridges aside for later. To keep them clean, place them in a bag or closed box.

Lines.Text: place the printer so that the right side is on the ground .
remove the paper tray from the bottom of the printer .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the printer so that the right side is on the ground. Remove the paper tray from the bottom of the printer.

Lines.Text: remove the indicated phillips m3 screw from the left side of the printer
in this photo , the paper tray is still in the printer . on your device , the tray should already be set aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the indicated Phillips M3 screw from the left side of the printer In this photo, the paper tray is still in the printer. On your device, the tray should already be set aside.

Lines.Text: release the tabs as indicated in the example by lifting or pressing them as needed .
some of the press tabs are hard to reach with a finger . if needed , gently press in the tab with a screwdriver until it releases .

Steps.Text_raw: Release the tabs as indicated in the example by lifting or pressing them as needed. Some of the press tabs are hard to reach with a finger. If needed, gently press in the tab with a screwdriver until it releases.

Lines.Text: lift and remove the left base cover

if it feels like something is holding the cover in place , there probably is . go back and look for additional tabs , as i may have missed listing some of them . this applies to any item removal in this guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift and remove the left base cover If it feels like something is holding the cover in place, there probably is. Go back and look for additional tabs, as I may have missed listing some of them. This applies to any item removal in this guide.

Lines.Text: release the tab fasteners on the left side cover

Steps.Text_raw: Release the tab fasteners on the left side cover

Lines.Text: lift and remove the left cover
if it feels like something is holding the cover in place , there probably is .
when reassembling , you have to mate the three noted tabs/slots , even though they do not snap in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift and remove the left cover If it feels like something is holding the cover in place, there probably is. When reassembling, you have to mate the three noted tabs/slots, even though they do not snap in place.

Lines.Text: rotate the device so it rests on its back .
unscrew and remove the two phillips m3 screws as indicated from the right side covers .
most of the screws in this printer are identical - the ones that are different will be noted as such .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the device so it rests on its back. Unscrew and remove the two Phillips M3 screws as indicated from the right side covers. Most of the screws in this printer are identical - the ones that are different will be noted as such.

Lines.Text: release tabs on the right base cover and right cover .
some of these tabs are inside the printer , so you will need to open the door and look along the right side .

Steps.Text_raw: Release tabs on the right base cover and right cover. Some of these tabs are inside the printer, so you will need to open the door and look along the right side.

Lines.Text: remove the right base cover and right cover from the printer .
if it feels like something is holding the cover in place , there probably is .
when reassembling , you have to mate the three noted tabs/slots , even though they do not snap in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the right base cover and right cover from the printer. If it feels like something is holding the cover in place, there probably is. When reassembling, you have to mate the three noted tabs/slots, even though they do not snap in place.

Lines.Text: place the device right side up once again .
remove the nine indicated phillips m3 screws from the back plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the device right side up once again. Remove the nine indicated Phillips M3 screws from the back plate.

Lines.Text: with the screws removed , lift the back cover from the bottom and remove from the printer .

Steps.Text_raw: With the screws removed, lift the back cover from the bottom and remove from the printer.

Lines.Text: during the next two steps , do not unplug any of the connections in the example boxed in orange .

Steps.Text_raw: During the next two steps, do not unplug any of the connections in the example boxed in orange.

Lines.Text: carefully and gently handle the wires and cables in the printer . they may break or bend , rendering your printer inoperable .
remove the ribbon cable by pulling directly along the cable .
remove the white connector by pressing down on the tab and pulling out .
pull the purple wire connectors directly out . you do not need to mark which cable goes where , as they are all unique sizes .
remove the white connector by pressing down on the tab and pulling out .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully and gently handle the wires and cables in the printer.  They may break or bend, rendering your printer inoperable. Remove the ribbon cable by pulling directly along the cable. Remove the white connector by pressing down on the tab and pulling out. Pull the purple wire connectors directly out. You do not need to mark which cable goes where, as they are all unique sizes. Remove the white connector by pressing down on the tab and pulling out.

Lines.Text: remove the four ribbon cables gently from the right edge of the circuit board assembly .
remove the final two wires by pulling them straight out .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four ribbon cables gently from the right edge of the circuit board assembly. Remove the final two wires by pulling them straight out.

Lines.Text: unwind the cables from the black harness on the top and right edges of the circuit board assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Unwind the cables from the black harness on the top and right edges of the circuit board assembly.

Lines.Text: depress the indicated tabs and remove the corner wiring harness from the circuit board assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Depress the indicated tabs and remove the corner wiring harness from the circuit board assembly.

Lines.Text: slide the top wiring harness to the left and remove it from the circuit board assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the top wiring harness to the left and remove it from the circuit board assembly.

Lines.Text: remove the eleven indicated phillips m3 screws from the circuit board assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the eleven indicated Phillips M3 screws from the circuit board assembly.

Lines.Text: remove the circuit board assembly from the printer , being cautious of the wires and cables ,

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the circuit board assembly from the printer, being cautious of the wires and cables,

Lines.Text: remove the two ribbon cables gently from the optical sub-assembly .
these ribbon cables are hard to replace . if you are having trouble , try asking someone with smaller hands ! be gentle , ribbon cables are not the most robust connectors .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two ribbon cables gently from the optical sub-assembly. These ribbon cables are hard to replace.  If you are having trouble, try asking someone with smaller hands!  Be gentle, ribbon cables are not the most robust connectors.

Lines.Text: tilt the printer forward and remove the phillips screw with a lock-washer from the bottom area of the printer .
the lock-washer is attached to the screw , so you do not need to worry about losing it .

Steps.Text_raw: Tilt the printer forward and remove the Phillips screw with a lock-washer from the bottom area of the printer. The lock-washer is attached to the screw, so you do not need to worry about losing it.

Lines.Text: set the printer back down and remove two more phillips screws with integrated lock-washers , which releases the optical sub-assembly .
remove the optical sub-assembly , this is what you need to repair .

Steps.Text_raw: Set the printer back down and remove two more Phillips screws with integrated lock-washers, which releases the optical sub-assembly. Remove the optical sub-assembly, this is what you need to repair.

Lines.Text: place the optical sub-assembly with the side that was facing you down .
remove the indicated black screw .
unhook and save the indicated spring .
remove the top plate from the optical sub-assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the optical sub-assembly with the side that was facing you down. Remove the indicated black screw. Unhook and save the indicated spring. Remove the top plate from the optical sub-assembly.

Lines.Text: these are lenses , mirrors , and sensors used by the printer to determine how it is printing . any damage will affect the quality of printing .
using a clean cotton swab or lens brush , gently clean the visible sides of every clear or reflective surface you can find .
do not scratch or rub the optics , use a brushing motion instead .
for more details on what you are doing and why , refer to the document mentioned in the introduction .

Steps.Text_raw: These are lenses, mirrors, and sensors used by the printer to determine how it is printing. Any damage will affect the quality of printing. Using a clean cotton swab or lens brush, GENTLY clean the visible sides of every clear or reflective surface you can find. Do not scratch or rub the optics, use a brushing motion instead. For more details on what you are doing and why, refer to the document mentioned in the introduction.

Lines.Text: finish with a light blast of compressed air on all of the surfaces you cleaned .
your printer should now be fully functional ! except for the part where it is disassembled .
to reassemble your device , repeat these steps in reverse order .

Steps.Text_raw: Finish with a light blast of compressed air on all of the surfaces you cleaned. Your printer should now be fully functional! Except for the part where it is disassembled. To reassemble your device, repeat these steps in reverse order.

Title: Logitech G500 Cord Replacement

Lines.Text: it's very common for this cord to fray with continued use . let's open up this mouse and replace the cord !

Steps.Text_raw: It's very common for this cord to fray with continued use. Let's open up this mouse and replace the cord!

Lines.Text: pry off the three feet to reveal screws .
it is easy to split the pads in half so make sure your spudger gets underneath both layers .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry off the three feet to reveal screws. It is easy to split the pads in half so make sure your spudger gets underneath both layers.

Lines.Text: locate the hidden screw hole behind the logitech sticker .
puncture the sticker to access the screw .
sometimes the screw head will not be removable because the sticker may get in the way . this is fine ; just make sure the screw stays inside and you don't lose it .
remove all five phillips screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the hidden screw hole behind the Logitech sticker. Puncture the sticker to access the screw. Sometimes the screw head will not be removable because the sticker may get in the way. This is fine; just make sure the screw stays inside and you don't lose it. Remove all five Phillips screws.

Lines.Text: now , or at any time , you may wish to remove the weighted cartridge inside of the mouse . it is best if you do it at or before this step , but it is not necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: Now, or at any time, you may wish to remove the weighted cartridge inside of the mouse. It is best if you do it at or before this step, but it is not necessary.

Lines.Text: with all screws removed , carefully pry the top of the mouse away from the body .
there is a cable securing the top of the mouse to the body . do not remove the case too far or this may break .

Steps.Text_raw: With all screws removed, carefully pry the top of the mouse away from the body. There is a cable securing the top of the mouse to the body. Do not remove the case too far or this may break.

Lines.Text: using a spudger , lift the zif cable guard .
remove the cable from the upper housing . the upper housing can now be set aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a spudger, lift the ZIF cable guard. Remove the cable from the upper housing. The upper housing can now be set aside.

Lines.Text: remove the three phillips screws to free the weight cartridge holder .
lift the weight cartridge holder from the body .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three Phillips screws to free the weight cartridge holder. Lift the weight cartridge holder from the body.

Lines.Text: pry the pin securing the mouse wheel and housing to the left .
remove the mouse wheel and housing .
save the two tiny springs under the wheel in a safe place until reassembly . not reinstalling these springs will cause the mouse to malfunction .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry the pin securing the mouse wheel and housing to the left. Remove the mouse wheel and housing. Save the two tiny springs under the wheel in a safe place until reassembly. Not reinstalling these springs will cause the mouse to malfunction.

Lines.Text: remove the two parallel screws holding a black piece of plastic to the mouse body .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two parallel screws holding a black piece of plastic to the mouse body.

Lines.Text: remove two screws securing the bottom circuit board to the bottom plate of the mouse .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove two screws securing the bottom circuit board to the bottom plate of the mouse.

Lines.Text: remove the final two phillips screws near the top of the mouse holding the circuit boards to the plate .
there is a transparent plastic part between the two boards . remember to reinstall this during reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the final two Phillips screws near the top of the mouse holding the circuit boards to the plate. There is a transparent plastic part between the two boards. Remember to reinstall this during reassembly.

Lines.Text: pull the circuit boards loose from the bottom plate .
you may need to use a spudger to pry the circuit free .
the mouse cable is glued to the bottom plate , so do not quickly yank the circuit boards away .
the circuit boards are not very strongly attached to each other ; do not pull hard on the top board or they may separate , damaging the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the circuit boards loose from the bottom plate. You may need to use a spudger to pry the circuit free. The mouse cable is glued to the bottom plate, so do not quickly yank the circuit boards away. The circuit boards are not very strongly attached to each other; do not pull hard on the top board or they may separate, damaging the device.

Lines.Text: carefully pry on each side of the mouse connector until the cable comes free .
since you don't care about the condition of the cable after you're done , an occasional light tug on the cable will help you determine if it is loose enough to be freed .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully pry on each side of the mouse connector until the cable comes free. Since you don't care about the condition of the cable after you're done, an occasional light tug on the cable will help you determine if it is loose enough to be freed.

Subject: Cord

Title: Western Digital My Book Mini USB Port Replacement

Lines.Text: start by turning the device port side up .
with the plastic opening tool , pry along the edges of the case .
when you hear the case snap-out of its fitted grooves , slowly slide the board assembly out of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Start by turning the device port side up. With the plastic opening tool, pry along the  edges of the case. When you hear the case  snap-out of its fitted grooves, slowly slide the board assembly out of the case.

Lines.Text: gently pull the three pronged , clear plastic piece from the rubber holder .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull the three pronged, clear plastic piece from the rubber holder.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two screws from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two screws from  the motherboard.

Lines.Text: remove all the rubber pieces from the four corners to unhinge the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove all the rubber pieces  from the four corners to  unhinge the motherboard.

Lines.Text: remove the motherboard .
set aside in a safe anti-static location .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the motherboard. Set aside in a safe anti-static location.

Lines.Text: grab the mini usb port and align it with the appropriate metal docks on the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab the mini USB port and align it with the appropriate  metal docks on the motherboard.

Lines.Text: soldering irons can get '''hot''' ! do not touch the iron tip , make sure it cools down for a good 30 minutes before touching the tip .
start heating up the soldering iron , may take about 1015 mins .

Steps.Text_raw: Soldering irons can get '''HOT'''!  Do not touch the iron tip, make sure it cools down for a good 30 minutes before touching the tip. Start heating up the Soldering  Iron, may take about 10–15 mins.

Lines.Text: solder together the four corners of the mini usb to the appropriate metal pieces on the motherboard .
make sure the usb is firmly attached to the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Solder together the four corners  of the mini USB to the  appropriate metal pieces on  the motherboard. Make sure the USB is firmly  attached to the motherboard.

note : i started with the paper trays already removed

lift the display panel
remove the blue connector and the ribbon cable gently

press the tab to release the clips , then when it's out gently pull towards you to release the back

unplug the ribbon cable and slid it out
note for reassembly : the ribbon cable placement holders can be removed to make it easier to re-thread the ribbon cable by gently pushing down the tabs with the spudger

Lines.Text: remove the panel on the left side exposing the wiring connectors for the top of the printer
after dissconecting the connectors remove the hole top of the printer and place it safely out of the way

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the Panel on the left side exposing the wiring connectors for the top of the printer After dissconecting the connectors remove the hole top of the printer and place it safely out of the way

Lines.Text: remove the 15 screws to the cover
remove the left and right side covers

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 15 screws to the cover Remove the left and right side covers

Lines.Text: remove the front corners by gently pulling upwards
open the back paper jam cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the front corners by gently pulling upwards Open the back paper jam cover.

Lines.Text: lift off the cover and put aside out of the way

Steps.Text_raw: Lift off the cover and put aside out of the way

Lines.Text: slide the clear print head guide wire off the tab on the right side
note : put on gloves if you have not it can get messy

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the clear print head guide wire off the tab on the right side *note: put on gloves if you have not it can get messy

Lines.Text: using a spudger , press down on the plastic housing of the park carriage that the print head rests on .
slide the print head to the left freeing it to move

Steps.Text_raw: Using a spudger, press down on the plastic housing of the park carriage that the print head rests on. Slide the print head to the left freeing it to move

Lines.Text: slide the print head left until it is at the end of the rail . you can feel it release ( lift upwards when it aligns with the cut out notch )
push the print head unit towards the back of the device and lift the unit from the back rail
using the spudger , press the spring section of the white pulley
release the conveyor from the pulley while the spring is still compressed
remove the conveyor from the gear on the other side of the device

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the print head left until it is at the end of the rail. You can feel it release (lift upwards when it aligns with the cut out notch) Push the print head unit towards the back of the device and lift the unit from the back rail Using the spudger, press the spring section of the white pulley Release the conveyor from the pulley while the spring is still compressed Remove the conveyor from the gear on the other side of the device

Lines.Text: how to clean with paper towel
tear a single sheet of paper towel in half . fold the sheet in half several times until it is about 1 /2 inch
put the print head on top of the paper towel and put a few drops of distilled water for at least 15 minutes . this will soften the ink on the printhead .

move print head assembly back to its resting position . you will probably notice that the paper towel now has one big black blob of ink on it . ( there is so much excess ink on the print head that all the colors are mixing to make black . )

if you cannot clearly see individual colors , then dampen another spot on the paper towel and move the print head back over the newly dampened spot on the paper towel . continue repeating this until you see all the individual colors .
note : when reassembling be certain to move the print head back to its resting position ( the extreme right side above the park carriage )

Steps.Text_raw: How to clean with paper towel Tear a single sheet of paper towel in half. Fold the sheet in half several times until it is about 1/2 inch Put the print head on top of the paper towel and put a few drops of distilled water  for at least 15 minutes. This will soften the ink on the printhead. Move print head assembly back to its resting position. You will probably notice that the paper towel now has one big black blob of ink on it. (There is so much excess ink on the print head that all the colors are mixing to make black.) If you cannot clearly see individual colors, then dampen another spot on the paper towel and move the print head back over the newly dampened spot on the paper towel. Continue repeating this until you see all the individual colors. *note:  when reassembling be certain to move the print head back to its resting position (the extreme right side above the park carriage)

Title: Replace Kyocera FS-1010 sponge rubber

Lines.Text: before you start , turn off the printer and remove all cables
in order to work better , it is recommended to remove the paper from the rear and front paper feed .

Steps.Text_raw: Before you start, turn off the printer and remove all cables In order to work better, it is recommended to remove the paper from the rear and front paper feed.

Lines.Text: use a phillips screwdriver to remove the phillips screw that holds the memory cover on the right side of the printer in place .
remove the memory cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips screwdriver to remove the Philips screw that holds the memory cover on the right side of the printer in place. Remove the memory cover.

Lines.Text: open the cover to change the toner
remove the two phillips screws that connect the top cover to the chassis .
since the cover is in the way , you can put the screwdriver only diagonally on the screws . be careful not to damage them .

Steps.Text_raw: Open the cover to change the toner Remove the two Phillips screws that connect the top cover to the chassis. Since the cover is in the way, you can put the screwdriver only diagonally on the screws. Be careful not to damage them.

Lines.Text: remove the top cover from the printer .
lift the cover on the front to easily and easily remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the top cover from the printer. Lift the cover on the front to easily and easily remove it.

Lines.Text: to remove the side cover , the front paper feed must be opened . in addition , the front paper cassette must be removed by pulling out to release one of the clips .
the cover is held in position by several clips . removing the side cover is the hardest part of the guide .
using a spudger or a flat-head screwdriver you can easily loosen the clips ( see picture 2 ) . there are several clips around the cover . only when all are solved , the side cover can be removed .
once all the clips have been released , you can fold the cover out of the front of the paper feeder ( see picture 3 ) .
make sure you do not damage any clips when removing the cover !

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the side cover, the front paper feed must be opened. In addition, the front paper cassette must be removed by pulling out to release one of the clips. The cover is held in position by several clips. Removing the side cover is the hardest part of the guide. Using a spudger or a flat-head screwdriver you can easily loosen the clips (see picture 2). There are several clips around the cover. Only when all are solved, the side cover can be removed. Once all the clips have been released, you can fold the cover out of the front of the paper feeder (see picture 3). Make sure you do not damage any clips when removing the cover!

Lines.Text: remove all cables from the board .
the green marked cables are very tight and difficult to loosen . take your time and do not exercise too much violence .
do not pull too hard on the cables as they may be damaged . attempt to loosen the plugs with a spudger or flat-head screwdriver .

Lines.Text: here are the three intake breakers to work on in the next steps .

at the red marked areas usually sits black foam rubber . this causes the problem - over time , it becomes sticky , which causes the interruption of the indentation only delayed . thus , the paper is fed too short / too far before the printing starts . this will move the text up or down .
in most cases , not every entry-breaker causes problems . nevertheless , it is advisable to replace the foam rubber directly on all parts in order to permanently eliminate the problem .

Steps.Text_raw: Here are the three intake breakers to work on in the next steps. At the red marked areas usually sits black foam rubber. This causes the problem - over time, it becomes sticky, which causes the interruption of the indentation only delayed. Thus, the paper is fed too short / too far before the printing starts. This will move the text up or down. In most cases, not every entry-breaker causes problems. Nevertheless, it is advisable to replace the foam rubber directly on all parts in order to permanently eliminate the problem.

Lines.Text: at this intake breaker the foam rubber is attached to the metal fork and not to the actual breaker . thus , an expansion of the actual feed breaker is not essential .
use tweezers or small pliers to remove the small spring that connects the metal fork to the feed breaker .
make sure that the spring does not fly away when removing !
in the picture you can already see the repaired component . normally , black sponge rubber is applied to the green marked area .
remove the metal fork .

Steps.Text_raw: At this intake breaker the foam rubber is attached to the metal fork and not to the actual breaker. Thus, an expansion of the actual feed breaker is not essential. Use tweezers or small pliers to remove the small spring that connects the metal fork to the feed breaker. Make sure that the spring does not fly away when removing! In the picture you can already see the repaired component. Normally, black sponge rubber is applied to the green marked area. Remove the metal fork.

Lines.Text: the green marked area usually contains black sponge rubber .
use a slotted screwdriver , a spudger or something similar to remove the sponge rubber . .
then clean the place to remove the glue residue . for cleaning , e . g . brake cleaner or silicone spray can be used .
after the spot has been cleaned , new sponge rubber or something similar ( e . g . , felt or shrink tubing as shown in the picture ) may be applied .

before reinstalling , also clean the place where the sponge rubber has come into contact with the actual retraction breaker to remove the glue residue . this is described at step 14 and can be done in this feed breaker in the installed state .
after cleaning and replacing the sponge rubber , the metal fork can be reinstalled . to do this , follow step 10 in reverse order

Lines.Text: use a slotted screwdriver , a spudger or something similar to remove the sponge rubber .
then clean the place to remove the glue residue . for cleaning , e . g . brake cleaner or silicone spray can be used .
after the site has been cleaned , new sponge rubber or something similar ( e . g . , felt or shrink tubing as shown in figure 3 ) can be applied .
before reinstalling , also clean the area where the sponge rubber has come into contact with the metal fork to remove the glue residue .
after cleaning and replacing the sponge rubber , the metal fork can be re-attached to the retraction breaker . to do this , follow step 13 in reverse order .
then the feed breaker can be re-installed in the printer . to do this , follow step 12 in reverse order .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a slotted screwdriver, a spudger or something similar to remove the sponge rubber. Then clean the place to remove the glue residue. For cleaning, e.g. Brake cleaner or silicone spray can be used. After the site has been cleaned, new sponge rubber or something similar (e.g., felt or shrink tubing as shown in Figure 3) can be applied. Before reinstalling, also clean the area where the sponge rubber has come into contact with the metal fork to remove the glue residue. After cleaning and replacing the sponge rubber, the metal fork can be re-attached to the retraction breaker. To do this, follow step 13 in reverse order. Then the feed breaker can be re-installed in the printer. To do this, follow step 12 in reverse order.

Lines.Text: remove the plug that connects the feed breaker to the board .
then remove the phillips screw and remove the feed breaker .

then follow steps 13 and 14 to remove the metal fork and old sponge rubber . to reinstall the metal fork , follow step 13 in reverse order . to reinstall the feed breaker in the printer , follow this step in reverse order .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plug that connects the feed breaker to the board. Then remove the Philips screw and remove the feed breaker. Then follow steps 13 and 14 to remove the metal fork and old sponge rubber. To reinstall the metal fork, follow step 13 in reverse order. To reinstall the feed breaker in the printer, follow this step in reverse order.

Lines.Text: here is the finished result . on all three intake breakers , the old sponge rubber was removed and replaced .
to check whether the repair was successful , you can press the metal fork against the feed breaker by hand . if you then let go off the metal fork , it should immediately jump back on the gear .

on the other hand , if the metal fork lingers briefly after being released and only returns with a delay , either the material that was used as a replacement is unsuitable or the area has not yet been completely cleaned of all adhesive residues . in this case , steps 10 and 11 or 12 , 13 and 14 should be repeated again .

Steps.Text_raw: Here is the finished result. On all three intake breakers, the old sponge rubber was removed and replaced. To check whether the repair was successful, you can press the metal fork against the feed breaker by hand. If you then let go off the metal fork, it should immediately jump back on the gear. On the other hand, if the metal fork lingers briefly after being released and only returns with a delay, either the material that was used as a replacement is unsuitable or the area has not yet been completely cleaned of all adhesive residues. In this case, steps 10 and 11 or 12, 13 and 14 should be repeated again.

Title: Logitech K750 Keyboard ML2032 to CR2032 battery replacement

Lines.Text: the battery tray is near the top edge of the bottom side of the keyboard . it is designed to be easy to insert , difficult to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: The battery tray is near the top edge of the bottom side of the keyboard.  It is designed to be easy to insert, difficult to remove.

Lines.Text: i used a putty knife to force the tray back out . just push it into the gap along the bottom , then angle the handle to direct the force of the tip away from the body of the keyboard . a few taps should get you this far .

Steps.Text_raw: I used a putty knife to force the tray back out.  Just push it into the gap along the bottom, then angle the handle to direct the force of the tip away from the body of the keyboard.  A few taps should get you this far.

Lines.Text: once you get the ears past the edge , just slide the tray the rest of the way out .
note the battery type carefully : it is a ml2032 , which is rechargeable . it is not the same as a cr2032 , which is not rechargeable . putting a cr2032 in here is a recipe for bad things to happen .

note the proper orientation ( see picture ) , positive + symbol facing towards bottom . negative side facing keys . slide the tray with the new battery back in . the battery can be oriented incorrectly and not work .
if you want to make it easier to remove the battery the next time , you could trim the ears slightly . or slice some notches in the plastic springs to weaken a little .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you get the "ears" past the edge, just slide the tray the rest of the way out. Note the battery type carefully:  It is a ML2032, which is rechargeable.  It is NOT the same as a CR2032, which is not rechargeable.  Putting a CR2032 in here is a recipe for bad things to happen. Note the proper orientation (see picture), positive + symbol facing towards bottom.  Negative side facing keys.  Slide the tray with the new battery back in.  The battery can be oriented incorrectly and NOT work. If you want to make it easier to remove the battery the next time, you could trim the ears slightly.  Or slice some notches in the plastic "springs" to weaken a little.

Title: Repairing Samsung SyncMaster SA300 Flicker and Vertical Lines

Lines.Text: place the monitor face-down on a mat , soft clean microfiber cloth , or even a dry towel , with the stand ( bottom ) facing toward you .
remove the stand by firmly pulling on the small , cylindrical portion while applying pressure on the swiveling mount .

work your way around the edge of the monitor using a plastic spudger , guitar pick , or smooth metal spudger . there's a large metal casing around the display , giving you some room for error as you work the plastic clips around it .
detach the small cables by pulling on the connectors and wiggling them off with spudgers , then remove the zif ribbon by flipping the back of the connector's black flipper upward .
remove the display and single pcb from the front mount by pulling up , then forward , clearing the small metal clip at the bottom of the display .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the monitor face-down on a mat, soft clean microfiber cloth, or even a dry towel, with the stand (bottom) facing toward you. Remove the stand by firmly pulling on the small, cylindrical portion while applying pressure on the swiveling mount. Work your way around the edge of the monitor using a plastic spudger, guitar pick, or smooth metal spudger. There's a large metal casing around the display, giving you some room for error as you work the plastic clips around it. detach the small cables by pulling on the connectors and wiggling them off with spudgers, then remove the ZIF ribbon by flipping the "back" of the connector's black flipper upward. Remove the display and single PCB from the front mount by pulling up, then forward, clearing the small metal clip at the bottom of the display.

Lines.Text: place the display face-down on a flat , heat-resistant surface . ideally this is soft enough not to damage the fragile front of the display , and doesn't conduct heat like metal would . i used a thin fabric mat .

fully remove the plastic shielding over the pcb by pulling up on the thick plastic with a spudger or your fingernails , taking care not to damage the aluminum tape . the black tape at the top will most likely have to be cut or pulled away , making it useless . put aside .

while you could replace the aluminum tape with your own , the one that comes with the display can withstand being pulled out once or twice and has helpful holes that line up with dimples on the metallic back of the display for re-placement .

lightly stick aluminum tape or kapton tape , either on it's own or with attached aluminum foil , to shield all components but the long set of contacts at the top of the pcb , and the flex cables attached to them .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the display face-down on a flat, heat-resistant surface. Ideally this is soft enough not to damage the fragile front of the display, and doesn't conduct heat like metal would. I used a thin fabric mat. Fully remove the plastic shielding over the PCB by pulling up on the thick plastic with a spudger or your fingernails, taking care not to damage the aluminum tape. The black tape at the top will most likely have to be cut or pulled away, making it useless. Put aside. While you could replace the aluminum tape with your own, the one that comes with the display can withstand being pulled out once or twice and has helpful holes that line up with dimples on the metallic back of the display for re-placement. Lightly stick aluminum tape or "Kapton" tape, either on it's own or with attached aluminum foil, to shield all components but the long set of contacts at the top of the PCB, and the flex cables attached to them.

Lines.Text: hold a heatgun at one centimeter from one of the flexible ribbons , using your non-dominant hand , moving slightly to cover the whole thing , or staying still if using a flat nozzle . set to 300 c and fire for one minute .

hold the spudger with the hand you write with , and the gun with the other . if you're prone to trembling or need to hold the gun in both hands , do so , but have a place to leave it while you use the spudger .

turn off and move the heat gun away , then using your dominant hand , firmly press a plastic spudger or guitar pick against the ribbon cable , running it from one direction to another , at least twice .
repeat process with all ribbon cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold a heatgun at one centimeter from one of the flexible ribbons, using your non-dominant hand, moving slightly to cover the whole thing, or staying still if using a flat nozzle. Set to 300 ° C and fire for one minute. Hold the spudger with the hand you write with, and the gun with the other. If you're prone to trembling or need to hold the gun in both hands, do so, but have a place to leave it while you use the spudger. Turn off and move the heat gun away, then using your dominant hand, firmly press a plastic spudger or guitar pick against the ribbon cable, running it from one direction to another, at least twice. Repeat process with all ribbon cables.

Lines.Text: if you used a conductive material like aluminum to shield the pcb , remove it . temporarily shield it with non-conductive tape , for example , lightly apply scotch tape to it , to prevent a shortcircuit .

re-place the front of the bezel , the connector and logic board assembly , and keep them stuck to the monitor using tape . re-connect all internal cables , then connect a working display output and a power cable .

it's obviously dangerous to test a display without covering up it's components , but it's extremely tedious to remove the entire bezel assembly over and over . use thick , non-conductive gloves , exercise caution .
turn on the monitor , propping it against something solid , or having someone hold it in position . run tests , for example a full-screen video or a full-screen stuck pixel fixer
if the problem reappears , re-apply insulation to the top pcb and repeat step 3.
if the problem does not reappear , remove the tape , re-apply the thick plastic shield using scotch or kapton tape in place of the black tape , and re-assemble the bezel .
after making sure all cables are in place and secured , simply place the back of the case on top of the monitor , align it correctly , and push down along the perimeter .

Steps.Text_raw: If you used a conductive material like Aluminum to shield the PCB, remove it. Temporarily shield it with non-conductive tape, for example, lightly apply scotch tape to it, to prevent a shortcircuit. Re-place the front of the bezel, the connector and logic board assembly, and keep them stuck to the monitor using tape. Re-connect all internal cables, then connect a working display output and a power cable. It's obviously dangerous to test a display without covering up it's components, but it's extremely tedious to remove the entire bezel assembly over and over. Use thick, non-conductive gloves, exercise caution. Turn on the monitor, propping it against something solid, or having someone hold it in position. Run tests, for example a full-screen video or a full-screen "stuck pixel fixer" If the problem reappears, re-apply insulation to the top PCB and repeat step 3. If the problem does not reappear, remove the tape, re-apply the thick plastic shield using scotch or kapton tape in place of the black tape, and re-assemble the bezel. After making sure all cables are in place and secured, simply place the back of the case on top of the monitor, align it correctly, and push down along the perimeter.

Title: Canon CanoScan N670U Sensor Bar Replacement

Lines.Text: open up your canon canoscan n670 u to an upright position .

Lines.Text: turn your device so that you're facing the long side of the canon canoscan n670 u .
locate the small crevice between the plastic components of the scanner bed and the scanner base .

Lines.Text: carefully insert a metal spudger tool in the crevice and slowly cut through the adhesive between the plastic components .
you may cut small bits of the plastic as you're slicing the adhesive . do not forcefully bend the plastic strip as you're cutting or it will snap .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully insert a metal spudger tool in the crevice and slowly cut through the adhesive between the plastic components. You may cut small bits of the plastic as you're slicing the adhesive. Do not forcefully bend the plastic strip as you're cutting or it will snap.

Lines.Text: repeat steps 2-4 for the other side of the scanner .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat steps 2-4 for the other side of the scanner.

Lines.Text: use your hands or a metal spudger tool to push the plastic bar at the bottom of the glass scanner bed forward until you can't push it any farther .

Lines.Text: insert the metal spudger tool underneath the glass scanner bed . the front of the scanner bed should be resting on top of the tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the metal spudger tool underneath the glass scanner bed. The front of the scanner bed should be resting on top of the tool.

Lines.Text: slowly pull the glass scanner bed towards you and set the piece aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly pull the glass scanner bed towards you and set the piece aside.

Lines.Text: this is the sensor bar that you will replace .

Steps.Text_raw: This is the sensor bar that you will replace.

Lines.Text: locate the small plug where the white strip of cable is connected to .
unfurl the cable strip if it's tucked in .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the small plug where the white strip of cable is connected to. Unfurl the cable strip if it's tucked in.

Lines.Text: gently use tweezers or your fingers to rock the cable back and forth to disconnect the it .
do not apply too much pressure or you may damage some delicate components .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently use tweezers or your fingers to rock the cable back and forth to disconnect the it. Do not apply too much pressure or you may damage some delicate components.

Lines.Text: locate the small metal spring behind the front buttons of the canon canoscan n670 u .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the small metal spring behind the front buttons of the Canon CanoScan N670U.

Lines.Text: use tweezers to gently remove the metal spring from the plastic hook .
due to the tension of the spring , it can be difficult to pull the metal end . you may attempt to use your hands to pull the spring itself if necessary .
take caution to not bend the metal .

Steps.Text_raw: Use tweezers to gently remove the metal spring from the plastic hook. Due to the tension of the spring, it can be difficult to pull the metal end. You may attempt to use your hands to pull the spring itself if necessary. Take caution to not bend the metal.

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the sensor bar over and unwind the belt from the gear system.

Lines.Text: remove the sensor bar from the scanner and replace it with the new one .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the sensor bar from the scanner and replace it with the new one.

Subject: Sensor Bar

Title: Rebuilding the ASF Assy

Lines.Text: remove the rear housing
remove the side panels
remove the upper housing

Steps.Text_raw: remove the rear housing remove the side panels remove the upper housing

Lines.Text: this is the asf assy which we will be removing .
i have separated the panel ffc ( control panel ) from the upper housing and reattached it to the printer for testing purposes .

Steps.Text_raw: This is the "ASF Assy" which we will be removing. I have separated the "Panel FFC" (control panel) from the upper housing and reattached it to the printer for testing purposes.

Lines.Text: our first task is to remove the metal brackets which hold the guide roller in place .
metal brackets
guide roller

Steps.Text_raw: Our first task is to remove the metal brackets which hold the Guide Roller in place. metal brackets Guide Roller

Lines.Text: note the vertical position of the screws holding the metal brackets . they move up and down to adjust the position of the guide roller . mine were in the highest position , which puts the least amount of pressure on the guide roller .
remove the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Note the vertical position of the screws holding the metal brackets.  They move up and down to adjust the position of the Guide Roller.  Mine were in the highest position, which puts the least amount of pressure on the Guide Roller. Remove the screws.

Lines.Text: gently pull on the roller guide to release the metal bracket from the shaft .
tilt the metal bracket sideways and off of the cam .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull on the Roller Guide to release the metal bracket from the shaft. Tilt the metal bracket sideways and off of the cam.

Lines.Text: because the roller guide flexes slightly , you can now shift the metal bracket toward the rear of the printer , to disengage it from the carriage assembly .
(needs new picture )

Steps.Text_raw: Because the Roller Guide flexes slightly, you can now shift the metal bracket toward the rear of the printer, to disengage it from the carriage assembly. (needs new picture)

Lines.Text: rotate the metal bracket upward around the roller guide and remove it .
(needs another picture )

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the metal bracket upward around the Roller Guide and remove it. (needs another picture)

Lines.Text: disconnect the sheet feeder motor at the relay connector and unroute the relay wire from the 'asf assy' .
the release tab for the relay connector is on the motor side of the connector .
separate the sheet feeder motor ground wire from the chassis ground .
i like to put the grounding screw back to keep it from getting lost .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the sheet feeder motor at the relay connector and unroute the relay wire from the 'ASF Assy'. The release tab for the relay connector is on the motor side of the connector. Separate the sheet feeder motor ground  wire from the chassis ground. I like to put the grounding screw back to keep it from getting lost.

Lines.Text: disconnect the ffc ( flat flexible cable ) ( which links the main board to the relay board ) at cn1
disconnect the paper edge sensor at cn2
disconnect the apg ( automatic paper guide ? ) sensors at cn4 and cn5.

disconnect the ffc which links the paper feed encoder to the relay board at cn6. the paper feed encoder's ffc is also tacked to the sheet feeder by double sided tape . carefully separate the cable from the sheet feeder's frame .
deroute the red black apg motor wires from the asf ( automatic sheet feeder ) housing .
deroute the flat flexible cables from the groove in the automatic sheet feeder housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the FFC (flat flexible cable) (which links the main board to the relay board) at CN1 Disconnect the Paper Edge sensor at CN2 Disconnect the APG (automatic paper guide?) sensors at CN4 and CN5. Disconnect the FFC which links the Paper Feed Encoder to the relay board at CN6.  The Paper Feed Encoder's FFC is also tacked to the Sheet Feeder by double sided tape.  Carefully separate the cable from the Sheet Feeder's frame. Deroute the red & black APG motor wires from the ASF (automatic sheet feeder) housing. Deroute the Flat Flexible Cables from the groove in the Automatic Sheet Feeder housing.

Lines.Text: remove right side screws .
remove left side screw .
todo : update left side picture to show correct disassembly state .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove right side screws. Remove left side screw. todo: update left side picture to show correct disassembly state.

Lines.Text: hold the sheet feeder here and lift it free .
because many of these printers were used in semi-professional settings , they were often modified . this one has a waste ink tank , bypassing the waste ink pads and the associated end-of-life error .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the Sheet Feeder here and lift it free. Because many of these printers were used in semi-professional settings, they were often modified.  This one has a waste ink tank, bypassing the waste ink pads and the associated end-of-life error.

Title: HP Photosmart 5520 Maintenance

Lines.Text: turn on the printer
lift up the scanner glass and the top cover , then the printerhead is centered in the printer case
remove the ink cartridges .
unplug the printer but do not turn off with the front i/o button . otherwise the printhead will return to its park slot .
use adhesive tape to fix together the scanner glass and the cover

Steps.Text_raw: Turn on the printer Lift up the scanner glass and the top cover, then the printerhead is centered in the printer case Remove the ink cartridges. Unplug the printer but do not turn off with the front I/O button. Otherwise the printhead will return to its park slot. Use adhesive tape to fix together the scanner glass and the cover

Lines.Text: gently pull on the hook . retain the scanner glass and the cover once the hook is removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull on the hook. Retain the scanner glass and the cover once the hook is removed.

Lines.Text: unscrew the 7 torx screws . do not forget the one below the printer label ( lower right corner ) .
push the clips at the rear of the lcd panel and pull the lcd panel outwards at the same time
then , pull the ribbon connected to the lcd panel
remove the 2 remaining torx screws hidden by the lcd panel
see where are clips ( blue arrows )

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the 7 torx screws. Do not forget the one below the printer label (Lower right corner). Push the clips at the rear of the LCD panel and pull the LCD panel outwards at the same time Then, pull the ribbon connected to the LCD panel Remove the 2 remaining torx screws hidden by the LCD panel See where are clips (Blue arrows)

Lines.Text: remove the springs that maintain the print head .
remove the print head by pulling on the ribbons .
in case you want to replace the print head , the spare part reference is : cn688 a
when inserting the print head after cleaning or replacing , make sure the horizontal plastic ribbon is between the plastic guides , as shown in the last picture .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the springs that maintain the print head. Remove the print head by pulling on the ribbons. In case you want to replace the print head, the spare part reference is: CN688A When inserting the print head after cleaning or replacing, make sure the horizontal plastic ribbon is between the plastic guides, as shown in the last picture.

Lines.Text: the printer has an automatic feature to clean the print head . usually , there is a lot of ink ( probably melt with dust ) in the area where the print head is cleaned
remove the 5 torx screw as shown in the picture
assuming the print head is now removed ( not shown on the picture ) , now gently tip the plastic plate and remove it
if you didn't put gloves yet , it is time to do it !
now , push the carriage that holds the print head cleaning system ( red arrows )
the carriage that holds the print head cleaning system is now clean ( last picture )

Steps.Text_raw: The printer has an automatic feature to clean the print head. Usually, there is a lot of ink (Probably melt with dust) in the area where the print head is cleaned Remove the 5 torx screw as shown in the picture Assuming the print head is now removed (Not shown on the picture), now gently tip the plastic plate and remove it If you didn't put gloves yet, it is time to do it ! Now, push the carriage that holds the print head cleaning system (Red arrows) The carriage that holds the print head cleaning system is now clean (Last picture)

Title: Canon Selphy CP910 Printer Body Replacement

Lines.Text: turn the printer over .
use the ph1 screw bit to remove the three 8 mm screws in the middle of the back plate .
keep track of these screws because you will need them to reassemble the printer .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the printer over. Use the PH1 screw bit to  remove the three 8 mm screws in the middle of the back plate. Keep track of these screws because you will need them to reassemble the printer.

Lines.Text: loosen up the four 10 mm corner screws .
a screwdriver with a long shaft approximately 7 mm in diameter will make it easier to reach these screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen up the four 10 mm corner screws. A screwdriver with a long shaft approximately 7mm in diameter will make it easier to reach these screws.

Lines.Text: turn the device around and remove the open lid .
this lid needs to be removed in order to take the printer apart .
gently bend the lid and remove it from its hinges .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the device around and remove the "open" lid. This lid needs to be removed in order to take the printer apart. Gently bend the lid and remove it from its hinges.

Lines.Text: turn the device back over and lift the top panel up .
disconnect the ribbon cables leading to the lcd screen .
pull the top panel off .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the device back over and lift the top panel up. Disconnect the ribbon cables leading to the LCD screen. Pull the top panel off.

Lines.Text: use the ph1 screwdriver to remove the three screws on the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the PH1 screw driver to remove the three screws on the motherboard.

Lines.Text: remove the printer .
this will prevent the printer from falling out during repair .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the printer. This will prevent the printer from falling out during repair.

Lines.Text: remove the output connections .
be careful ! do not pull too hard because the wires might rip .
output connections are located on the corners of the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the output connections. Be careful! Do not pull too hard because the wires might rip. Output connections are located on the corners of the motherboard.

Lines.Text: the motherboard is attached to three more ribbon wires .
detach these wires .
be careful not to pull too hard .

Steps.Text_raw: The motherboard is attached to three more ribbon wires. Detach these wires. Be careful not to pull too hard.

Lines.Text: separate the motherboard from the main hard drive .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the motherboard from the main hard drive.

Lines.Text: remove the main hard drive from the printer body .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the main hard drive from the printer body.

Lines.Text: gently remove the fan from the body .
the fan is glued to the case . when you install it in the new body , use hot glue to secure it in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently remove the fan from the body. The fan is glued to the case. When you install it in the new body, use hot glue to secure it in place.

Lines.Text: the empty case will look like this once all the parts are removed .

Steps.Text_raw: The empty case will look like this once all the parts are removed.

Subject: Printer Body

Title: Fix Linksys WRT54GC yellow light error

Lines.Text: insert your x-acto knife on the groove in order to remove part of the glue that is holding the two parts .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert your X-Acto knife on the groove in order to remove part of the glue that is holding the two parts.

Lines.Text: using your prying tools or a butter knife , slide it in and then bend it until you ear it pop .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your prying tools or a butter knife, slide it in and then bend it until you ear it pop.

Lines.Text: on the board of the power supply you'll probably see the faulty capacitor . is the one on the right that has swollen .

Steps.Text_raw: On the board of the power supply you'll probably see the faulty capacitor. Is the one on the right that has swollen.

Lines.Text: the capacitor has a right position . mind the markings on the capacitor and the board , they must match .
i used a 1000 uf 25 v that i've removed from an old crt monitor , but the recommended one is a 1000 uf 16 v or 1000 uf 10 v ( like the original ) .
using the soldering iron , desolder the faulty capacitor and solder a new one .

Steps.Text_raw: The capacitor has a right position. Mind the markings on the capacitor and the board, they must match. I used a 1000uF 25V that I've removed from an old CRT monitor, but the recommended one is a 1000uF 16V or 1000uF 10V (like the original). Using the soldering iron, desolder the faulty capacitor and solder a new one.

Lines.Text: reassemble the power supply and your router should be back and running fine : )

Steps.Text_raw: Reassemble the power supply and your router should be back and running fine :)

Subject: Capacitor from the power supply

Title: OnHub Speaker Grille Replacement

Lines.Text: make sure the device is unplugged before proceeding with the disassembly .
while holding the base firmly using the palm of one hand , remove the cowl ( cover ) by turning the cowl counterclockwise until a snap is heard . once disengaged , pull upwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the device is unplugged before proceeding with the disassembly. While holding the base firmly using the palm of one hand, remove the cowl (cover) by turning the cowl counterclockwise until a snap is heard. Once disengaged, pull upwards.

Lines.Text: place the plastic opening tool under the speaker grille , and just above the light ring .
move the plastic opening tool around the groove while applying upward force to pry loose the 4 clips holding the grille in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the plastic opening tool under the speaker grille, and just above the light ring. Move the plastic opening tool around the groove while applying upward force to pry loose the 4 clips holding the grille in place.

Lines.Text: using a metal spudger , carefully remove the congestion-sensor antenna by undoing the two clips .
there is a delicate wire connection to the antenna that is easily broken if not careful .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a metal spudger, carefully remove the congestion-sensor antenna by undoing the two clips. There is a delicate wire connection to the antenna that is easily broken if not careful.

Subject: Speaker Grille

while holding the base firmly using the palm of one hand , remove the cowl ( cover ) by turning the cowl counterclockwise until a snap is heard . once disengaged , pull upwards .

move the plastic opening tool around the groove while applying upward force to pry loose the 4 clips holding the grille in place .

there is a delicate wire connection to the antenna that is easily broken if not careful .

Lines.Text: remove the wire connection to the antenna by soldering it off .
for help with soldering and de-soldering check out the soldering guide

Title: Iomega MiniMax Disassembly

Lines.Text: before you begin :
if your disk is mounted and running , be sure to eject it from your desktop .
turn power off via the physical switch on the rear of the enclosure .

remove all cables from the rear of the device . make note of which cables were used in which ports if you have multiple devices and may mix them up . it's best to use the exact same ports to eliminate any potential issues in case you have a bad port .

Steps.Text_raw: Before you begin: If your disk is mounted and running, be sure to eject it from your desktop. Turn power off via the physical switch on the rear of the enclosure. Remove all cables from the rear of the device.  Make note of which cables were used in which ports if you have multiple devices and may mix them up.  It's best to use the exact same ports to eliminate any potential issues in case you have a bad port.

Lines.Text: on the rear of the device , remove the 2 phillips screws , with a small screwdriver . screws are both the same .
(sorry for the poor quality photos . )

Steps.Text_raw: On the rear of the device, remove the 2 philips screws, with a small screwdriver.  Screws are both the same. (Sorry for the poor quality photos.)

Lines.Text: using a thin rigid tool ( or old credit card ) , start on the rear , wedge it into the gap between the upper and lower cases as shown .
slowly work your way around the device while gently pulling up on the separating cover .

make sure to use care near the rear center , to avoid breaking a single center tab at this location . by the time you get to the front , the upper case should almost be falling off , and can be easily removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a thin rigid tool (or old credit card), start on the rear, wedge it into the gap between the upper and lower cases as shown. Slowly work your way around the device while gently pulling up on the separating cover. Make sure to use care near the rear center, to avoid breaking a single center  tab at this location.  By the time you get to the front, the upper case should almost be falling off, and can be easily removed.

Lines.Text: remove upper case . one each of the left , front , and right sides , you can see 3 tabs ( per side ) , that were holding the case on . on the rear you will see the fragile clip that should be removed last , if possible .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove upper case.  One each of the Left, Front, and Right sides, you can see 3 tabs (per side), that were holding the case on.  On the rear you will see the fragile clip that should be removed last, if possible.

Title: OnHub Speaker Replacement

Lines.Text: make sure the device is unplugged before proceeding with the disassembly .
while holding the base firmly using the palm of one hand , remove the cowl ( cover ) by turning the cowl counterclockwise until a snap is heard . once disengaged , pull upwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the device is unplugged before proceeding with the disassembly. While holding the base firmly using the palm of one hand, remove the cowl (cover) by turning the cowl counterclockwise until a snap is heard. Once disengaged, pull upwards.

Lines.Text: place the plastic opening tool under the speaker grille , and just above the light ring .
move the plastic opening tool around the groove while applying upward force to pry loose the 4 clips holding the grille in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the plastic opening tool under the speaker grille, and just above the light ring. Move the plastic opening tool around the groove while applying upward force to pry loose the 4 clips holding the grille in place.

Lines.Text: using a metal spudger , carefully remove the congestion-sensor antenna by undoing the two clips .
there is a delicate wire connection to the antenna that is easily broken if not careful .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a metal spudger, carefully remove the congestion-sensor antenna by undoing the two clips. There is a delicate wire connection to the antenna that is easily broken if not careful.

Lines.Text: remove the wire connection to the antenna by soldering it off .
for help with soldering and de-soldering check out the soldering guide

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the wire connection to the antenna by soldering it off. For help with soldering and de-soldering check out the    [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|iFixit Soldering Guide|new_window=true]

Lines.Text: you must remove the plastic cover found just above the speaker .
wedge the plastic opening tool under the cover and apply pressure in an upward direction .
there are four clips that you are removing . when disengaged , these clips will make a snapping noise .
though the snapping noise is normal , take care not to break these clips .

Steps.Text_raw: You must remove the plastic cover found just above the speaker. Wedge the plastic opening tool under the cover and apply pressure in an upward direction. There are four clips that you are removing. When disengaged, these clips will make a snapping noise. Though the snapping noise is normal, take care not to break these clips.

Lines.Text: upon removing the cover , four screws and the speaker housing will be exposed .
unscrew the four 12 mm screws using a 1 phillips head screwdriver .
this unlocks the speaker housing and antenna array from the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Upon removing the cover, four screws and the speaker housing will be exposed. Unscrew the four 12mm screws using a #1 Phillips head screwdriver. This unlocks the speaker housing and antenna array from the casing.

Lines.Text: on the bottom of the onhub is two screws holding the casing to the base .
to access these screws , you must remove the rubber pad that is glued to the base .
to remove the pad , slide a metal spudger under the edge of the pad . pry the pad away from the base , removing the glue .
once the pad is pulled up enough to grab , peel it the rest of the way exposing the screws .
the rubber pad is thin and fragile ; be careful not to tear when removing .

Steps.Text_raw: On the bottom of the OnHub is two screws holding the casing to the base. To access these screws, you must remove the rubber pad that is glued to the base. To remove the pad, slide a metal spudger under the edge of the pad. Pry the pad away from the base, removing the glue. Once the pad is pulled up enough to grab, peel it the rest of the way exposing the screws. The rubber pad is thin and fragile; be careful not to tear when removing.

Lines.Text: remove the two 12 mm screws under the base of the onhub by using a 1 phillips head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 12mm screws under the base of the OnHub by using a #1 Phillips head screwdriver.

Lines.Text: once the two screws are removed from the base , it is time to split the casing apart .
it is okay if a couple clips break . it will still hold together with a few remaining .
wedge a spudger between the two casing halves , and pry the clips apart starting from the top
there are three hooking style clips in total .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the two screws are removed from the base, it is time to split the casing apart. It is okay if a couple clips break. It will still hold together with a few remaining. Wedge a spudger between the two casing halves, and pry the clips apart starting from the top There are three hooking style clips in total.

Lines.Text: once unclipped , you can slide the two casing halves apart , and remove the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Once unclipped, you can slide the two casing halves apart, and remove the casing.

Lines.Text: underneath the speaker is an intertwined black and white wire .
disconnect the wire from its connection to the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Underneath the speaker is an intertwined black and white wire. Disconnect the wire from its connection to the motherboard.

Lines.Text: the speaker should now easily come off with a firm grip on the onhub device and pull .

Steps.Text_raw: The speaker should now easily come off with a firm grip on the OnHub device and pull.

Title: Verizon Ellipsis Jetpack MHS800L Battery Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the sim card , that is located on top of the jetpack .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the SIM card, that is located on top of the Jetpack.

Lines.Text: with the device on its back and the label facing you , remove the rubber screw cover on the top left corner of the device .
under the rubber circle , remove the 1.25 mm screw using a phillips 00 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: With the device on its back and the label facing you, remove the rubber screw cover on the top left corner of the device. Under the rubber circle, remove the 1.25 mm screw using a Philips #00 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove three 1.25 mm screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove three 1.25 mm screws.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool at the seams and pry open the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool at the seams and pry open the case.

Lines.Text: once the cover is off , this is what your device will look like .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the cover is off, this is what your device will look like.

Lines.Text: once you have the case off of your device gently pull your battery away from the device .
do not attempt to completely remove the battery , as it is still attached to the motherboard by wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have the case off of your device gently pull your battery away from the device. Do not attempt to completely remove the battery, as it is still attached to the motherboard by wires.

Lines.Text: with a pair of esd tweezers remove the yellow tape covering the battery wires .

Steps.Text_raw: With a pair of ESD Tweezers remove the yellow tape covering the battery wires.

Lines.Text: after removing the tape you may use the esd tweezers to remove the wiring harness from the circuit board .
do not squeeze the wires to hard you may damage them and cause a short .

Steps.Text_raw: After removing the tape you may use the ESD Tweezers to remove the wiring harness from the circuit board. Do not squeeze the wires to hard you may damage them and cause a short.

Lines.Text: you may now replace the battery in your verizon ellipsis jetpack mhs800 l .

Steps.Text_raw: You may now replace  the battery in your Verizon Ellipsis Jetpack MHS800L.
