Steps.Text_raw: there are another 7 hidden screws that need to be removed. once that is done you can slowly start separating the plastic shell be careful, the thumb keys(underneath the spacebar) mas a tendency to stay stuck to the the top plastic part but its attached to the main PCB that is attched to the bottom, hence the next step.

Lines.Text: carefully separate the cable from the main body
remove the thumb key pcb from the top plastic bit ( you can put the top plastic part to the side as you'll only need it when you are closing up the keyboard
i recommend reconnecting the thumb key pcb to the main keyboard as it can be easily forgotten when closing up .
enjoy the easter egg . (after all you are now a l337 h4x0 r yourself )

Steps.Text_raw: carefully separate the cable from the main body remove the thumb key PCB from the top plastic bit ( you can put the top plastic part to the side as you'll only need it when you are closing up the keyboard I recommend reconnecting the thumb key PCB to the main keyboard as it can be easily forgotten when closing up. enjoy the easter egg.(after all you are now a l337 h4x0r yourself)

Lines.Text: flip over the pcb and remove the usb cable . ( more of an optional step but wort the effort )

Steps.Text_raw: flip over the PCB and remove the USB cable. (more of an optional step but wort the effort)

Lines.Text: here we are removing the shift led and switch with the break key led and switch .
if you want to take out all the key caps and do some basic maintenance on your keyboard , now is a good time but erm . . take a picture of your layout first .
flip the keyboard over and identify the keys , here i have outlined them with a sharpie

Steps.Text_raw: here we are removing the shift led and switch with the "break" key led and switch. if you want to take out all the key caps and do some basic maintenance on your keyboard, now is a good time but erm.. take a picture of your layout first. flip the keyboard over and identify the keys, here I have outlined them with a sharpie

Lines.Text: every key will have at least four solder points . two for the led , two for the switch . the ones that are parallel to each other , are the led ( highlighted here in yellow and the switch solder points are in an offset placement ( like a knight in chess ) , highlighted here in red
after removing the solder , you should be able to pull the led free . take it slow and if you feel that it is still stuck , repeat the process to ensure there isn't any solder holding it in place .
if you are replacing the switch , after removing the solder push the switch from the back

Steps.Text_raw: every key will have at least four solder points.  two for the led, two for the switch. the ones that are parallel to each other, are the led (highlighted here in yellow and the switch solder points are in an offset placement (like a knight in chess), highlighted here in red after removing the solder , you should be able to pull the led free. take it slow and if you feel that it is still stuck, repeat the process to ensure there isn't any solder holding it in place. if you are replacing the switch, after removing the solder push the switch from the back

Lines.Text: get your new donor switch and let and get ready to resolder . look at other keys for reference on the correct way to pop in your led
if you have access to bluetac , it may help hold the key and led in place without leaving any residue ( and being easy to clean )
when soldering , less is more , i actually redid this because i used too much solder

Steps.Text_raw: get your new donor switch and let and get ready to resolder. look at other keys for reference on the correct way to pop in your led if you have access to bluetac, it may help hold the key and led in place without leaving any residue (and being easy to clean) when soldering, less is more, I actually redid this because I used too much solder

Lines.Text: before testing your changes , hit the keyboard with some compressed air to remove any solder that may have fallen on it and could cause a short . doing basic maintenance now is also a good idea .
reconnect the usb power and test your keyboard while it is still open and easier for you to work on .
success ! everything is working and you can now go ahead and close up your keyboard , you are finished

Title: Kodak ESP C315 - How to reseat printhead ribbon cable

Lines.Text: the cat is out of the bag ! - : ( loose ribbon cable ( image 1 red )
lift the top hinged lid ( not just the scanner lid )
remove any power to the printer and use a long flat bladed screwdriver to release the cartridges - move them into the centre position ( image 2 )
follow the general advice on this video to release the printhead park lock but be aware your printhead on the c315 will be on the right hand side not the left
remove the cartridges by pinching the ends with thumb and finger , then lifting upwards and out
now remove the printhead cartridge carrier tray by pushing up on the grey tab above the pressure point ( label ) ( image 3 )

Steps.Text_raw: "The cat is out of the bag!" - :( loose ribbon cable (Image 1 red) Lift the top hinged lid (not just the scanner lid) Remove any power to the printer and use a long flat bladed screw driver to release  the cartridges - move them into the centre position (Image 2) Follow the general advice on this video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n3bQ0n417UU) to release the printhead park lock but be aware your printhead on the C315 will be on the right hand side not the left Remove the cartridges by pinching the ends with thumb and finger, then lifting upwards and out Now remove the printhead cartridge carrier tray by pushing up on the grey tab above the pressure point (label) (Image 3)

Lines.Text: using your t-8 torx ( image 1 ) untighten the two screws ( image 2 ) and keep safe . you will only need the t-8 torx again to replace these screws
next use the long flat bladed screwdriver to press back on the tab ( image 3 orange arrow ) whilst lifting upward on the top bar ( image 3 red rectangle )
there are two lugs and two areas on the top bar to grab , once both lugs are released and visible ( sat slightly forward ) it is time to loosen the top plastic

Steps.Text_raw: Using your T-8 Torx (Image 1) untighten the two screws (Image 2) and keep safe. You will only need the T-8 Torx again to replace these screws Next use the long flat bladed screw driver to press back on the tab (Image 3 orange arrow) whilst lifting upward on the top bar (Image 3 red rectangle) There are two lugs and two areas on the top bar to grab, once both lugs are released and visible (sat slightly forward) it is time to loosen the top plastic

Lines.Text: warning ! there is a clear coloured optical ribbon ( image 1 ) which runs through the top section of the printhead . avoid damaging with the flat blade
you need to put the flat blade into the seam near the top just in front of or just behind the optical cable , wherever you feel most comfortable ( image 2 )
repeat for the other side
your cover should wiggle freely , it should move up and down

Steps.Text_raw: Warning! There is a clear coloured optical ribbon (Image 1) which runs through the top section of the printhead. Avoid damaging with the flat blade You need to put the flat blade into the seam near the top just in front of or just behind the optical cable, wherever you feel most comfortable (Image 2) Repeat for the other side Your cover should wiggle freely, it should  move up and down

Lines.Text: your aim is to grip the top of the cover with both hands using thumb and finger ( s )
you need to pull the cover up to the fixed plastic casing ( with the force required the plastic casing bends but did not break )
while pulling upwards , you need to be pulling towards your body and using your little fingers pushing outwards on the sides of the printhead tray carrier while tilting the cover
you may hear creaking of the plastics , but with patience and firm but gentle persuasion you should end up with the top of the plastic cover sat on the fixed case ( image 1 )
you need to then work the sides out carefully ( image 2 ) using the flat bladed screwdriver for assistance if required while pulling up so the tabs don't get snapped at the bottom of the part
if successful , you will have the cover off ( image 3 )
note the tabs ( image 3 red arrows ) and the best spots to place your thumbs/fingers ( image 3 green arrows )

Steps.Text_raw: Your aim is to grip the top of the cover with both hands using thumb and finger(s) You need to pull the cover up to the fixed plastic casing (with the force required the plastic casing bends but did not break) While pulling upwards, you need to be pulling towards your body and using your little fingers pushing outwards on the sides of the printhead tray carrier while tilting the cover You may hear creaking of the plastics, but with patience and firm but gentle persuasion you should end up with the top of the plastic cover sat on the fixed case (Image 1) You need to then work the sides out carefully (Image 2) using the flat bladed screw driver for assistance if required while pulling up so the tabs don't get snapped at the bottom of the part If successful, you will have the cover off (Image 3) Note the tabs (Image 3 red arrows) and the best spots to place your thumbs/fingers (Image 3 green arrows)

Lines.Text: warning ! lift out the optical cable from the clear plastic sensor on the back of the circuit board ( top right ) before attempting to move the board ( image 1 )
the circuit board should slide forward and up past the grey sprung catch ( image 1 ) to reveal the back of the board and the socket without it's ribbon ( image 2 pink arrow )
now its time to get the ribbon cable in side the housing ( image 2 orange arrow ) . look on the left of the housing and find the vertical slot . ( image 3 )
feed the ribbon cable in with the metallic strips/pins facing away from you
if you succeeded you should see the metallic strips/pins facing you when the ribbon naturally flexes ( image 2 )

Steps.Text_raw: Warning! Lift out the optical cable from the clear plastic sensor on the back of the circuit board (top right) before attempting to move the board (Image 1) The circuit board should slide forward and up past the grey sprung catch (Image 1) to reveal the back of the board and the socket without it's ribbon (Image 2 pink arrow) Now its time to get the ribbon cable in side the housing (Image 2 orange arrow). Look on the left of the housing and find the vertical slot. (Image 3) Feed the ribbon cable in with the metallic strips/pins facing away from you If you succeeded you should see the metallic strips/pins facing you when the ribbon naturally flexes (Image 2)

Lines.Text: lift the brown holding tab up on the connector ( image 1 orange arrows )
the ribbon only has writing on one side , that side needs to face towards the clear plastic sensor on the other end of the board

feed it into the connector and while holding it in place with your finger and thumb in the centre of the ribbon cable , push each side of the brown connector tab down until the connector grips the ribbon cable

you should notice the tops of the metallic strips/pins stuck out the top of the connector should be uniform ( image 2 ) . if you have put it in incorrectly , then there will be more of the strips/pins showing at one end or the strips will not be visible because it is in backwards

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the brown holding tab up on the connector (Image 1 orange arrows) The ribbon only has writing on one side, that side needs to face towards the clear plastic sensor on the other end of the board Feed it into the connector and while holding it in place with your finger and thumb in the centre of the ribbon cable, push each side of the brown connector tab down until the  connector grips the ribbon cable You should notice the tops of the metallic strips/pins stuck out the top of the connector should be uniform (Image 2). If you have put it in incorrectly, then there will be more of the strips/pins showing at one end or the strips will not be visible because it is in backwards

Lines.Text: you now need to feed any excess ribbon out as you push the circuit board back into place , being sure to lift the grey sprung catch to allow the board to go far enough back to sink down slightly

now is the time to re-seat the optical cable ( image 2 green ) behind the top right of the board . note it sits in between the clear plastic reader ( image 2 orange arrow ) in a groove ( image 2 red depth indicators )
now you need to line up the screw holes ( image 3 blue arrows ) by persuading the board down and slightly backwards . you might need to push the red and white wires backwards ( image 3 yellow arrow )
warning ! failure to do this before replacing the plastic case will prevent screws securing the printhead casing and circuit board

Steps.Text_raw: You now need to feed any excess ribbon out as you push the circuit board back into place, being sure to lift the grey sprung catch to allow the board to go far enough back to sink down slightly Now is the time to re-seat the optical cable (Image 2 green) behind the top right of the board. Note it sits in between the clear plastic reader (Image 2 orange arrow) in a groove (Image 2 red depth indicators) Now you need to line up the screw holes (Image 3 blue arrows) by persuading the board down and slightly backwards. You might need to push the red and white wires backwards (Image 3 yellow arrow) Warning! Failure to do this before replacing the plastic case will prevent screws securing the printhead casing and circuit board

Lines.Text: replacing the plastic casing is a reverse of the removal - the big flat top under the fixed plastic casing first ( image 1 red ) , then lifting up and pushing back until the lugs are in towards the bottom
you might find it easier to apply gentle outward pressure to the side of the printhead cartridge carrier tray ( image 1 orange depth markers )
i found it easier once i had the section of the cover ( image 2 yellow arrows ) higher than the pin pad ( image 2 blue depth marker ) to push it backwards

if you get the lugs in at the bottom and the top flat section of the cover is aligned and close to the fixed printhead ( image 3 ) , now is the time to check the optical cable has not been disturbed . it should be vertical and the print head should not have any problems sliding side to side
finally replace the screws ( image 3 orange ) and you are finished with the cover

Steps.Text_raw: Replacing the plastic casing is a reverse of the removal - the big flat top under the fixed plastic casing first (Image 1 red), then lifting up and pushing back until the lugs are in towards the bottom You might find it easier to apply gentle outward pressure to the side of the printhead cartridge carrier tray (Image 1 orange depth markers) I found it easier once I had the section of the cover (Image 2 yellow arrows) higher than the pin pad (Image 2 blue depth marker) to push it backwards If you get the lugs in at the bottom and the top flat section of the cover is aligned and close to the fixed printhead (Image 3), now is the time to check the optical cable has not been disturbed. It should be vertical and the print head should not have any problems sliding side to side Finally replace the screws (Image 3 orange) and you are finished with the cover

Lines.Text: all that is left is to replace the printhead cartridge carrier tray ensuring you push against the white label ( image 1 orange arrow ) until it clicks under the grey sprung catch ( image 1 red ) and then replace the cartridges ( image 2 ) as normal ensuring they also click into place
you can now move the assembly all the way to the right to park it
close the printer lid
restore power and test it moves at the request of the printer during start up sequence

Steps.Text_raw: All that is left is to replace the printhead cartridge carrier tray ensuring you push against the white label (Image 1 orange arrow) until it clicks under the grey sprung catch (Image 1 red) and then replace the  cartridges (Image 2) as normal ensuring they also click into place You can now move the assembly all the way to the right to park it Close the printer lid Restore power and test it moves at the request of the printer during start up sequence

Title: Linksys EA6900 USB Ports Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the antennas by unscrewing them from the base .
flip over the device and locate the four rubber feet on the bottom .
remove the rubber feet with tweezers

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the antennas by unscrewing them from the base. Flip over the device and locate the four rubber feet on the bottom. Remove the rubber feet with tweezers

Lines.Text: remove the 0.4cm head screws from each slot with the 1 phillips head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 0.4cm head screws from each slot with the #1 Phillips head Screwdriver.

Lines.Text: use a blue plastic opening tool to remove the top cover .
move the blue plastic opening tool gently underneath the top cover from side to side .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a blue plastic opening tool to remove the top cover. Move the blue plastic opening tool gently underneath the top cover from side to side.

Lines.Text: gently lift the motherboard and remove it from the case
put the motherboard over a ( preferably white ) surface .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift the motherboard and remove it from the case Put the motherboard over a (preferably white) surface.

Lines.Text: locate the usb ports on both sides of the router motherboard . there are six points on the reverse side where the usb ports are soldered onto .
apply the soldering iron carefully to the six points to melt to solder . touching the motherboard with the solder can damage the circuits .
be careful with using the soldering iron , it is hot !
after the solder has melted and been removed , gently pry the usb port with a black spudger to separate it from the motherboard .
confirm that all of the old solder has been removed after the usb port is detached from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the USB ports on both sides of the router motherboard. There are six points on the reverse side where the USB ports are soldered onto. Apply the soldering iron carefully to the six points to melt to solder. Touching the motherboard with the solder can damage the circuits. Be careful with using the soldering iron, it is hot! After the solder has melted and been removed, gently pry the USB port with a black spudger to separate it from the motherboard. Confirm that all of the old solder has been removed after the USB port is detached from the motherboard.

Subject: USB Ports

Title: ASUS VG248 Disassembly

Lines.Text: before you begin , lay the monitor face down on a smooth , clean surface .
four rubbery covers hide four screws in the rear of the monitor .
pry out the plastic covers with a stiff pointed tool , like a metal spudger .

Steps.Text_raw: Before you begin, lay the monitor face down on a smooth, clean surface. Four rubbery covers hide four screws in the rear of the monitor. Pry out the plastic covers with a stiff pointed tool, like a metal spudger.

Lines.Text: remove the four 13.4 mm phillips 1 screws securing the monitor stand .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 13.4 mm Philips #1 screws securing the monitor stand.

Lines.Text: remove the stand from the display .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the stand from the display.

Lines.Text: the display bezel is held to the rear case by plastic clips that can be released by pulling straight up on the bezel .
rather than use any prying tools that could damage the lcd , it's best to just pull with your fingers . a thin cloth will both protect your fingertips and prevent you from smudging the lcd .
lay the cloth over one of the long edges of the display .
grip the side of the bezel through the cloth and lift straight up . a few clips in the center will pop free .
be careful to pull straight up , and not pry against the display . pushing down on the display could damage it .

Steps.Text_raw: The display bezel is held to the rear case by plastic clips that can be released by pulling straight up on the bezel. Rather than use any prying tools that could damage the LCD, it's best to just pull with your fingers. A thin cloth will both protect your fingertips and prevent you from smudging the LCD. Lay the cloth over one of the long edges of the display. Grip the side of the bezel through the cloth and lift straight up. A few clips in the center will pop free. Be careful to pull straight up, and not pry against the display. Pushing down on the display could damage it.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure around the display , lifting up the center of the next side .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure around the display, lifting up the center of the next side.

Lines.Text: move around to the other long side and lift up on the center of the bezel .

Steps.Text_raw: Move around to the other long side and lift up on the center of the bezel.

Lines.Text: grip the center of the final side and lift the bezel away from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Grip the center of the final side and lift the bezel away from the rear case.

Lines.Text: now that you've freed the centers of the four sides , it's time to move on to the corners .
each corner is secured by two large clips that can't be freed by just pulling straight up like you did with the sides .
in the next step , you'll be pushing in on the corner clip on the left of the bottom edge of the bezel .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that you've freed the centers of the four sides, it's time to move on to the corners. Each corner is secured by two large clips that can't be freed by just pulling straight up like you did with the sides. In the next step, you'll be pushing in on the corner clip on the left of the bottom edge of the bezel.

Lines.Text: using a thin stiff prying device , like a press in against the bottom clip in the lower left corner ( beneath the hdmi logo ) .
while pressing the clip in , pull up on the lower edge of the bezel . the entire corner should pop free .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a thin stiff prying device, like a [https://www.ifixit.com/Store/Tools/Jimmy/IF145-259|Jimmy|new_window=true], press in against the bottom clip in the lower left corner (beneath the HDMI logo). While pressing the clip in, pull up on the lower edge of the bezel. The entire corner should pop free.

Lines.Text: once you've freed one corner , you should be able to gently twist the bezel off , freeing all of the remaining corners .
if any corners are particularly stubborn , repeat the previous step on the difficult corner .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you've freed one corner, you should be able to gently twist the bezel off, freeing all of the remaining corners. If any corners are particularly stubborn, repeat the previous step on the difficult corner.

Lines.Text: remove the bezel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bezel.

Lines.Text: lift the lcd out of the rear case .
the row of adjustment buttons will come out of the case with the display , attached by a thin ribbon cable . take care not to damage the cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the LCD out of the rear case. The row of adjustment buttons will come out of the case with the display, attached by a thin ribbon cable. Take care not to damage the cable.

Lines.Text: with the casing removed , you now have access to the button board , cables , and the housing over the motherboard components .

Steps.Text_raw: With the casing removed, you now have access to the button board, cables, and the housing over the motherboard components.

Lines.Text: when cleaning : do not spill distilled or orher water on the pcb , clean arround with cotton swabs . use the syringe with distilled water , spill it over the print head and clean with the swabs .

after cleaning : let it dry for a couple of hours .
if you spilled some water to the pcb : instantly clean the pcb with isopropyl alcohol .
in the last picture you see 3 or 4 black spots in the water . that where little grains of hard dry ink . . and causing my printing problem . . .

a spudger like object is helpful for pushing in the tabs if the fan is not removed also

Title: Razer Naga Epic Chroma Scroll Wheel Replacement

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the cords connecting the scroll wheel with the circuit board.

keep pulling this tab gently towards the battery mount until the scroll wheel has been removed .

Title: Razer Naga Epic Chroma Side Button Connection Strip Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the four screws with the phillips head 00 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws with the Phillips head #00 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: gently pull on the top plastic plate of the device and carefully unplug the white cord from the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull on the top plastic plate of the device and carefully unplug the white cord from the circuit board.

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull up on the two side plastic plates.

Lines.Text: take a plastic spudger and gently pry the battery pack from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Take a plastic spudger and gently pry the battery pack from the device.

Lines.Text: unplug the power cord from the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the power cord from the circuit board.

Lines.Text: plug the cord of the new battery into the socket on the bottom right of the circuit board .

remove the battery mount .

Title: Razer Naga Epic Chroma Tracking Sensor Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the teflon tape from the bottom of the mouse with a spudger .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the teflon tape from the bottom of the mouse with a spudger.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws with the phillips head 00 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws with the Phillips head #00 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: gently pull on the top plastic plate of the device and carefully unplug the white cord from the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull on the top plastic plate of the device and carefully unplug the white cord from the circuit board.

Lines.Text: gently pull up on the two side plastic plates .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull up on the two side plastic plates.

Lines.Text: take a plastic spudger and gently pry the battery pack from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Take a plastic spudger and gently pry the battery pack from the device.

Lines.Text: unplug the power cord from the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the power cord from the circuit board.

Lines.Text: plug the cord of the new battery into the socket on the bottom right of the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Plug the cord of the new battery into the socket on the bottom right of the circuit board.

Lines.Text: remove the two screws holding the battery mount in place and remove the mount from the mouse .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws holding the battery mount in place and remove the mount from the mouse.

Lines.Text: disconnect the white connection strip from the white connection port on the circuit board .
disconnect the usb cable ( the cable is located on the right and center of the circuit board ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the white connection strip from the white connection port on the circuit board. Disconnect the USB cable (the cable is located on the right and center of the circuit board).

Lines.Text: remove the two screws that were on either side of the battery mount . this will allow the circuit board to be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws that were on either side of the battery mount. This will allow the circuit board to be removed.

Lines.Text: remove the circuit board and turn it over to its underside .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the circuit board and turn it over to its underside.

Lines.Text: around the yellow sensor , located in the middle of the back of the circuit board , locate the eleven leads ( soldered connections ) surrounding the yellow sensor .

Steps.Text_raw: Around the yellow sensor, located in the middle of the back of the circuit board, locate the eleven "leads" (soldered connections) surrounding the yellow sensor.

Lines.Text: re-solder all eleven leads to the connection points of the sensor .
this should fix the problem with the mouse sensor tracking issues .
for soldering tips , refer to guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Re-solder all eleven leads to the connection points of the sensor. This should fix the problem with the mouse sensor tracking issues. For soldering tips, refer to [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|this guide].

Subject: Tracking Sensor

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the gel membrane.

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two silver 4.0 mm Phillips #1 screws and the three black 6.5 mm Phillips #1 screws holding the silicone sheets.

Lines.Text: remove the sheets .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the sheets.

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew  the two silver 4.5 mm Phillips #1 screws and the seven 5.0 mm Phillips #1 screws that deter the plastic panel from removal.

Lines.Text: remove the plastic panel and the white sheet .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plastic panel and the white sheet.

Lines.Text: unplug the wires connected to the leds .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the wires connected to the LEDs.

Lines.Text: remove the leds .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the LEDs.

turn the mouse over so the bottom is facing up .

Lines.Text: use a phillips 0 screwdriver to remove two 6.7 mm screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #0 screwdriver to remove two 6.7 mm screws.

clear the label away from around the screw for easier removal .

separate the top casing from the bottom base by pulling the top casing upwards .
separating the casing too quickly could damage the ribbon connector between the motherboard and the led lights .

Title: Pacific Image Electronics CS3600 Bulb Panel Replacement

Lines.Text: start by removing the 5 screws that are 5 mm x 9 mm located on the bottom of the device with a j1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Start by removing the 5 screws that are 5mm x 9mm located on the bottom of the device with a J1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: now that the screws have been removed , carefully but firmly open up the device at the seam until it is presented as shown .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the screws have been removed, carefully but firmly open up the device at the seam until it is presented as shown.

Lines.Text: use a j0 screwdriver to remove the following four screws that are 5 mm x 9 mm .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a J0 screwdriver to remove the following four screws that are 5mm x 9mm.

Lines.Text: use the same j0 screwdriver to remove the following 3 screws that are 7 mm x 6 mm .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the same J0 screwdriver to remove the following 3 screws that are 7mm x 6mm.

Lines.Text: now grab the plastic cover you just removed screws from and gently remove it from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Now grab the plastic cover you just removed screws from and gently remove it from the device.

Lines.Text: you may now pick up the plastic covering you removed screws from in step 3 with ease revealing the bulb .

Steps.Text_raw: You may now pick up the plastic covering you removed screws from in Step 3 with ease revealing the bulb.

Lines.Text: lodge the plastic opening tool underneath the bulb casing . using some upward force , pop the bulb off the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Lodge the plastic opening tool underneath the bulb casing. Using some upward  force,  pop the bulb off the casing.

Lines.Text: you have now removed the bulb from the casing . gently pull the wires forward and prepare a soldering station .

Steps.Text_raw: You have now removed the bulb from the casing. Gently pull the wires forward and prepare a soldering station.

Lines.Text: carefully desolder the 2 wires from their solder contact points to detach the bulb panel from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully desolder the 2 wires from their solder contact points to detach the bulb panel from the motherboard.

Subject: Bulb Panel

turn the mouse over so the bottom is facing up .

clear the label away from around the screw for easier removal .

separate the top casing from the bottom base by pulling the top casing upwards .
separating the casing too quickly could damage the ribbon connector between the motherboard and the led lights .

Title: Logitech G502 Proteus Core Scroll Wheel Replacement

Lines.Text: flip the mouse over to access the feet .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the mouse over to access the feet.

Lines.Text: use your fingers or a nylon spudger to remove the specified mouse feet in order to reveal the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your fingers or a nylon spudger to remove the specified mouse feet in order to reveal the screws.

Lines.Text: use a 00 phillips screw bit to remove the indicated 12.5 mm screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a #00 Philips screw bit to remove the indicated 12.5mm screws.

Lines.Text: use a nylon spudger to pry the top shell from the bottom of the mouse .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a nylon spudger to pry the top shell from the bottom of the mouse.

Lines.Text: use a nylon spudger to push the fastener pin free .
be careful not to lose two springs near the front of the mouse underneath the wheel housing . place them aside safely .

Lines.Text: once the pin is removed , use a 00 phillips screw bit to remove the 7.5 mm screw from the scroll wheel holder .
once the plastic scroll wheel holder is off , the scroll wheel is free and can be lifted out .

Title: Logitech Anywhere Mouse MX Full Disassembly

Lines.Text: some earlier variants of the anywhere mouse have a matte finish on the buttons . it is unknown if the internal construction differs from this later , shiny button version .

Steps.Text_raw: Some earlier variants of the Anywhere Mouse have a matte finish on the buttons. It is unknown if the internal construction differs from this later, shiny button version.

Lines.Text: open the battery cover and remove the batteries .

Steps.Text_raw: Open the battery cover and remove the batteries.

Lines.Text: use the blade to pry beneath the feet of the mouse and remove them . be careful not to excessively bend the feet as they easily deform from their original flat shape .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the blade to pry beneath the feet of the mouse and remove them. Be careful not to excessively bend the feet as they easily deform from their original flat shape.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws circled in red .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws circled in red.

Lines.Text: pry open the mouse using a plastic blade or spudger . the top shell of the mouse should come off relatively easily as there are no clips to disengage between the two halves .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry open the mouse using a plastic blade or spudger. The top shell of the mouse should come off relatively easily as there are no clips to disengage between the two halves.

Lines.Text: disconnect the orange ribbon cable by carefully pulling the white locking bar horizontally out from the socket . the ribbon cable should then easily slip out of the unlocked socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the orange ribbon cable by carefully pulling the white locking bar horizontally out from the socket. The ribbon cable should then easily slip out of the unlocked socket.

Lines.Text: disconnect the white ribbon cable by flipping the white retention lever up . the ribbon cable should then easily slip out of the unlocked socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the white ribbon cable by flipping the white retention lever up. The ribbon cable should then easily slip out of the unlocked socket.

Lines.Text: remove the back/forward button board from its holder on the case of the mouse by carefully pulling back on the two retention clips and sliding the board out .
be careful not to pull hard on the board once it is removed from its holder as the ribbon cable connecting this board to the main board is soldered and does not have a removable connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the back/forward button board from its holder on the case of the mouse by carefully pulling back on the two retention clips and sliding the board out. Be careful not to pull hard on the board once it is removed from its holder as the ribbon cable connecting this board to the main board is soldered and does not have a removable connector.

Lines.Text: remove the six screws from the locations circled in red .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six screws from the locations circled in red.

Lines.Text: pull gently on the rear battery contacts to slide them out of their held location in the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull gently on the rear battery contacts to slide them out of their held location in the casing.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two screws marked in yellow . this will allow you to remove the unifying receiver storage holder .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two screws marked in yellow. This will allow you to remove the Unifying receiver storage holder.

Lines.Text: remove the two screws from the locations circled in red . this will allow you to remove the power switch board .
be careful not to pull hard on the board once it is removed from its holder as the ribbon cable connecting this board to the main board is soldered and does not have a removable connector .

once the power switch circuit board is unscrewed , a small plastic piece can then fall out of the casing . this piece serves to press down on the power switch when the lens cover of the mouse is closed .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws from the locations circled in red. This will allow you to remove the power switch board. Be careful not to pull hard on the board once it is removed from its holder as the ribbon cable connecting this board to the main board is soldered and does not have a removable connector. Once the power switch circuit board is unscrewed, a small plastic piece can then fall out of the casing. This piece serves to press down on the power switch when the lens cover of the mouse is closed.

Lines.Text: if the plastic piece fell out , this is how it should be positioned when reassembling the mouse . the plastic piece is marked in blue .

Steps.Text_raw: If the plastic piece fell out, this is how it should be positioned when reassembling the mouse. The plastic piece is marked in blue.

Lines.Text: with the power switch board unscrewed , you should now be able to flip the main board upwards .
unscrew the two screws indicated in red .
the retaining bridge should now easily come off .

Steps.Text_raw: With the power switch board unscrewed, you should now be able to flip the main board upwards. Unscrew the two screws indicated in red. The retaining bridge should now easily come off.

Lines.Text: remove the screw circled in red .
the scroll wheel assembly can now be lifted upwards and removed from the mouse .
the black plastic piece where the screw removed in this step is located is spring loaded and can fall out of the scroll wheel assembly . be sure not to lose this piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the screw circled in red. The scroll wheel assembly can now be lifted upwards and removed from the mouse. The black plastic piece where the screw removed in this step is located is spring loaded and can fall out of the scroll wheel assembly. Be sure not to lose this piece.

Lines.Text: if the black plastic piece has fallen out of the scroll wheel assembly , it should be oriented like this when reassembled .
the plastic piece has a small peg that inserts into a spring-loaded hole in the scroll wheel assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: If the black plastic piece has fallen out of the scroll wheel assembly, it should be oriented like this when reassembled. The plastic piece has a small peg that inserts into a spring-loaded hole in the scroll wheel assembly.

Lines.Text: remove the screws from the three locations circled in red .
the left/right button board can now be easily removed from the mouse casing .
the two main microswitches are indicated in blue .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the screws from the three locations circled in red. The left/right button board can now be easily removed from the mouse casing. The two main microswitches are indicated in blue.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws circled in red . the sensor assembly can then be easily removed by pulling it up and out of the casing .
now you can clean the lens of the mouse . the sensor itself is permanently attached to the lens however .
this particular sensor integrates the infrared laser diodes in the same package . it is rated at a sensitivity of 1000 dpi .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws circled in red. The sensor assembly can then be easily removed by pulling it up and out of the casing. Now you can clean the lens of the mouse. The sensor itself is permanently attached to the lens however. This particular sensor integrates the infrared laser diodes in the same package. It is rated at a sensitivity of 1000 DPI.

Lines.Text: the mouse is now fully disassembled . the main circuit board was not removed from the casing as it was not necessary to access the sensor and remove all other parts of the mouse .
the major parts of the mouse are visible in the first two images of this step .
here is a shot of the bottom of the main circuit board . the power switch circuit board is indicated in red while the mouse's microprocessor is indicated in blue .

Steps.Text_raw: The mouse is now fully disassembled. The main circuit board was not removed from the casing as it was not necessary to access the sensor and remove all other parts of the mouse. The major parts of the mouse are visible in the first two images of this step. Here is a shot of the bottom of the main circuit board. The power switch circuit board is indicated in red while the mouse's microprocessor is indicated in blue.

Title: Logitech Wireless Gaming Mouse G700 Left/Right Click Button Replacement

Lines.Text: this is my trusty ole logitech g700. i've had it for a good 7 years at the time of writing this guide ! it's about time the switch has died .

Steps.Text_raw: This is my trusty ole Logitech G700. I've had it for a good 7 years at the time of writing this guide! It's about time the switch has died.

Lines.Text: start by turning off the mouse and removing the back battery cover and battery of the mouse .
then remove the teflon feet of the mouse to get to the five ( 5 ) screws that hold the top and bottom of the parts of the mouse together .

if you want to keep the stickers reusable , consider only peeling back the amount you need to get at the screw . anymore will increase the risk of the glue sticking to the body of the mouse rendering the sticker feeling bumpy and will cause the mouse to track unevenly .
if you are using brand new stickers , make sure you clean off any excess glue . i found using the glue stuck to the peeled off sticker extremely useful at peeling off the remaining glue .

Steps.Text_raw: Start by turning off the mouse and removing the back battery cover and battery of the mouse. Then remove the teflon "feet" of the mouse to get to the five (5) screws that hold the top and bottom of the parts of the mouse together. If you want to keep the stickers reusable, consider only peeling back the amount you need to get at the screw. Anymore will increase the risk of the glue sticking to the body of the mouse rendering the sticker feeling bumpy and will cause the mouse to track unevenly. If you are using brand new stickers, make sure you clean off any excess glue. I found using the glue stuck to the peeled off sticker extremely useful at peeling off the remaining glue.

Lines.Text: use a small 2 or 3 mm screwdriver to take out the five screws at the bottom .
keep the screws in a safe place !

the top and bottom shells of the mouse should open up fairly easily . if not , poke a spludger or guitar pick or even just your fingernail into the split between the shiny and matte plastic and the shell should pop right off .
when the top shell comes apart , be careful not to pull too hard as there is a connection wire that connects the side buttons to the upper pcb !

Steps.Text_raw: Use a small 2 or 3mm screw driver to take out the five screws at the bottom. Keep the screws in a safe place! The top and bottom shells of the mouse should open up fairly easily. If not, poke a spludger or guitar pick or even just your fingernail into the split between the shiny and matte plastic and the shell should pop right off. When the top shell comes apart, be careful not to pull too hard as there is a connection wire that connects the side buttons to the upper PCB!

Lines.Text: the side button cluster connection cable can be a little tough to disconnect . the socket on mine was really tight but just wiggle the brown connector a little and it should come off .

Steps.Text_raw: The side button cluster connection cable can be a little tough to disconnect. The socket on mine was REALLY tight but just wiggle the brown connector a little and it should come off.

Lines.Text: '''warning : be careful in this section . there are two almost microscopic springs that are part of the mouse wheel . do not turn the mouse up side down after removing the locking pin or you will lose them . '''
rotate the free spin activation arm up ( as can be seen in the first picture ) .
make a note of the orientation of the locking pin , curved section facing down and slide it out of the socket ( as can be seen in second picture ) .
once the locking pin has been taken out , the entire mouse wheel should lift out of it's resting cradle . make sure you note the springs ( can be seen in the third picture ) .

'''do not lose these springs as they serve to give your middle mouse click that bounce . they are almost impossible to find if dropped . ( yes i did drop mine and i found them again through sheer dumb luck ) '''
'''store locking pin and springs in a safe location . '''

Steps.Text_raw: '''WARNING: Be careful in this section. There are two almost microscopic springs that are part of the mouse wheel. Do NOT turn the mouse up side down after removing the locking pin or you will LOSE them.''' Rotate the free spin activation arm up (as can be seen in the first picture). Make a note of the orientation of the locking pin, curved section facing down and slide it out of the socket (as can be seen in second picture). Once the locking pin has been taken out, the entire mouse wheel should lift out of it's resting cradle. Make sure you note the springs (can be seen in the third picture). '''Do not lose these springs as they serve to give your middle mouse click that "bounce". They are almost impossible to find if dropped. (Yes I did drop mine and I found them again through sheer dumb luck)''' '''Store locking pin and springs in a safe location.'''

Lines.Text: there are four screws to remove here . two screws are next to where you found the springs and another two that fixes the mouse wheel structure to the upper pcb .
second picture shows the springs . . . '''don't lose them ! '''

Steps.Text_raw: There are four screws to remove here. Two screws are next to where you found the springs and another two that fixes the mouse wheel structure to the upper PCB. Second picture shows the springs... '''Don't lose them!'''

Lines.Text: with the screws taken off from the upper pcb , it's time to desolder the connecting pins that connect the upper pcb to power pcb . my preferred method was to use a desoldering braid but i think a solder sucker works too .
careful not to let your soldering iron touch the plastic ribbon cable or the upper shell connector ( white in the first photo ) . you can see i did singe my ribbon cable a little bit haha . . .
once you've removed the solder from all the pins , you should be able to lift the upper pcb off easily .

Steps.Text_raw: With the screws taken off from the upper PCB, it's time to desolder the connecting pins that connect the upper PCB to power PCB. My preferred method was to use a desoldering braid but I think a solder sucker works too. Careful not to let your soldering iron touch the plastic ribbon cable or the upper shell connector (white in the first photo). You can see I did singe my ribbon cable a little bit haha... Once you've removed the solder from all the pins, you should be able to lift the upper PCB off easily.

Lines.Text: with the upper pcb removed , you can now flip it upside down and desolder the omron switch . ( make a note of which way the switch is facing ! )
clean off any excess solder from the component mounting point of the omron switch .
mount new switch on with the white click button facing the same direction as the old switch .
it's okay to burn the switch a little ( since it's dead anyways right ? ) but try not to let the soldering iron touch any of the other solder points when soldering/desoldering the new/old switch .

Steps.Text_raw: With the upper PCB removed, you can now flip it upside down and desolder the Omron Switch. (Make a note of which way the switch is facing!) Clean off any excess solder from the component mounting point of the Omron switch. Mount new switch on with the white click button facing the same direction as the old switch. It's okay to burn the switch a little (since it's dead anyways right?) but try not to let the soldering iron touch any of the other solder points when soldering/desoldering the new/old switch.

Lines.Text: remount and resolder the upper pcb then connect your mouse to the computer and check that it still functions .
tip : you don't need to reassemble the entire mouse to ensure that the new omron switch is working . just connect the usb cable and try clicking with the replaced switch !
once everything is confirmed working , reassemble and reconnect everything you took out and you'll have a working mouse again ! : d

Steps.Text_raw: Remount and resolder the upper PCB then connect your mouse to the computer and check that it still functions. Tip: You don't need to reassemble the entire mouse to ensure that the new Omron switch is working. Just connect the USB cable and try clicking with the replaced switch! Once everything is confirmed working, reassemble and reconnect everything you took out and you'll have a working mouse again! :D

Subject: Left/Right Click Button

Title: HTC Vive Outer Sheath Replacement

Lines.Text: slide the htc panel covering the cables forward , away from the vive .
gently pull on each of the four connectors to remove the sound and three-in-one cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the HTC panel covering the cables forward, away from the Vive. Gently pull on each of the four connectors to remove the sound and Three-in-One cables.

Lines.Text: undo the hook and loop tape on the straps .
slide the ends of the straps through the hinge loops .

Steps.Text_raw: Undo the hook and loop tape on the straps. Slide the ends of the straps through the hinge loops.

Lines.Text: pull the facerest cushion off away from the vive , separating the hook and loop tape .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the facerest cushion off away from the Vive, separating the hook and loop tape.

Lines.Text: use a t6 torx screwdriver to remove either of the two 12 mm hinge screws holding the two hinges in place .
allow the hinge to fall away once the screw is removed .
repeat for the opposite side .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a T6 Torx Screwdriver to remove  either of the two 12mm hinge screws holding the two hinges in place. Allow the hinge to fall away once the screw is removed. Repeat for the opposite side.

Lines.Text: slide the plastic facerest away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the plastic facerest away from the device.

Lines.Text: orient the vive so that the camera is facing towards you and the connector ports are facing upwards , as in the photos .
use a plastic opening tool to gently pry up the left side of the outer sheath .
if the left sheath is glued down , slide your plastic opening tool along the middle seam to break the bond .
slide the left side of the sheath outwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Orient the Vive so that the camera is facing towards you and the connector ports are facing upwards, as in the photos. Use a plastic opening tool to gently pry up the left side of the outer sheath. If the left sheath is glued down, slide your plastic opening tool along the middle seam to break the bond. Slide the left side of the sheath outwards.

Lines.Text: slide a plastic opening tool underneath the right side of the sheath to remove any remaining glue .
using the plastic opening tool , pry the right side of the sheath upwards slightly .
using your hands , slide the right side of the sheath outwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide a plastic opening tool underneath the right side of the sheath to remove any remaining glue. Using the plastic opening tool, pry the right side of the sheath upwards slightly. Using your hands, slide the right side of the sheath outwards.

Subject: Outer Shell

Lines.Text: remove the five 4 mm phillips 00 screws holding the sensor array to the motherboard .
remove the two 4 mm phillips 00 screws holding the sensor array to the midframe .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the five 4mm Philips #00 screws holding the sensor array to the motherboard. Remove the two 4mm Philips #00 screws holding the sensor array to the midframe.

Lines.Text: using a pair of esd safe tweezers , gently pull the four ribbon cables out horizontally from the sensor array .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a pair of ESD safe tweezers, gently pull the four ribbon cables out horizontally from the sensor array.

Lines.Text: be careful not to lift the sensor array too far from the rest of the device because the camera ribbon cable may tear .
lift the sensor array away from the rest of the vive until the camera cable tugs back and hold it in place .
the camera ribbon cable must be pulled out of its socket vertically , as opposed to all other ribbon cables which slide out horizontally .
disconnect the camera by lifting its ribbon cable up and away from the motherboard using a pair of esd safe tweezers .
lift the sensor array upwards away from the motherboard to separate the array from the device fully .

Steps.Text_raw: Be careful not to lift the sensor array too far from the rest of the device because the camera ribbon cable may tear. Lift the sensor array away from the rest of the Vive until the camera cable tugs back and hold it in place. The camera ribbon cable must be pulled out of its socket vertically, as opposed to all other ribbon cables which slide out horizontally. Disconnect the camera by lifting its ribbon cable up and away from the motherboard using a pair of ESD safe tweezers. Lift the sensor array upwards away from the motherboard to separate the array from the device fully.

Lines.Text: for the ribbon cable , lift the tab from the side facing the inside of the mother board with your fingernail or a spudger .
remove the cable by pulling while lifting slightly .
if the cable does not come out easily , than the secure tab may not be fully opened .

Steps.Text_raw: For the ribbon cable, Lift the tab from the side facing the inside of the mother board with your fingernail or a spudger. Remove the cable by pulling while lifting slightly. If the cable does not come out easily, than the secure tab may not be fully opened.

Lines.Text: remove each of the 5 mm length screws attaching the motherboard to the body of the monitor using a 1 phillips head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove each of the 5mm length screws attaching the motherboard to the body of the monitor using a #1 Phillips head screwdriver.

Lines.Text: using both hands , lift the board off of the monitor body by the motherboards base .

Steps.Text_raw: Using both hands, lift the board off of the monitor body by the motherboards base.

Lines.Text: gently place the motherboard on a static free surface .
it is imperative that this is done on a static free surface , as any discharge of static electricity can 'fry' your motherboard and render it useless .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently place the motherboard on a static free surface. It is imperative that this is done on a static free surface, as any discharge of static electricity can 'fry' your motherboard and render it useless.

Lines.Text: each of the indicated leads located on the back of the motherboard .
the hdmi port should fall off of the board after all solder is removed .

Steps.Text_raw: [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|Desolder] each of the indicated leads located on the back of the motherboard. The HDMI Port should fall off of the board after all solder is removed.

Lines.Text: if the hdmi port does not fall off the motherboard , try tugging it with your hand .
the hdmi port may be too hot to touch right after desoldering .
excessive tugging ccould damage the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: If the HDMI Port does not fall off the motherboard, try tugging it with your hand. The HDMI Port may be too hot to touch right after desoldering. Excessive tugging ccould damage the motherboard.

Subject: HDMI Port

Title: Logitech Harmony Smart Keyboard Back Panel

Lines.Text: turn keyboard over to the backside .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn keyboard over to the  backside.

Lines.Text: press and slide up on the upper battery latch , using both thumbs .

Steps.Text_raw: Press and slide up on the upper battery latch, using both thumbs.

Lines.Text: remove the two aa batteries and set them aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two AA batteries and set them aside.

Lines.Text: unscrew all five 4.0 mm screws , using phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew all five 4.0 mm screws, using Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: peel off the center sticker to reveal two hidden 4.0 mm screws .
unscrew these two screws with a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel off the center sticker to reveal two hidden 4.0 mm screws. Unscrew these two screws with a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift both top left and top right rubber stickers halfway , using the sharp end of the plastic spudger .
unscrew a total of two 4.0 mm screws , under the rubber stickers , using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift both top left and top right rubber stickers halfway, using the sharp end of the plastic spudger. Unscrew a total of two 4.0 mm screws, under the rubber stickers,  using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: unscrew the top center 4.0 mm screw , in the battery compartment , using the phillips 1 screwdriver .
now , you should have a total of ten 4.0 mm screws set aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the top center 4.0 mm screw, in the battery compartment, using the Phillips  #1 screwdriver. Now, you should have a total of ten 4.0 mm screws set aside.

Lines.Text: wedge the flat end of the spudger between the back panel and front panel .
slide the flat end of the spudger from right to left to pry the two panels apart .

Steps.Text_raw: Wedge the flat end of the spudger between the back panel and front panel. Slide the flat end of the spudger from right to left to pry the two panels apart.

Lines.Text: separate the back panel from the front panel completely , using both hands .
a white ribbon flex cable will remain connected to both panels .
pull the panels apart slowly and gently , or the white ribbon flex cable may be unsafely removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the back panel from the front panel completely, using both hands. A white ribbon flex cable will remain connected to both panels. Pull the panels apart slowly and gently, or the white ribbon flex cable may be unsafely removed.

Subject: Back Panel

Lines.Text: remove the two aa batteries and set them aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two AA batteries and set them aside.

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew all five 4.0 mm screws, using Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: peel off the center sticker to reveal two hidden 4.0 mm screws .
unscrew these two screws with a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel off the center sticker to reveal two hidden 4.0 mm screws. Unscrew these two screws with a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift both top left and top right rubber stickers halfway , using the sharp end of the plastic spudger .
unscrew a total of two 4.0 mm screws , under the rubber stickers , using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

now , you should have a total of ten 4.0 mm screws set aside .

Lines.Text: wedge the flat end of the spudger between the back panel and front panel .
slide the flat end of the spudger from right to left to pry the two panels apart .

Steps.Text_raw: Wedge the flat end of the spudger between the back panel and front panel. Slide the flat end of the spudger from right to left to pry the two panels apart.

Lines.Text: separate the back panel from the front panel completely , using both hands .
a white ribbon flex cable will remain connected to both panels .
pull the panels apart slowly and gently , or the white ribbon flex cable may be unsafely removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the back panel from the front panel completely, using both hands. A white ribbon flex cable will remain connected to both panels. Pull the panels apart slowly and gently, or the white ribbon flex cable may be unsafely removed.

Lines.Text: lift up and pull off the track pads left and right clickers .
use caution while lifting , lift slowly with slight pressure .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up and pull off the track pad’s left and right clickers. Use caution while lifting, lift slowly with slight pressure.

Lines.Text: grip the lower end of the ribbon flex cable ( white band ) using your thumb and index finger .
then slide the strip out toward yourself in a scooping motion .
now , you should have two completely separated panel pieces .

Steps.Text_raw: Grip the lower end of the ribbon flex cable (white band) using your thumb and index finger. Then slide the strip out toward yourself in a scooping motion. Now, you should  have two completely separated panel pieces.

Lines.Text: flip the front panel over so the front side faces up , and rotate so the keys appear upside down .
lift the upper-right corner of the sensor sticker using the sharp end of the spudger and your index finger .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the front panel over so the front side faces up, and rotate so the keys appear upside down. Lift the upper-right corner of the sensor sticker using the sharp end of the spudger and your index finger.

Lines.Text: peel the sticker off by pinching the sticker corner using your index finger and thumb .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel the sticker off by pinching the sticker corner using your index finger and  thumb.

Lines.Text: rotate the front panel around so the keys appear right-side up .
wedge the flat-head metal spudger under the pcb's bottom-right corner .
wedge and slide the spudger along the right side to reach the upper-right corner .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the front panel around so the keys appear right-side up. Wedge the flat-head metal spudger under the PCB's bottom-right corner. Wedge and slide the spudger along the right side to reach the upper-right corner.

Lines.Text: wedge the flat-head metal spudger under the pcb's bottom-left corner .
wedge and slide the spudger along the bottom side to reach the bottom-right corner .

Steps.Text_raw: Wedge the flat-head metal spudger under the PCB's bottom-left corner. Wedge and slide the spudger along the bottom side to reach the bottom-right corner.

Lines.Text: slide and nudge the spudger upward underneath the pcb .
wiggle and lift up the pcb with your thumb as you nudge the spudger up to release the pcb .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide and nudge the spudger upward underneath the PCB. Wiggle and lift up the PCB with your thumb as you nudge the spudger up to release the PCB.

Title: Remove Scanner Assembly

Lines.Text: remove the printer from the optional second paper tray .
pull out the paper tray from the front , and the duplexer from the rear .
removing the print head ( see the hp user guide ) may also reduce the chance of ink leakage while working on the printer .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the printer from the optional second paper tray. Pull out the paper tray from the front, and the duplexer from the rear. Removing the print head (see the HP user guide) may also reduce the chance of ink leakage while working on the printer.

Lines.Text: hold up the control panel with one hand , reach underneath it with the other , and pull firmly downward on the curved support to detach it from the display
lifting the display further up , reach behind the brown plastic cover , and pull it forwards to release it

Steps.Text_raw: Hold up the control panel with one hand, reach underneath it with the other, and pull firmly downward on the curved support to detach it from the display Lifting the display further up, reach behind the brown plastic cover, and pull it forwards to release it

Lines.Text: rest the machine on it's rear panel , so you can access the cable .
lift up the brown clamp , and pull out the cable
using a t-10 torx screwdriver , undo the two screws beneath the display ( pictured )

the display remains attached to the scanner assembly for now . if you need to detach it from the scanner - for instance , to operate the printer while it is open - you can detach it once the scanner assembly is removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Rest the machine on it's rear panel, so you can access the cable. Lift up the brown clamp, and pull out the cable Using a T-10 Torx screwdriver, undo the two screws beneath the display (pictured) The display remains attached to the scanner assembly for now. If you need to detach it from the scanner - for instance, to operate the printer while it is open - you can detach it once the scanner assembly is removed.

Lines.Text: on the back of the printer , remove the two screws on the right hand side ( left-hand when viewed from the front .
using a spudger lever firmly outwards on the lower rear side of the panel .
with your other hand , push the panel backwards , it will slide half a centimeter backwards and come free .
could you help me ? it would be useful if you could take an image of the rear of the printer , add it to this guide , so the locations of various screws can be marked .

Steps.Text_raw: On the back of the printer, remove the two screws on the right hand side (left-hand when viewed from the front. Using a spudger lever firmly outwards on the lower rear side of the panel. With your other hand, push the panel backwards, It will slide half a centimeter backwards and come free. Could you help me? It would be useful if you could take an image of the rear of the printer, add it to this guide, so the locations of various screws can be marked.

Lines.Text: disconnect the scanner flatfex , sheet feeder and led cables ( marked in red ) .
remove the earth strap ( marked in yellow ) .
no other cables need to be removed at this time .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the scanner flatfex, sheet feeder and LED cables (marked in red). Remove the earth strap (marked in yellow). No other cables need to be removed at this time.

Lines.Text: remove the remaining screws around the top of the printer .
lift the scanner assembly away from the printer .

if you need to detach the display , lay the scanner assembly upside down , lower the display assembly , push it to the right , and then adjust the angle of the display until it drops away from the scanner . reconnect it to the flat-flex cable , and clip the support back into the rear to hold it . the printer will operate normally without the scanner .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the remaining screws around the top of the printer. Lift the scanner assembly away from the printer. If you need to detach the display, lay the scanner assembly upside down, lower the display assembly, push it to the right, and then adjust the angle of the display until it drops away from the scanner. Reconnect it to the flat-flex cable, and clip the support back into the rear to hold it. The printer will operate normally without the scanner.

release the two clips on the underside of the printer .

Lines.Text: remove the three screws from the bracket between the end of the carriage support and the case . remove this bracket .

detach the smaller hose from the t joint .
pull up on the carriage support . this should give you enough room to work the cleaning station out of the printer .

Title: Fix False Paper Jam Error.

Lines.Text: the symptoms of this fault are :

the printer displays a 'paper jam' error , and tells you to remove the rear duplexer , and says that you may need to open the front cover too . when you touch 'ok' , nothing happens , unless you open and close the front door .

when you open and close the front door and then touch 'ok' , the printer mechanism moves a little and then it displays the error again . occasionally the printer may move through most of a full initialization before stopping again .

if you bypass the door close mechanism ( place an opaque object in the rectangular slot on the left hand side ) , you will see that the paper feed rollers are moving a small distance back , the carriage moves to the left slightly , then the feed rollers move forward and stop .

shine a light into the printer , and check over on the far right for a small lever . this lever should slide to the right with gentle pressure , and spring back into position . if it doesn't slide back , try pulling it gently to the left .
if you can move the lever back and forth but it doesn't spring , then you need to disassemble your printer and replace this spring .

Steps.Text_raw: The symptoms of this fault are: The printer displays a 'Paper Jam' error, and tells you to remove the rear duplexer, and says that you may need to open the front cover too. When you touch 'OK', nothing happens, unless you open and close the front door. When you open and close the front door and then touch 'OK', the printer mechanism moves a little and then it displays the error again. Occasionally the printer may move through most of a full initialization before stopping again. If you bypass the door close mechanism (place an opaque object in the rectangular slot on the left hand side), you will see that the paper feed rollers are moving a small distance back, the carriage moves to the left slightly, then the feed rollers move forward and stop. Shine a light into the printer, and check over on the far right for a small lever. This lever should slide to the right with gentle pressure, and spring back into position. If it doesn't slide back, try pulling it gently to the left. If you can move the lever back and forth but it doesn't spring, then you need to disassemble your printer and replace this spring.

removing the print head ( see the hp user guide ) may also reduce the chance of ink leakage while working on the printer .

with clean hands or gloves , depress the sprung bracket on the right , and release the plastic sensor strip . then undo it from the hook on the left side . lay it over the print head , and secure it with a clean object .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three screws from the bracket between the end of the carriage support and the case. Remove this bracket. With clean hands or gloves, depress the sprung bracket on the right, and release the plastic sensor strip. Then undo it from the hook on the left side. Lay it over the print head, and secure it with a clean object. It is essential that you do not crease, twist or soil this strip. Small amounts of ink can be removed with a mild solvent, such as isopropyl alcohol, but other solvents may remove the fine lines printed on it. It may be safer to remove it at this point, but it is hard to feed it back through the print head assembly. Remove the two bolts holding the steel rod to the chassis, and slide it out of the printer. Lines.Text: lift out the wiper/cap assembly .
release the clip on the left hand side , and remove the small moulding .
carefully spring back the small black plastic blade retaining the lever , and lift it up out of the assembly .
this small plastic blade is thin and fragile . push it back just enough to allow the support to push past it .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift out the wiper/cap assembly. Release the clip on the left hand side, and remove the small moulding. Lines.Text: you should now be able to see , covered in lots of ink , the broken spring . my pictures were taken during reassembly , after i had given everything a thorough cleaning .

it is much nicer to work on this if you first give it a thorough cleaning . to do this you either need to remove the ink-soaked pads , ( some of which are glued in ) , or wash the entire assembly with the pads in place , which means you will need to leave them a long time to dry .
my replacement spring , shown in these pictures , was wound from some fine music wire i had on hand , it is too flimsy , but seems to work ok . you should use a more substantial spring than this .
open the clips on each side of the bar , allowing the spring retainer to move .
slide the bar out the left hand side of the cleaning station , pulling the end cog and the spring retainer off the bar .

Steps.Text_raw: You should now be able to see, covered in lots of ink, the broken spring. My pictures were taken during reassembly, after I had given everything a thorough cleaning. It is much nicer to work on this if you first give it a thorough cleaning. To do this you either need to remove the ink-soaked pads, (some of which are glued in), or wash the entire assembly with the pads in place, which means you will need to leave them a long time to dry. My replacement spring, shown in these pictures, was wound from some fine music wire I had on hand, It is too flimsy, but seems to work OK. You should use a more substantial spring than this. Open the clips on each side of the bar, allowing the spring retainer to move. Slide the bar out the left hand side of the cleaning station, pulling the end cog and the spring retainer off the bar.

Lines.Text: if you have not cleaned the entire station , at least wash the parts of the cog assembly , and mop up some of the ink in the station with paper towels or shop rags .

poke the bar in through the left side , then place over it the replacement spring and the spring retainer . the clips of the retainer go towards the spring . do not slide the retainer all the way home yet .
place put the sliding cog over the bar , taking note of the direction . slide the spring retainer home . the sliding cog will locate in the hole in the housing on the right .

Steps.Text_raw: If you have not cleaned the entire station, at least wash the parts of the cog assembly, and mop up some of the ink in the station with paper towels or shop rags. Poke the bar in through the left side, then place over it the replacement spring and the spring retainer. The clips of the retainer go towards the spring. Do not slide the retainer all the way home yet. Place put the sliding cog over the bar, taking note of the direction. Slide the spring retainer home. The sliding cog will locate in the hole in the housing on the right.

Lines.Text: replace the small molding on the left side .
apply grease to the cog , bar , the rack under the wiper assembly , and any other places where the parts slide against each other .

replace the lever . ensure it hooks into the end of the white sprung cog assembly . ensure that the lever moves smoothly back , pushing the cog on the other side out , and then springs firmly back into position .
replace the top cover and secure it with the 4 screws .
replace the front cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the small molding on the left side. Apply grease to the cog, bar, the rack under the wiper assembly, and any other places where the parts slide against each other. Replace the lever. Ensure it hooks into the end of the white sprung cog assembly. Ensure that the lever moves smoothly back, pushing the cog on the other side out, and then springs firmly back into position. Replace the top cover and secure it with the 4 screws. Replace the front cover.

Lines.Text: once the old ribbon cable has been detached from the lens/battery bundle it's time to release the other side from the base .
locate the screws holding the base together by feeling for the soft spots underneath the manufacturer's sticker . punch through with your screwdriver and remove the three 3 mm phillips 0 screws .
the two pieces of the base can now be easily pulled apart .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the old ribbon cable has been detached from the lens/battery bundle it's time to release the other side from the base. Locate the screws holding the base together by feeling for the soft spots underneath the manufacturer's sticker. Punch through with your screwdriver and remove the three 3mm Phillips #0 screws. The two pieces of the base can now be easily pulled apart.
